Although the spots in our picture are geometrical figures, geometry can obviously say nothing about their actual form and position. But the network is purely geometrical; all its properties can be given a priori.

18 January, 1915

Fast nichts gearbeitet. Fühlte mich ganz matt & ohne jedes Animo. Es wird aber wohl anders werden. ——. ————.

Did almost no work. Felt completely weak and without any brio. But probably things will change. ——. ————.

18 January, 1915

Der Vergleich zwischen Satz & Beschreibung ist rein logisch und muß daher weiter geführt werden.

The comparison between proposition and description is purely logical and for that reason must be pursued.

The comparison between proposition and description is purely logical and for that reason must be pursued.

18 January, 1915

Der Vergleich zwischen Satz & Beschreibung ist rein logisch und muß daher weiter geführt werden.

The comparison between proposition and description is purely logical and for that reason must be pursued.

The comparison between proposition and description is purely logical and for that reason must be pursued.

19 January, 1915

Sehr wenig gearbeitet. In dieser Beziehung ganz tot. Nur sich zu nichts zwingen!!! Wann werde ich eine Nachricht von David erhalten?! ——.

Worked very little. Quite dead in that respect. Just don't force yourself!!! When will I get some news from David?! ——.

20 January, 1915

Nichts gearbeitet; aber diese Ruhe ist wie der erquickende Schlaf.

Didn’t work; but this rest is like a refreshing sleep.

20 January, 1915

Wieso ist Alle ein logischer Begriff?

How is it that all is a logical concept?

How is it that all is a logical concept?

20 January, 1915

Wieso ist Alle ein Begriff der Form??

How is it that all is a concept of form??

How is it that all is a concept of form??

20 January, 1915

Wie kommt es daß Alle in jedem Satz vorkommen kann?

Denn dies ist das Charakteristikum des Formbegriffs!

How does it come about that all can occur in any proposition?

For that is characteristic of the concept of form.

How does it come about that all can occur in any proposition?

For that is characteristic of the concept of form.

20 January, 1915

Alle scheint dem Inhalt des Satzes näher zu stehen als der Form. / Alle: Dinge, Alle: Funktionen, Alle: Beziehungen: Es ist als ob Alle ein Bindeglied zwischen dem Begriff des Dinges, der Funktion etc. und dem einzelnen Ding der einzelnen Funktion sei.

All appears to be closer to the proposition’s content than to its form. All: things, All: functions, All: relations: It is as if All were a connecting link between the concept of thing, function, etc., and the individual thing, the individual functions.

All appears to be closer to the proposition’s content than to its form. All: things, All: functions, All: relations: It is as if All were a connecting link between the concept of thing, function, etc., and the individual thing, the individual functions.

20 January, 1915

Die Allgemeinheit ist wesentlich mit der Elementar-Form verbunden.

Generality is essentially connected with the elementary form.

Generality is essentially connected with the elementary form.

20 January, 1915

Das erlösende Wort –?!

The redeeming word -?!

The redeeming word -?!

20 January, 1915

Wieso ist Alle ein logischer Begriff?

How is it that all is a logical concept?

How is it that all is a logical concept?

20 January, 1915

Wieso ist Alle ein Begriff der Form??

How is it that all is a concept of form??

How is it that all is a concept of form??

20 January, 1915

Wie kommt es daß Alle in jedem Satz vorkommen kann?

Denn dies ist das Charakteristikum des Formbegriffs!

How does it come about that all can occur in any proposition?

For that is characteristic of the concept of form.

How does it come about that all can occur in any proposition?

For that is characteristic of the concept of form.

20 January, 1915

Alle scheint dem Inhalt des Satzes näher zu stehen als der Form. / Alle: Dinge, Alle: Funktionen, Alle: Beziehungen: Es ist als ob Alle ein Bindeglied zwischen dem Begriff des Dinges, der Funktion etc. und dem einzelnen Ding der einzelnen Funktion sei.

All appears to be closer to the proposition’s content than to its form. All: things, All: functions, All: relations: It is as if All were a connecting link between the concept of thing, function, etc., and the individual thing, the individual functions.

All appears to be closer to the proposition’s content than to its form. All: things, All: functions, All: relations: It is as if All were a connecting link between the concept of thing, function, etc., and the individual thing, the individual functions.

20 January, 1915

Die Allgemeinheit ist wesentlich mit der Elementar-Form verbunden.

Generality is essentially connected with the elementary form.

Generality is essentially connected with the elementary form.

20 January, 1915

Das erlösende Wort –?!

The redeeming word -?!

The redeeming word -?!

21 January, 1915

Etwas gearbeitet. Brief an David abgeschickt. Ging mit ihm direkt zum Zensor an der hiesigen / Hauptpost der ein sehr netter Mensch ist.

Worked a bit. Sent letter to David. Took it directly to the censor at the local general post office who is a very nice person.

21 January, 1915

Der Übergang von der allgemeinen Betrachtung der Satzform: Unendlich schwierig, fabelhaft.

Moving on from general consideration of propositional form: immensely difficult, fabulous.

Moving on from general consideration of propositional form: immensely difficult, fabulous.

21 January, 1915

Der Übergang von der allgemeinen Betrachtung der Satzform: Unendlich schwierig, fabelhaft.

Moving on from general consideration of propositional form: immensely difficult, fabulous.

Moving on from general consideration of propositional form: immensely difficult, fabulous.

22 January, 1915

Gearbeitet.

Worked.

22 January, 1915

Meine ganze Aufgabe besteht darin, das Wesen des Satzes zu erklären. / Das heißt, das Wesen aller Tatsachen anzugeben, deren Bild der Satz ist.

My whole task consists in explaining the nature of the proposition. That is to say, in giving the nature of all facts, whose picture the proposition is.

My whole task consists in explaining the nature of the proposition. That is to say, in giving the nature of all facts, whose picture the proposition is.

22 January, 1915

Das Wesen alles Seins angeben.

In giving the nature of all being.

In giving the nature of all being.

22 January, 1915

(Und hier bedeutet Sein nicht existieren – dann wäre es unsinnig.)

(And here „being“ does not mean existing—if so, it would be nonsensical.)

(And here „being“ does not mean existing—if so, it would be nonsensical.)

22 January, 1915

Meine ganze Aufgabe besteht darin, das Wesen des Satzes zu erklären. / Das heißt, das Wesen aller Tatsachen anzugeben, deren Bild der Satz ist.

My whole task consists in explaining the nature of the proposition. That is to say, in giving the nature of all facts, whose picture the proposition is.

My whole task consists in explaining the nature of the proposition. That is to say, in giving the nature of all facts, whose picture the proposition is.

22 January, 1915

Das Wesen alles Seins angeben.

In giving the nature of all being.

In giving the nature of all being.

22 January, 1915

(Und hier bedeutet Sein nicht existieren – dann wäre es unsinnig.)

(And here „being“ does not mean existing—if so, it would be nonsensical.)

(And here „being“ does not mean existing—if so, it would be nonsensical.)

23 January, 1915

Etwas gearbeitet. Komme jetzt durch meine unausgesprochene Stellung in Schwierigkeiten. Nur sich selbst besitzen! ——.

Worked a bit. Getting in trouble now due to my unspoken position. Just be self-possessed! ——.

 TLP 5·2341 (2)**

The sense of a truth-function of p is a function of the sense of p.

(Negation reverses the sense of a sentence.)

Negation, disjunction, logical multiplication, etc., are operations.

23 January, 1915

Die Verneinung ist eine Operation.

Negation is an operation. [Cf. 5.2341 (2).]

Negation is an operation. [Cf. 5.2341 (2).]

Negation, disjunction, logical multiplication, etc., are operations.

23 January, 1915

Eine Operation bezeichnet eine Operation.

An operation refers to an operation.

An operation refers to an operation.

23 January, 1915

Das Wort ist eine Sonde, manches reicht tief; manches nur wenig tief.

Words are probes: some reach deep, some only a little way.

Words are probes: some reach deep, some only a little way.

TLP 5·25 (2)**

The occurrence of an operation does not characterize the sense of a sentence.

Indeed, an operation states nothing, only its result does, and this depends on the operation’s bases.

(Operation and function must not be confused with each other.)

Of course the mere occurrence of an operation in a proposition cannot say anything.

23 January, 1915

Eine Operation sagt natürlich nichts aus, nur ihr Resultat, und dies hängt von ihrem / Gegenstand ab.

Die logischen Scheinfunktionen sind Operationen.

Indeed, an operation says nothing, only its result does; and this depends on its object. [Cf. 5.25 (2).]

Logical pseudo-functions are operations.

Indeed, an operation says nothing, only its result does; and this depends on its object. [Cf. 5.25 (2).]

Logical pseudo-functions are operations.

Of course the mere occurrence of an operation in a proposition cannot say anything.

TLP 5·2341 (2)**

The sense of a truth-function of p is a function of the sense of p.

(Negation reverses the sense of a sentence.)

Negation, disjunction, logical multiplication, etc., are operations.

23 January, 1915

Die Verneinung ist eine Operation.

Negation is an operation. [Cf. 5.2341 (2).]

Negation is an operation. [Cf. 5.2341 (2).]

Negation, disjunction, logical multiplication, etc., are operations.

23 January, 1915

Eine Operation bezeichnet eine Operation.

An operation refers to an operation.

An operation refers to an operation.

23 January, 1915

Das Wort ist eine Sonde, manches reicht tief; manches nur wenig tief.

Words are probes: some reach deep, some only a little way.

Words are probes: some reach deep, some only a little way.

TLP 5·25 (2)**

The occurrence of an operation does not characterize the sense of a sentence.

Indeed, an operation states nothing, only its result does, and this depends on the operation’s bases.

(Operation and function must not be confused with each other.)

Of course the mere occurrence of an operation in a proposition cannot say anything.

23 January, 1915

Eine Operation sagt natürlich nichts aus, nur ihr Resultat, und dies hängt von ihrem / Gegenstand ab.

Die logischen Scheinfunktionen sind Operationen.

Indeed, an operation says nothing, only its result does; and this depends on its object. [Cf. 5.25 (2).]

Logical pseudo-functions are operations.

Indeed, an operation says nothing, only its result does; and this depends on its object. [Cf. 5.25 (2).]

Logical pseudo-functions are operations.

Of course the mere occurrence of an operation in a proposition cannot say anything.

24 January, 1915

Etwas gearbeitet. ——.

Worked a bit. ——.

 TLP 5·254*

Operations can vanish (for example, negation in “~~p”: ~~p = p).

Only operations can vanish (e.g. negation in ~~p).

24 January, 1915

Nur Operationen können verschwinden!

Only operations can vanish. [Cf. 5.254.]

Only operations can vanish. [Cf. 5.254.]

Only operations can vanish (e.g. negation in ~~p).

24 January, 1915

Der negative Satz schließt die Wirklichkeit aus.

Negative propositions exclude reality.

Negative propositions exclude reality.

TLP 5·511

How can an all-embracing, world-reflecting logic use such contrived hooks and manipulations? Only by their all knitting themselves together into an infinitely fine network, the great mirror.

How can an all-embracing world-reflecting logic use such contrived hooks and manipulations? Only because they are all connected together in an infinitely fine network, the great mirror.

24 January, 1915

Wie kann die allumfassende, weltspiegelnde Logik so spezielle Haken & Manipulationen gebrauchen?! Nur indem sich alle diese zusammen zu einem unendlich feinen Netzwerk, zu dem großen Spiegel verknüpfen!

How can an all-embracing, world-reflecting logic use such contrived hooks and manipulations? Only by knitting them all together in an infinitely fine network, the great mirror. [See 5.511.]

How can an all-embracing, world-reflecting logic use such contrived hooks and manipulations? Only by knitting them all together in an infinitely fine network, the great mirror. [See 5.511.]

How can an all-embracing world-reflecting logic use such contrived hooks and manipulations? Only because they are all connected together in an infinitely fine network, the great mirror.

TLP 5·254*

Operations can vanish (for example, negation in “~~p”: ~~p = p).

Only operations can vanish (e.g. negation in ~~p).

24 January, 1915

Nur Operationen können verschwinden!

Only operations can vanish. [Cf. 5.254.]

Only operations can vanish. [Cf. 5.254.]

Only operations can vanish (e.g. negation in ~~p).

24 January, 1915

Der negative Satz schließt die Wirklichkeit aus.

Negative propositions exclude reality.

Negative propositions exclude reality.

TLP 5·511

How can an all-embracing, world-reflecting logic use such contrived hooks and manipulations? Only by their all knitting themselves together into an infinitely fine network, the great mirror.

How can an all-embracing world-reflecting logic use such contrived hooks and manipulations? Only because they are all connected together in an infinitely fine network, the great mirror.

24 January, 1915

Wie kann die allumfassende, weltspiegelnde Logik so spezielle Haken & Manipulationen gebrauchen?! Nur indem sich alle diese zusammen zu einem unendlich feinen Netzwerk, zu dem großen Spiegel verknüpfen!

How can an all-embracing, world-reflecting logic use such contrived hooks and manipulations? Only by knitting them all together in an infinitely fine network, the great mirror. [See 5.511.]

How can an all-embracing, world-reflecting logic use such contrived hooks and manipulations? Only by knitting them all together in an infinitely fine network, the great mirror. [See 5.511.]

How can an all-embracing world-reflecting logic use such contrived hooks and manipulations? Only because they are all connected together in an infinitely fine network, the great mirror.

25 January, 1915

Brief von Keynes! Nicht sehr lieb. In den letzten Tagen sehr sinnlich. —— Ohne Erfolg gearbeitet. Ich bin ganz im Dunkeln darüber wie meine Arbeit weiter gehen wird. Nur durch Wunder kann sie gelingen. Nur dadurch / indem von außerhalb mir der Schleier von meinen Augen weggenommen wird. Ich muß mich ganz in mein Schicksal ergeben. Wie es über mich verhängt ist so wird es werden. Ich lebe in der Hand des Schicksals. (Nur nicht klein werden.) Und so kann ich nicht klein werden. ——.

Letter from Keynes! Not very nice. Very sensual in the last few days. —— Worked without success. I am completely in the dark about how my work will go on. It can only succeed by a miracle. Only from outside myself, in the veil’s being taken away from my eyes. I must surrender myself completely to my fate. As it is imposed on me, so will it be. I live in the hand of fate. (Just don't become petty.) So I can't become petty. ——.

25 January, 1915

Man kann auch sagen; ~p ist falsch, wenn p wahr ist.

One can also say: if p is true, ~p is false.

One can also say: if p is true, ~p is false.

25 January, 1915

Man kann auch sagen; ~p ist falsch, wenn p wahr ist.

One can also say: if p is true, ~p is false.

One can also say: if p is true, ~p is false.

26 January, 1915

Liebe Karte von Arne erhalten. Etwas — aber erfolglos — gearbeitet.

Got a nice card from Arne. Worked a bit, but unsuccessfully.

27 January, 1915

Nicht gearbeitet. Abends mit vielen Offizieren im Kaffee. Die meisten benahmen sich wie Schweine. Selbst ich trank ein ganz klein / wenig mehr als nötig.

Didn’t work. In the evening with many officers in the café. Most behaved like pigs. Even I drank a tiny bit more than necessary.

28 January, 1915

Nicht gearbeitet was mir sehr gesund ist — nämlich der Arbeit. Sehr sinnlich was merkwürdig ist weil ich jetzt nicht wenig Bewegung mache. Schlafe nicht gut.

Didn’t work which is very healthy for me - namely work. Very sensual which is strange because I’m doing quite a bit of exercise now. Not sleeping well.

29 January, 1915

Fast nicht gearbeitet.

Did almost no work.

 TLP 3·141 (2)

A sentence is not a mixture of words. – (Just as a musical theme is not a mixture of notes.)

A proposition is not a jumble of words. (Just as a tune is not a jumble of notes.)

29 January, 1915

Die Sprache ist artikuliert.

Language is articulate. [Cf. 3.141 (2).]

Language is articulate. [Cf. 3.141 (2).]

A proposition is not a jumble of words. (Just as a tune is not a jumble of notes.)

TLP 3·141 (2)

A sentence is not a mixture of words. – (Just as a musical theme is not a mixture of notes.)

A proposition is not a jumble of words. (Just as a tune is not a jumble of notes.)

29 January, 1915

Die Sprache ist artikuliert.

Language is articulate. [Cf. 3.141 (2).]

Language is articulate. [Cf. 3.141 (2).]

A proposition is not a jumble of words. (Just as a tune is not a jumble of notes.)

30 January, 1915

Nicht gearbeitet. Habe mich viel über meine äußere Stellung aufregen müssen & werde in dieser Sache wahrscheinlich bald einen entscheidenden Schritt tun. ——————.

Didn’t work. Have been very upset about my external position and will probably take a decisive step in this business soon. ——————.

31 January, 1915

Nicht gearbeitet. ————.

Didn’t work. ————.

1 February, 1915

Nicht gearbeitet. Zu Mittag in der Offiziersmesse des Hauptmannes Scholz wo es sehr gemütlich war. ——.

Didn’t work. In Captain Scholz’s officers' mess at noon, which was very pleasant. ——.

2 February, 1915

Ein klein wenig gearbeitet. ——.

Worked a little bit. ——.

3 February, 1915

Nicht gearbeitet. Keine Ideen. Soll jetzt die Aufsicht über unsere Schmiede übernehmen. Wie wird das gehen? Möge der Geist mir beistehen! Es wird sehr schwierig werden aber: nur Mut! ——. ————.

Didn’t work. No ideas. Supposed to take over the supervision of our forge now. How will that work? May the spirit help me! It will be very difficult. However: courage! ——. ————.

5 February, 1915

Nicht gearbeitet. Bin jetzt viel in der Schmiede.: ——.

Didn’t work. I'm in the forge a lot now. ——.

6 February, 1915

Lieben Brief von David (vom 14.1.)

Lovely letter from David (from 14 January).

7 February, 1915

Nicht gearbeitet. ——! ——.

Didn’t work. ——! ——.

 TLP 3·141 (1)**

A sentence is not a mixture of words. – (Just as a musical theme is not a mixture of notes.)

A proposition is not a jumble of words. (Just as a tune is not a jumble of notes.)

7 February, 1915

Die musikalischen Themen sind in gewissem Sinne Sätze. Die Kenntnis des Wesens der Logik wird deshalb zur Kenntnis des Wesens der Musik führen.

Musical themes are in a certain sense propositions. So knowledge of the nature of logic will lead to knowledge of the nature of music. [Cf. 3.141 (1).]

Musical themes are in a certain sense propositions. So knowledge of the nature of logic will lead to knowledge of the nature of music. [Cf. 3.141 (1).]

A proposition is not a jumble of words. (Just as a tune is not a jumble of notes.)

TLP 3·141 (1)**

A sentence is not a mixture of words. – (Just as a musical theme is not a mixture of notes.)

A proposition is not a jumble of words. (Just as a tune is not a jumble of notes.)

7 February, 1915

Die musikalischen Themen sind in gewissem Sinne Sätze. Die Kenntnis des Wesens der Logik wird deshalb zur Kenntnis des Wesens der Musik führen.

Musical themes are in a certain sense propositions. So knowledge of the nature of logic will lead to knowledge of the nature of music. [Cf. 3.141 (1).]

Musical themes are in a certain sense propositions. So knowledge of the nature of logic will lead to knowledge of the nature of music. [Cf. 3.141 (1).]

A proposition is not a jumble of words. (Just as a tune is not a jumble of notes.)

8 February, 1915

Von Ficker ein nachgelassenes Werk Trakls erhalten. Wahrscheinlich sehr gut. —— Sinnlich. Habe jetzt gar keine Handhabe für meine Arbeit. —— ————.

Received a posthumous work of Trakl’s from Ficker. Probably very good. —— Sensual. Have hardly any grip on my work now. —— ————.

9 February, 1915

Nicht gearbeitet. ——. ————.

Didn’t work. ——. ————.

10 February, 1915

Nicht gearbeitet. Netten Brief von Ficker. Widmung von Rilke. Könnte ich nur schon wieder / arbeiten!!! Alles andere würde sich finden. Wann wird mir wieder etwas einfallen??! Alles das liegt in Gottes Hand. Wünsche nur und hoffe! Dann verlierst du keine Zeit. —— ————.

Didn’t work. Nice letter from Ficker. Dedication by Rilke. If only I could only work again!!! Everything else would turn out all right. When will I think of something again?? All of that is in God's hands. Just wish and hope! Then you won't waste any time. —— ————.

11 February, 1915

Nicht gearbeitet. —— Stehe jetzt mit einem der Offiziere – dem Kadetten Adam – auf sehr gespannten Fuße. Es ist möglich daß es zwischen uns zu einem Duell kommt. Lebe deswegen immer noch gut & nach deinem Gewissen. Der Geist sei mit mir! Jetzt und in jeder Zukunft! ————.

Didn’t work. —— Now on a very tense footing with Cadet Adam, one of the officers. It is possible that there will be a duel between us. So, keep on living well and follow your conscience. The spirit be with me! Now and whatever the future may bring! ————.

13 February, 1915

Nicht gearbeitet. Der Geist sei mit / mir. ————.

Didn’t work. The spirit be with me. ————.

TLP 4·023 (1-2)*

Sentences must capture reality in terms of yes or no.

To achieve this, they must describe it completely.

A sentence is a description of a state of affairs.

Just as a description describes an object in accordance with its external properties, so a sentence describes reality in accordance with its internal properties.

Relying on a logical scaffolding a sentence constructs a world, which is why one can see from the sentence how all logical matters stand, if the sentence is true. One can draw inferences from a false sentence.

A proposition shows how things stand, if it is true.

14 February, 1915

Gäbe es mathematische Gegenstände – logische Konstante – so wäre der Satz „ich esse 5 Pflaumen” ein Satz der Mathematik. Und er ist auch kein Satz der angewandten Mathematik.

If there were mathematical objects – logical constants – the proposition "I am eating five plums" would be a proposition of mathematics. And it is not even a proposition of applied mathematics.

If there were mathematical objects – logical constants – the proposition "I am eating five plums" would be a proposition of mathematics. And it is not even a proposition of applied mathematics.

A proposition shows how things stand, if it is true.

14 February, 1915

Der Satz muß seine Bedeutung vollständig beschreiben.

A proposition must describe its meaning completely. [Cf. 4.023.]

A proposition must describe its meaning completely. [Cf. 4.023.]

TLP 4·023 (1-2)*

Sentences must capture reality in terms of yes or no.

To achieve this, they must describe it completely.

A sentence is a description of a state of affairs.

Just as a description describes an object in accordance with its external properties, so a sentence describes reality in accordance with its internal properties.

Relying on a logical scaffolding a sentence constructs a world, which is why one can see from the sentence how all logical matters stand, if the sentence is true. One can draw inferences from a false sentence.

A proposition shows how things stand, if it is true.

14 February, 1915

Gäbe es mathematische Gegenstände – logische Konstante – so wäre der Satz „ich esse 5 Pflaumen” ein Satz der Mathematik. Und er ist auch kein Satz der angewandten Mathematik.

If there were mathematical objects – logical constants – the proposition "I am eating five plums" would be a proposition of mathematics. And it is not even a proposition of applied mathematics.

If there were mathematical objects – logical constants – the proposition "I am eating five plums" would be a proposition of mathematics. And it is not even a proposition of applied mathematics.

A proposition shows how things stand, if it is true.

14 February, 1915

Der Satz muß seine Bedeutung vollständig beschreiben.

A proposition must describe its meaning completely. [Cf. 4.023.]

A proposition must describe its meaning completely. [Cf. 4.023.]

15 February, 1915

Gestern etwas gearbeitet. Es vergeht ja jetzt kein Tag an dem ich nicht einmal wenn auch nur flüchtig an die Logik denke & dies ist ein gutes Zeichen. Ich ahne alles Mögliche! – Gestern abend bei Hauptmann Scholz wo musiziert wurde (bis 12 p.m.). Sehr gemütlich.

Worked a bit yesterday. Not a day goes by now that I don't think about logic, even if only briefly, and this is a good sign. I think anything’s possible! – Yesterday evening at Captain Scholz’s, where there was music (until 12 p.m.) Very pleasant.

17 February, 1915

Gestern & heute etwas gearbeitet. Meine Stellung im Detachement ist jetzt durchaus unbefriedigend, es wird etwas geschehen müssen. —— Ich muß mich viel ärgern & kränken und meine innere Kraft vergeuden. Bin wieder sehr sinnlich & onaniere / fast jeden Tag: So geht es nicht weiter. ——

Worked a bit today and yesterday. My position in the detachment is now thoroughly unsatisfactory, something will have to be done. —— I can’t help getting annoyed and offended a lot and wasting my internal strength. I'm very sensual again and masturbate almost every day: it can't go on like this. ——

18 February, 1915

Fast nicht gearbeitet. Viel über meine Lage nachgedacht. Ich bin auf meine Zukunft in jeder Hinsicht neugierig. ——.

Did almost no work. Thought a lot about my situation. I wonder about my future from every point of view. ——.

18 February, 1915

a R b

~c S d

a R b

~c S d

a R b

~c S d

18 February, 1915

a R b

~c S d

a R b

~c S d

a R b

~c S d

19 February, 1915

Neuerliche Unannehmlichkeiten in der Fabrik. Langes Gespräch mit meinem Kommandanten das aber zu nichts Rechtem geführt hat. Fast nicht gearbeitet. Diese Unannehmlichkeiten stören mich im Denken. Das muß anders werden. ——. ——.

Renewed trouble in the factory. Long conversation with my commander but that didn't lead to anything positive. Did almost no work. These troubles disturb my thinking. That must change. ——. ——.

20 February, 1915

Feiger Gedanken bängliches / Schwanken, ängstliches Zagen, weibliches Klagen, wendet kein Elend, macht dich nicht frei! Nicht gearbeitet. Viel gedacht. ————.

Cowardly thinking, fearful wavering, anxious hesitating, effeminate complaining, remedy no misery, won’t set you free! Didn’t work. Thought a lot. ————.

21 February, 1915

Nicht gearbeitet. Besserer Stimmung. Sinnlich. Könnte ich nur schon wieder arbeiten!!!! ——! ——.

Didn’t work. Better mood. Sensual. If only I could work again!!!! ——! ——.

22 February, 1915

Nicht gearbeitet. Heute nacht riesig viel und lebhaft aber nicht schlecht geträumt. Viel Unannehmlichkeiten mit der Mannschaft. Ärger & Aufregung; Selbstvorwürfe etc. etc. ——. ————.

Didn’t work. Very many vivid dreams last night, but not bad ones. A lot of trouble with the crew. Annoyance & agitation; self-reproach etc. etc. ——. ————.

23 February, 1915

Nicht gearbeitet. Meine Schwierigkeiten / noch immer nicht geregelt. ————.

Didn’t work. My difficulties are still not resolved. ————.

26 February, 1915

Nicht gearbeitet! Werde ich je wieder arbeiten?!? Trüber Stimmung. Keine Nachricht von David. Bin ganz verlassen. Denke an Selbstmord. Werde ich je wieder arbeiten??! —— ————.

Didn’t work! Will I ever work again?!? Gloomy mood. No news from David. Am utterly lonely. Think of suicide. Will I ever work again??! —— ————.

27 February, 1915

Nicht gearbeitet. Trübe Stimmung. Sehr sinnlich. Fühle mich vereinsamt. Das Ziel meiner Arbeit scheint mir mehr denn je in unabsehbare Ferne gerückt! Der siegesgewisse und kühn hoffende Mut fehlt mir. Es ist mir als sollte ich nie mehr eine große / Entdeckung machen. Schon lang war ich nicht so von allen guten Geistern verlassen wie jetzt. Verliere nur nicht dich selbst!! ——. ——.

Didn’t work. Gloomy mood. Very sensual. Feel very isolated. The goal of my work seems to me more than ever to have receded into an indeterminable distance! I lack the courage to be sure of victory and hope boldly. It seems to me as if I shall never again make a big discovery. It’s been a long time since I’ve been as forsaken by all good spirits as I am now. Just don't lose yourself!! ——. ——.

4 March, 1915

Nicht gearbeitet. Bin moralisch matt; sehe aber die enorme / Schwierigkeit meiner Lage ein und bisher bin ich mir noch ganz im Unklaren darüber wie sie zu korrigieren ist. ——.

Didn’t work. Am morally weak; but appreciate the enormous difficulty of my situation and so far I am still quite unsure how to correct it. ——.

4 March, 1915

Die Melodie ist eine Art Tautologie, sie ist in sich selbst abgeschlossen; sie befriedigt sich selbst.

A tune is a kind of tautology. It is self-contained; it satisfies itself.

A tune is a kind of tautology. It is self-contained; it satisfies itself.

4 March, 1915

Die Melodie ist eine Art Tautologie, sie ist in sich selbst abgeschlossen; sie befriedigt sich selbst.

A tune is a kind of tautology. It is self-contained; it satisfies itself.

A tune is a kind of tautology. It is self-contained; it satisfies itself.

5 March, 1915

Sprach heute mit Gürth über meine unwürdige Stellung. Noch keine Entscheidung. Vielleicht gehe ich als Infanterist an die Front. = .

Talked to Gurth about my humiliating position today. No decision yet. Maybe I'll go to the front as an infantryman. = .

 TLP 5·4541 (2-3)*

The solutions to logical problems must be simple, since they set the standard of simplicity.

People have always had an inkling that there must be a realm of questions where the answers – a priori – are symmetrically united and form a self-contained regular structure.

A realm governed by the maxim: simplex sigillum veri.

The solutions to logical problems must be simple, since they set the standard of simplicity.

5 March, 1915

Die Menschheit hat immer geahnt, daß es ein Gebiet von Fragen geben muß worin die Antworten – a priori – symmetrisch, und zu einem abgeschlossenen regelmäßigen Gebilde vereint – liegen.

People have always had an inkling that there must be a realm in which the answers to questions combine symmetrically - a priori - into a self-contained regular formation. [See 5.4541 (2-3).]

People have always had an inkling that there must be a realm in which the answers to questions combine symmetrically - a priori - into a self-contained regular formation. [See 5.4541 (2-3).]

The solutions to logical problems must be simple, since they set the standard of simplicity.

5 March, 1915

(Je älter ein Wort ist desto tiefer reicht es.)

(The older a word, the deeper it reaches.)

(The older a word, the deeper it reaches.)

TLP 5·4541 (2-3)*

The solutions to logical problems must be simple, since they set the standard of simplicity.

People have always had an inkling that there must be a realm of questions where the answers – a priori – are symmetrically united and form a self-contained regular structure.

A realm governed by the maxim: simplex sigillum veri.

The solutions to logical problems must be simple, since they set the standard of simplicity.

5 March, 1915

Die Menschheit hat immer geahnt, daß es ein Gebiet von Fragen geben muß worin die Antworten – a priori – symmetrisch, und zu einem abgeschlossenen regelmäßigen Gebilde vereint – liegen.

People have always had an inkling that there must be a realm in which the answers to questions combine symmetrically - a priori - into a self-contained regular formation. [See 5.4541 (2-3).]

People have always had an inkling that there must be a realm in which the answers to questions combine symmetrically - a priori - into a self-contained regular formation. [See 5.4541 (2-3).]

The solutions to logical problems must be simple, since they set the standard of simplicity.

5 March, 1915

(Je älter ein Wort ist desto tiefer reicht es.)

(The older a word, the deeper it reaches.)

(The older a word, the deeper it reaches.)

6 March, 1915

= . Meine Lage ist noch immer unentschieden. Meine Stimmung stark wechselnd. ——.

= . My situation is still undecided. My mood very unsettled. ——.

 TLP 5·511

How can an all-embracing, world-reflecting logic use such contrived hooks and manipulations? Only by their all knitting themselves together into an infinitely fine network, the great mirror.

How can an all-embracing world-reflecting logic use such contrived hooks and manipulations? Only because they are all connected together in an infinitely fine network, the great mirror.

6 March, 1915

Die Probleme der Verneinung, der Disjunktion, von Wahr & Falsch – sind nur Spiegelbilder des einen, großen Problems, in / den verschieden gestellten großen und kleinen Spiegeln der Philosophie.

The problems of negation, of disjunction, of true and false, are only reflections of the one great problem in the variously placed great and small mirrors of philosophy. [Cf. 5.511.]

The problems of negation, of disjunction, of true and false, are only reflections of the one great problem in the variously placed great and small mirrors of philosophy. [Cf. 5.511.]

How can an all-embracing world-reflecting logic use such contrived hooks and manipulations? Only because they are all connected together in an infinitely fine network, the great mirror.

TLP 5·511

How can an all-embracing, world-reflecting logic use such contrived hooks and manipulations? Only by their all knitting themselves together into an infinitely fine network, the great mirror.

How can an all-embracing world-reflecting logic use such contrived hooks and manipulations? Only because they are all connected together in an infinitely fine network, the great mirror.

6 March, 1915

Die Probleme der Verneinung, der Disjunktion, von Wahr & Falsch – sind nur Spiegelbilder des einen, großen Problems, in / den verschieden gestellten großen und kleinen Spiegeln der Philosophie.

The problems of negation, of disjunction, of true and false, are only reflections of the one great problem in the variously placed great and small mirrors of philosophy. [Cf. 5.511.]

The problems of negation, of disjunction, of true and false, are only reflections of the one great problem in the variously placed great and small mirrors of philosophy. [Cf. 5.511.]

How can an all-embracing world-reflecting logic use such contrived hooks and manipulations? Only because they are all connected together in an infinitely fine network, the great mirror.

7 March, 1915

= . Lage unverändert; unbehaglich. Bin mir noch ganz im Unklaren über eine geeignete Veränderung. Jetzt bricht wieder / starker Frost herein! Sehr zur Unzeit! Fühle mich nicht wohl. Bin sozusagen seelisch abgespannt, sehr abgespannt. Was dagegen zu machen ist?? Ich werde von widerlichen Umständen aufgezehrt. Das ganze äußere Leben mit seiner ganzen Gemeinheit stürmt auf mich ein. Und ich bin innerlich haßerfüllt und kann den Geist nicht in mich einlassen. Gott ist die Liebe. — Ich bin wie ein ausgebrannter Ofen voll Schlacke und Unrat. ——

——————

——————

=. Situation unchanged; uneasy. I'm still in the dark about an appropriate change. Heavy frost has returned again! Very much out of season! I don't feel at all well. I'm mentally weary, so to speak, very weary. On the other hand, what is to be done about it?? I am exhausted by loathesome circumstances. The whole of outer life, with all its viciousness, assaults me. And I’m filled with hatred inside and can’t let the spirit in me. God is love. — I'm like a burned-out furnace full of slag and garbage. ——

——————

——————

7 March, 1915

Wie ~ξ, ~ξ . ⌵ . ~ξ etc. dieselbe Funktion ist so ist auch ~η ⌵ η, η⊃η etc. dieselbe – nämlich die tautologische – Funktion. Wie die anderen so kann auch sie – und vielleicht mit Vorteil – untersucht werden.

Just as ~ξ, ~ξ . ⌵ . ~ξ etc. are the same function, so too are ~η ⌵ η, η⊃η, etc. the same – that is, the tautological – function. Like the others, it can be investigated – and perhaps advantageously.

Just as ~ξ, ~ξ . ⌵ . ~ξ etc. are the same function, so too are ~η ⌵ η, η⊃η, etc. the same – that is, the tautological – function. Like the others, it can be investigated – and perhaps advantageously.

7 March, 1915

Wie ~ξ, ~ξ . ⌵ . ~ξ etc. dieselbe Funktion ist so ist auch ~η ⌵ η, η⊃η etc. dieselbe – nämlich die tautologische – Funktion. Wie die anderen so kann auch sie – und vielleicht mit Vorteil – untersucht werden.

Just as ~ξ, ~ξ . ⌵ . ~ξ etc. are the same function, so too are ~η ⌵ η, η⊃η, etc. the same – that is, the tautological – function. Like the others, it can be investigated – and perhaps advantageously.

Just as ~ξ, ~ξ . ⌵ . ~ξ etc. are the same function, so too are ~η ⌵ η, η⊃η, etc. the same – that is, the tautological – function. Like the others, it can be investigated – and perhaps advantageously.

Situation undecided! Unchanged! Depression. —— ＝ . —— ——.

8 March, 1915

Meine Schwierigkeit ist nur eine – enorme – Schwierigkeit des Ausdrucks.

My difficulty is only an – enormous – difficulty of expression.

My difficulty is only an – enormous – difficulty of expression.

8 March, 1915

Meine Schwierigkeit ist nur eine – enorme – Schwierigkeit des Ausdrucks.

My difficulty is only an – enormous – difficulty of expression.

My difficulty is only an – enormous – difficulty of expression.

9 March, 1915

Lage unentschieden! = . Stimmung wachsam aber schlecht. —— ————.

Situation undecided! = . Mood: vigilant but poor. —— ————.

10 March, 1915

Sehr sinnlich. Unentschlossen. Ruhelos im Geist. ＝ . ——.

Very sensual. Irresolute. Restless in spirit. ＝ . ——.

11 March, 1915

Nicht gearbeitet. Lage unverändert! Nichts als Unannehmlichkeiten. ——. ————.

Didn’t work. Situation unchanged! Nothing but trouble. ——. ————.

12 March, 1915

Nicht gearbeitet. Viel gedacht. Lage noch unentschieden.

————.

Didn’t work. Thought a lot. Situation still undecided.

————.

13 March, 1915

Lage im Gleichen. Bin ganz unschlüssig. ＝ . ——.

Same situation. Am completely indecisive. ＝ . ——.

14 March, 1915

Lage unverändert! ——

Nicht gearbeitet. Depression. Der Druck auf die Brust. ——. ————.

Situation unchanged! ——

Didn’t work. Depression. Chest pressure. ——. ————.

15 March, 1915

Traf einen bekannten Einjährigen & besprach mit ihm meine Angelegenheit & werde morgen weiter darüber sprechen. Jetzt habe ich also meine Noten eingeholt. Und noch immer arbeite ich nicht. Werde ich je wieder arbeiten??!! —— ————

Met a one-year volunteer that I know & discussed my concerns with him & will continue to talk about it tomorrow. So now I'm dealing with that business. And I'm still not working. Will I ever work again??!! —— ————

16 March, 1915

————.

————.

18 March, 1915

Gestern lieben Brief von David! —— Bin in die Fabrik umgezogen. David geantwortet. Sehr sinnlich.

Lovely letter from David yesterday! —— Moved to the factory. Answered David. Very sensual.

18 March, 1915

Es ist klar daß die genaueste Untersuchung des Satzzeichens nicht ergeben kann was es aussagt – wohl aber was es aussagen kann.

lt is clear that the closest examination of the propositional sign cannot yield what it asserts – but what it can yield is what it is capable of asserting.

lt is clear that the closest examination of the propositional sign cannot yield what it asserts – but what it can yield is what it is capable of asserting.

18 March, 1915

Es ist klar daß die genaueste Untersuchung des Satzzeichens nicht ergeben kann was es aussagt – wohl aber was es aussagen kann.

lt is clear that the closest examination of the propositional sign cannot yield what it asserts – but what it can yield is what it is capable of asserting.

lt is clear that the closest examination of the propositional sign cannot yield what it asserts – but what it can yield is what it is capable of asserting.

19 March, 1915

Sprach heute mit Gürth über meine Zukunft. Ohne erfreuliches Resultat. Sehr sinnlich. ——.

Talked to Gürth today about my future. Without a satisfactory result. Very sensual. ——.

21 March, 1915

Denke daran zu den Kaiserjägern zu gehen da auch Ficker dort ist. Nicht ganz wohl. Nicht gearbeitet. Anhaltend unwohl. ————.

Think of joining the Emperor’s Hunters as Ficker is there too. Not quite well. Didn’t work. Persistently unwell. ————.

22 March, 1915

Unwohl. Gegen Abend besser.

Unwell. Better towards evening.

23 March, 1915

Sehr sinnlich.

Very sensual.

——. Didn’t work! Will I ever work again??!!! ——.

27 March, 1915

Das Bild kann eine Beschreibung ersetzen.

A picture can replace a description.

A picture can replace a description.

27 March, 1915

A picture can replace a description.

A picture can replace a description.

29 March, 1915

Überdrüssig! Von Gemeinheit umgeben. Wie bin ich müde! ————. ————

Weary! Surrounded by viciousness. How tired I am! ————. ————

 TLP 6·32

The law of causality is not a law but the form of a law.

[Sentence crossed out]

29 March, 1915

Das Kausalitätsgesetz ist kein Gesetz sondern die Form eines Gesetzes.

The law of causality is not a law but the form of a law. [See 6.32.]

The law of causality is not a law but the form of a law. [See 6.32.]

[Sentence crossed out]

TLP 6·321**

“Law of causality” is a generic name. And just as in mechanics there are, for instance, minimum-laws, such as that of least action, so in physics there are laws of causality, laws of the form of causality.

“Law of causality” is a generic name. And just as in mechanics there are, for instance, minimum-laws, such as that of least action, so too in physics there is a law of causality, a law of the causal form.

29 March, 1915

„Kausalitätsgesetz” das ist ein Gattungsname. Und wie es in der Mechanik – sagen wir – Minimumgesetze gibt – etwa der kleinsten Wirkung – so gibt es in der Physik ein Kausalitätsgesetz, ein Gesetz von der Kausalitätsform.

“Law of causality” is a generic name. And just as in mechanics there are, for instance, minimum-laws, such as that of least action, so too in physics there is a law of causality, a law of the form of causality. [Cf. 6.321.]

“Law of causality” is a generic name. And just as in mechanics there are, for instance, minimum-laws, such as that of least action, so too in physics there is a law of causality, a law of the form of causality. [Cf. 6.321.]

“Law of causality” is a generic name. And just as in mechanics there are, for instance, minimum-laws, such as that of least action, so too in physics there is a law of causality, a law of the causal form.

TLP 6·3211*

Indeed people used to have a notion that there must be a “law of least action” before they knew exactly how it was to be spelled out. (Here, as always, what is certain a priori turns out to be something purely logical.)

Indeed people had an idea that there must be a “law of least action” before they knew exactly what it was. (Here, as always, what is a priori turns out to be something purely logical.)

29 March, 1915

Wie die Menschen ja auch eine Ahnung davon gehabt haben daß es ein „Gesetz / der kleinsten Wirkung” geben müsse ehe sie genau wußten wie es lautete.

(Hier wie so oft stellt sich das Aprioristische als etwas rein Logisches heraus.)

Just as people also had a notion that there must be a “law of least action” before they knew exactly how it was to be spelled out.

(Here, as so often, what is a priori turns out to be something purely logical.) [Cf. 6.3211.]

Just as people also had a notion that there must be a “law of least action” before they knew exactly how it was to be spelled out.

(Here, as so often, what is a priori turns out to be something purely logical.) [Cf. 6.3211.]

Indeed people had an idea that there must be a “law of least action” before they knew exactly what it was. (Here, as always, what is a priori turns out to be something purely logical.)

3 April, 1915

Der Satz ist ein Maß der Welt.

A proposition is a measure of the world.

A proposition is a measure of the world.

3 April, 1915

Dies ist das Bild eines Vorgangs und stimmt nicht. Wie kann es dann noch immer das Bild jenes Vorgangs sein?

This is the picture of a process and is wrong. How, then, can it still be a picture of that process?

This is the picture of a process and is wrong. How, then, can it still be a picture of that process?

3 April, 1915

Daß „a” a vertreten kann & „b” b vertreten kann wenn „a” in der Relation „R” zu „b” steht, darin eben besteht / jene gesuchte potentielle interne – Relation.

That "a" can represent a and "b" can represent b if "a" stands in relation "R" to "b": this is what that potential internal relation we are seeking consists in.

That "a" can represent a and "b" can represent b if "a" stands in relation "R" to "b": this is what that potential internal relation we are seeking consists in.

 TLP 3·141 (1)**

A sentence is not a mixture of words. – (Just as a musical theme is not a mixture of notes.)

A proposition is not a jumble of words. (Just as a tune is not a jumble of notes.)

Der Satz ist kein Wörtergemisch.

A sentence is not a mixture of words. [See 3.141.]

Ich kann von dem Wesen des Satzes nicht auf die einzelnen logischen Operationen kommen!!!

I cannot get from the nature of the proposition to the individual logical operations!!!

15 April, 1915

Es fällt mir nichts Neues mehr ein! (Gürth von hier abkommandiert.) / Ich kann auf nichts mehr Neues denken. Und darauf darf es wohl auch gar nicht ankommen.

Nothing new comes to mind! (Gürth posted away from here.) I can’t think of anything new. And that’s probably not what matters at all.

15 April, 1915

Ich kann eben nicht herausbringen inwiefern der Satz das Bild des Sachverhaltes ist!

Beinahe bin ich bereit / alle Bemühungen aufzugeben. ‒ ‒

I just can't bring out how a proposition is a picture of a state of things!

I am almost willing to give up all my efforts. ‒ ‒

16 April, 1915

Die Beschreibung ist auch sozusagen eine Operation deren Basis ihre Hilfsmittel und deren Resultat der beschriebene Gegenstand ist.

A description is also, as it were, an operation that takes its means of description as its basis and its described object as its result.

A description is also, as it were, an operation that takes its means of description as its basis and its described object as its result.

16 April, 1915

Das Zeichen „Nicht” ist die Klasse aller verneinender Zeichen.

The sign "not" is the class of all negating signs.

The sign "not" is the class of all negating signs.

17 April, 1915

Working.

17 April, 1915

Das subjektive Universum.

The subjective universe.

The subjective universe.

17 April, 1915

Statt die logischen Operationen im Satz an dessen Teilsätzen zu vollziehen, können wir diesen auch Marken zuordnen und mit ihnen / operieren. Dann ist einem Satzbild ein mit ihm in kompliziertester Weise zusammenhängendes Markensternbild zugeordnet.

(aRb, cSd, φe) ((p⌵q).r :⊃: q.r.≡.p⌵r)

p q r

Instead of performing a proposition’s logical operations on its component propositions, we can also correlate marks with them and operate on them. Then a single sentence picture is correlated with a constellation of marks connected with it in a most complicated way.

(aRb, cSd, φe) ((p⌵q).r :⊃: q.r.≡.p⌵r)

p q r

18 April, 1915

Got a bad cold today!

18 April, 1915

Für die Operation der Verneinung ist der Übergang von p auf ~p nicht charakteristisch. (Der beste Beweis: sie führt auch von ~p zu p.) -----------------

The transition from p to ~p is not what is characteristic of the operation of negation. (The best proof of this: negation also leads from ~p to p.) -----------------

The transition from p to ~p is not what is characteristic of the operation of negation. (The best proof of this: negation also leads from ~p to p.) -----------------

18 April, 1915

The transition from p to ~p is not what is characteristic of the operation of negation. (The best proof of this: negation also leads from ~p to p.) -----------------

TLP 4·121 (2)

Sentences cannot represent logical form: it is mirrored in them.

Whatever is mirrored in language cannot be represented by it.

What expresses itself in language, we cannot express by means of language.

Sentences show the logical form of reality.

Propositions do not represent logical form: they display it; they show it.

19 April, 1915

Was sich in der Sprache spiegelt, kann ich nicht mit ihr ausdrücken.

Whatever is mirrored in language I cannot use language to express. [Cf. 4.121 (2).]

Whatever is mirrored in language I cannot use language to express. [Cf. 4.121 (2).]

Propositions do not represent logical form: they display it; they show it.

TLP 4·121 (2)

Sentences cannot represent logical form: it is mirrored in them.

Whatever is mirrored in language cannot be represented by it.

What expresses itself in language, we cannot express by means of language.

Sentences show the logical form of reality.

Propositions do not represent logical form: they display it; they show it.

19 April, 1915

Was sich in der Sprache spiegelt, kann ich nicht mit ihr ausdrücken.

Whatever is mirrored in language I cannot use language to express. [Cf. 4.121 (2).]

Whatever is mirrored in language I cannot use language to express. [Cf. 4.121 (2).]

Propositions do not represent logical form: they display it; they show it.

22 April, 1915

Soll jetzt die Oberaufsicht über die ganze Werkstätte kriegen. Neuerliche Unannehmlichkeiten.

Will now be supervisor of the whole workshop. Further trouble.

TLP 6·33*

We do not believe a priori in a law of conservation, rather we know a priori the possibility of a logical form.

We do not believe a priori in a law of conservation, rather we know a priori the possibility of a logical form.

23 April, 1915

Wir glauben nicht a priori an ein Erhaltungsgesetz / sondern wir wissen a priori die Möglichkeit seiner logischen Form.

We do not believe a priori in a law of conservation, rather we know a priori the possibility of its logical form. [See 6.33.]

We do not believe a priori in a law of conservation, rather we know a priori the possibility of its logical form. [See 6.33.]

We do not believe a priori in a law of conservation, rather we know a priori the possibility of a logical form.

TLP 6·34*

All such sentences, including the principle of sufficient reason, the laws of continuity in nature and of least effort in nature, etc. etc. – all these are a priori insights about possible formulations of scientific sentences.

All such propositions, including the principle of sufficient reason, the laws of continuity in nature and of least effort in nature, etc. etc. - all these are a priori insights about possible forms of scientific propositions.

23 April, 1915

Alle jene a priori gewissen Sätze, wie der Satz vom Grunde von der Kontinuität in der Natur etc. etc., alle diese sind aprioristische Einsichten bezüglich der möglichen Formgebung der Sätze der Wissenschaft.

All such a priori certain propositions, including the principle of sufficient reason, the laws of continuity in nature etc. etc. - all these are a priori insights about possible formulations of scientific propositions. [Cf. 6.34.]

All such a priori certain propositions, including the principle of sufficient reason, the laws of continuity in nature etc. etc. - all these are a priori insights about possible formulations of scientific propositions. [Cf. 6.34.]

All such propositions, including the principle of sufficient reason, the laws of continuity in nature and of least effort in nature, etc. etc. - all these are a priori insights about possible forms of scientific propositions.

TLP 5·47321 (1)

Of course, Occam's razor is no arbitrary rule, nor one that is justified by its practical success: its point is that unnecessary sign-units mean nothing.

Signs that serve one purpose are logically equivalent, and signs that serve none are logically meaningless.

Naturally, Occam's razor is no arbitrary rule, nor one that is justified by its practical success: its point is that unnecessary units in a sign language mean nothing.

23 April, 1915

„Ockhams Devise” ist natürlich keine willkürliche oder durch ihren praktischen Erfolg gerechtfertigte Regel. Sie besagt daß unnötige Zeichen-Einheiten nichts be / deuten.

Of course, Occam's razor is no arbitrary rule, nor one that is justified by its practical success. Its point is that unnecessary sign-units mean nothing. [See 5.47321 (1).]

Of course, Occam's razor is no arbitrary rule, nor one that is justified by its practical success. Its point is that unnecessary sign-units mean nothing. [See 5.47321 (1).]

Naturally, Occam's razor is no arbitrary rule, nor one that is justified by its practical success: its point is that unnecessary units in a sign language mean nothing.

TLP 5·47321 (2)

Of course, Occam's razor is no arbitrary rule, nor one that is justified by its practical success: its point is that unnecessary sign-units mean nothing.

Signs that serve one purpose are logically equivalent, and signs that serve none are logically meaningless.

Naturally, Occam's razor is no arbitrary rule, nor one that is justified by its practical success: its point is that unnecessary units in a sign language mean nothing.

23 April, 1915

Es ist klar daß Zeichen, die denselben Zweck erfüllen logisch identisch sind. Das rein Logische ist eben das was alle diese leisten können.

It is clear that signs that serve the same purpose are logically identical. What all of these are able to accomplish just is strictly logical. [Cf. 5.47321 (2).]

It is clear that signs that serve the same purpose are logically identical. What all of these are able to accomplish just is strictly logical. [Cf. 5.47321 (2).]

Naturally, Occam's razor is no arbitrary rule, nor one that is justified by its practical success: its point is that unnecessary units in a sign language mean nothing.

TLP 6·33*

We do not believe a priori in a law of conservation, rather we know a priori the possibility of a logical form.

We do not believe a priori in a law of conservation, rather we know a priori the possibility of a logical form.

23 April, 1915

Wir glauben nicht a priori an ein Erhaltungsgesetz / sondern wir wissen a priori die Möglichkeit seiner logischen Form.

We do not believe a priori in a law of conservation, rather we know a priori the possibility of its logical form. [See 6.33.]

We do not believe a priori in a law of conservation, rather we know a priori the possibility of its logical form. [See 6.33.]

We do not believe a priori in a law of conservation, rather we know a priori the possibility of a logical form.

TLP 6·34*

All such sentences, including the principle of sufficient reason, the laws of continuity in nature and of least effort in nature, etc. etc. – all these are a priori insights about possible formulations of scientific sentences.

All such propositions, including the principle of sufficient reason, the laws of continuity in nature and of least effort in nature, etc. etc. - all these are a priori insights about possible forms of scientific propositions.

23 April, 1915

Alle jene a priori gewissen Sätze, wie der Satz vom Grunde von der Kontinuität in der Natur etc. etc., alle diese sind aprioristische Einsichten bezüglich der möglichen Formgebung der Sätze der Wissenschaft.

All such a priori certain propositions, including the principle of sufficient reason, the laws of continuity in nature etc. etc. - all these are a priori insights about possible formulations of scientific propositions. [Cf. 6.34.]

All such a priori certain propositions, including the principle of sufficient reason, the laws of continuity in nature etc. etc. - all these are a priori insights about possible formulations of scientific propositions. [Cf. 6.34.]

All such propositions, including the principle of sufficient reason, the laws of continuity in nature and of least effort in nature, etc. etc. - all these are a priori insights about possible forms of scientific propositions.

TLP 5·47321 (1)

Of course, Occam's razor is no arbitrary rule, nor one that is justified by its practical success: its point is that unnecessary sign-units mean nothing.

Signs that serve one purpose are logically equivalent, and signs that serve none are logically meaningless.

Naturally, Occam's razor is no arbitrary rule, nor one that is justified by its practical success: its point is that unnecessary units in a sign language mean nothing.

23 April, 1915

„Ockhams Devise” ist natürlich keine willkürliche oder durch ihren praktischen Erfolg gerechtfertigte Regel. Sie besagt daß unnötige Zeichen-Einheiten nichts be / deuten.

Of course, Occam's razor is no arbitrary rule, nor one that is justified by its practical success. Its point is that unnecessary sign-units mean nothing. [See 5.47321 (1).]

Naturally, Occam's razor is no arbitrary rule, nor one that is justified by its practical success: its point is that unnecessary units in a sign language mean nothing.

TLP 5·47321 (2)

Of course, Occam's razor is no arbitrary rule, nor one that is justified by its practical success: its point is that unnecessary sign-units mean nothing.

Signs that serve one purpose are logically equivalent, and signs that serve none are logically meaningless.

Naturally, Occam's razor is no arbitrary rule, nor one that is justified by its practical success: its point is that unnecessary units in a sign language mean nothing.

23 April, 1915

Es ist klar daß Zeichen, die denselben Zweck erfüllen logisch identisch sind. Das rein Logische ist eben das was alle diese leisten können.

It is clear that signs that serve the same purpose are logically identical. What all of these are able to accomplish just is strictly logical. [Cf. 5.47321 (2).]

It is clear that signs that serve the same purpose are logically identical. What all of these are able to accomplish just is strictly logical. [Cf. 5.47321 (2).]

Naturally, Occam's razor is no arbitrary rule, nor one that is justified by its practical success: its point is that unnecessary units in a sign language mean nothing.

24 April, 1915

Ich arbeite. ——.

I work. ——.

 TLP 6·1261

In logic, process and result are equivalent. (Hence, no surprise.)

In logic process and result are equivalent. (Hence, no surprises.)

24 April, 1915

In der Logik (Mathematik) sind Prozeß & Resultat gleichwertig. (Darum keine Überraschungen.)

In logic (mathematics) process and result are equivalent. (Hence, no surprises.) [See 6.1261.]

In logic (mathematics) process and result are equivalent. (Hence, no surprises.) [See 6.1261.]

In logic process and result are equivalent. (Hence, no surprises.)

TLP 6·1261

In logic, process and result are equivalent. (Hence, no surprise.)

In logic process and result are equivalent. (Hence, no surprises.)

24 April, 1915

In der Logik (Mathematik) sind Prozeß & Resultat gleichwertig. (Darum keine Überraschungen.)

In logic (mathematics) process and result are equivalent. (Hence, no surprises.) [See 6.1261.]

In logic (mathematics) process and result are equivalent. (Hence, no surprises.) [See 6.1261.]

In logic process and result are equivalent. (Hence, no surprises.)

25 April, 1915

Da die Sprache in internen Relationen zur Welt steht, so bestimmt sie und diese Relationen die logische Möglichkeit der Tatsachen. Haben wir ein bedeutungsvolles Zeichen so muß es in einer bestimmten / internen Relation zu einem Gebilde stehen. Zeichen & Relation bestimmen eindeutig die logische Form des Bezeichneten.

Since language stands in internal relations to the world, it and these relations decide the logical possibility of facts. If we have a meaningful sign, it must stand in a particular internal relation to a structure. Sign and relation unambiguously decide the logical form of that which it signifies.

Since language stands in internal relations to the world, it and these relations decide the logical possibility of facts. If we have a meaningful sign, it must stand in a particular internal relation to a structure. Sign and relation unambiguously decide the logical form of that which it signifies.

25 April, 1915

Aber kann nicht irgendein sogenanntes Ding mit irgend einem solchen auf ein und dieselbe Weise zugeordnet werden?

Es ist z.B. ganz klar daß wir die Wörter der Sprache als miteinander logisch äquivalente Einheiten – empfinden und – gebrauchen.

But can't any so-called thing be correlated in one and the same way with any other such thing?

For example, it is quite clear that we use—and experience—the words of language as logically equivalent units.

But can't any so-called thing be correlated in one and the same way with any other such thing?

For example, it is quite clear that we use—and experience—the words of language as logically equivalent units.

25 April, 1915

Da die Sprache in internen Relationen zur Welt steht, so bestimmt sie und diese Relationen die logische Möglichkeit der Tatsachen. Haben wir ein bedeutungsvolles Zeichen so muß es in einer bestimmten / internen Relation zu einem Gebilde stehen. Zeichen & Relation bestimmen eindeutig die logische Form des Bezeichneten.

Since language stands in internal relations to the world, it and these relations decide the logical possibility of facts. If we have a meaningful sign, it must stand in a particular internal relation to a structure. Sign and relation unambiguously decide the logical form of that which it signifies.

Since language stands in internal relations to the world, it and these relations decide the logical possibility of facts. If we have a meaningful sign, it must stand in a particular internal relation to a structure. Sign and relation unambiguously decide the logical form of that which it signifies.

25 April, 1915

Aber kann nicht irgendein sogenanntes Ding mit irgend einem solchen auf ein und dieselbe Weise zugeordnet werden?

But can't any so-called thing be correlated in one and the same way with any other such thing?

For example, it is quite clear that we use—and experience—the words of language as logically equivalent units.

26 April, 1915

Arbeite. Sonst meine Tätigkeit sehr unzufriedenstellend.

Work. Apart from that, my employment is very unsatisfying.

26 April, 1915

Es scheint immer als ob es etwas gäbe was man als Ding betrachten könne, andererseits wirkliche einfache Dinge.

It always seems as if there were on the one hand, something that one could regard as a thing, and on the other hand, real simple things.

It always seems as if there were on the one hand, something that one could regard as a thing, and on the other hand, real simple things.

26 April, 1915

Es ist klar: Weder ein Bleistiftstrich noch ein Dampfschiff sind einfach. Besteht zwischen diesen beiden wirklich eine logische Äquivalenz?

It is clear that neither a pencil stroke nor a steamship is simple. Is there really a logical equivalence between these two?

It is clear that neither a pencil stroke nor a steamship is simple. Is there really a logical equivalence between these two?

TLP 6·35 (2)

Although the spots in our picture are geometrical figures, geometry can obviously say nothing about their actual form and position. The net, though, is purely geometrical and all its properties can be specified a priori.

Laws like the principle of sufficient reason, etc. are about the net and not about what the net describes.

Although the spots in our picture are geometrical figures, geometry can obviously say nothing about their actual form and position. But the network is purely geometrical; all its properties can be given a priori.

26 April, 1915

„Gesetze” wie der Satz vom Grunde etc. handeln vom Netz, nicht von dem was das Netz beschreibt.

“Laws” like the principle of sufficient reason, etc. are about the net and not about what the net describes. [See 6.35 (2).]

“Laws” like the principle of sufficient reason, etc. are about the net and not about what the net describes. [See 6.35 (2).]

Although the spots in our picture are geometrical figures, geometry can obviously say nothing about their actual form and position. But the network is purely geometrical; all its properties can be given a priori.

26 April, 1915

Durch die Allgemeinheit müssen die gebräuchlichen Sätze ihr einfaches Gepräge kriegen.

Ordinary propositions must get their imprint of simplicity by means of generality.

Ordinary propositions must get their imprint of simplicity by means of generality.

26 April, 1915

Wir müssen erkennen, wie die Sprache für sich selbst sorgt.

We must recognize how language takes care of itself.

We must recognize how language takes care of itself.

TLP 3·24 (1)

A sentence about a complex stands in an internal relation to a sentence about one of the constituents of the complex.

A complex can be given only by its description, and this will be right or wrong. A sentence that mentions a complex that does not exist will not be nonsensical, but just false.

When an element of a sentence signifies a complex, this can be gleaned from an indeterminateness in the sentences in which it occurs. We know that everything is not yet determined by the sentence. (After all, the notation for generality contains a prototype.)

The condensation of a symbol for a complex into a simple symbol can be expressed by a definition.

A proposition about a complex stands in an internal relation to a proposition about a constituent part.

26 April, 1915

Der Satz welcher vom „Komplex” handelt steht in interner Beziehung zum Satze welcher / von dessen Bestandteil handelt.

A proposition about a "complex" stands in a internal relation to a proposition about its constituents. [See 3.24 (1).]

A proposition about a "complex" stands in a internal relation to a proposition about its constituents. [See 3.24 (1).]

A proposition about a complex stands in an internal relation to a proposition about a constituent part.

26 April, 1915

Es scheint immer als ob es etwas gäbe was man als Ding betrachten könne, andererseits wirkliche einfache Dinge.

It always seems as if there were on the one hand, something that one could regard as a thing, and on the other hand, real simple things.

It always seems as if there were on the one hand, something that one could regard as a thing, and on the other hand, real simple things.

26 April, 1915

It is clear that neither a pencil stroke nor a steamship is simple. Is there really a logical equivalence between these two?

It is clear that neither a pencil stroke nor a steamship is simple. Is there really a logical equivalence between these two?

27 April, 1915

Arbeite! In der Fabrik muß ich jetzt meine Zeit verplempern!!! ——

Work! Now I have to waste my time at the factory!!! ——

 TLP 5·1362 (1)

Freedom of the will consists in the impossibility of our knowing future actions now. We could know them only if causality were an intrinsic necessity like that of logical inference. – The connection between knowing and the known is that of logical necessity.

(“A knows that p” is senseless if p is a tautology.)

Freedom of the will consists in the impossibility of our knowing future events now. We could know them only if causality were an inner necessity like that of logical inference. - The connection between knowledge and the known is that of logical necessity.

27 April, 1915

Die Willensfreiheit besteht darin daß zukünftige Ereignisse jetzt nicht gewußt werden können. Nur dann könnten wir sie wissen, wenn die Kausalität eine innere Notwendigkeit wäre – wie etwa die des logischen Schlusses. – Der Zusammenhang von Wissen & Gewußtem ist der der logischen Notwendigkeit.

Freedom of the will consists in the impossibility of our knowing future events now. We could know them only if causality were an inner necessity like, say, that of logical inference. - The connection between knowing and the known is that of logical necessity.

Freedom of the will consists in the impossibility of our knowing future events now. We could know them only if causality were an inner necessity like, say, that of logical inference. - The connection between knowing and the known is that of logical necessity.

Freedom of the will consists in the impossibility of our knowing future events now. We could know them only if causality were an inner necessity like that of logical inference. - The connection between knowledge and the known is that of logical necessity.

27 April, 1915

Ich darf mich nicht um die Sprache kümmern brauchen.

I cannot need to worry about language.

I cannot need to worry about language.

27 April, 1915

Das Nicht-Stimmen ist ähnlich wie die Nicht-Identität. /

Non-truth is like non-identity.

Non-truth is like non-identity.

Freedom of the will consists in the impossibility of our knowing future actions now. We could know them only if causality were an intrinsic necessity like that of logical inference. – The connection between knowing and the known is that of logical necessity.
