Even if the world is infinitely complex, so that every fact consists of infinitely many states of affairs and every state of affairs is composed of infinitely many objects, there would still have to be objects and states of affairs.

Even if the world were infinitely complex, so that every fact consisted of infinitely many elementary facts and every elementary fact were composed of infinitely many objects, there would still have to be objects and elementary facts.

23 May, 1915

Trotzdem scheint nun der unendlich komplexe Sachverhalt ein Unding zu sein!

Nevertheless, an infinitely complex state of things now looks preposterous.

Nevertheless, an infinitely complex state of things now looks preposterous.

Even if the world were infinitely complex, so that every fact consisted of infinitely many elementary facts and every elementary fact were composed of infinitely many objects, there would still have to be objects and elementary facts.

23 May, 1915

Aber auch das scheint sicher, daß wir die Existenz einfacher Gegenstände nicht aus der Existenz bestimmter einfacher Gegenstände schließen, sondern sie vielmehr als Endresultat einer Analyse– sozusagen durch die Beschreibung– durch einen zu ihnen führenden Prozeß, kennen.

But it also seems certain that we do not infer the existence of simple objects from the existence of particular simple objects, but rather know them through a process leading to them, as the end result of an analysis—by description, as it were.

But it also seems certain that we do not infer the existence of simple objects from the existence of particular simple objects, but rather know them through a process leading to them, as the end result of an analysis—by description, as it were.

23 May, 1915

Deswegen, weil eine Redewendung unsinnig / ist, kann man sie noch immer gebrauchen – siehe die letzte Bemerkung.

That is why one can still go on using a nonsensical idiom — see the last remark.

That is why one can still go on using a nonsensical idiom — see the last remark.

TLP 5·631 (2)*

The subject that thinks, entertains ideas: there is no such thing.

If I were to write a book called The World as I Encountered It, then this would also have to report on my body, and say which parts are subject to my will and which are not, etc. For this is a method of isolating the subject, or rather of showing that in an important sense there is no subject; for it alone could not be mentioned in that book.—

The subject that thinks, entertains ideas: there is no such thing.

23 May, 1915

In dem Buch „Die Welt welche ich vorfand” wäre auch über meinen Leib zu berichten und zu sagen welche Glieder meinem Willen unterstehen etc. Dies ist nämlich eine Methode das Subjekt zu isolieren oder vielmehr zu zeigen daß es in einem wichtigen Sinne kein Subjekt gibt: Von ihm allein nämlich könnte in diesem Buche nicht die Rede sein. –

The book called The World I Found would also have to report on my body and say which parts are subject to my will, etc. For this is a method of isolating the subject, or rather of showing that in an important sense there is no subject; for it alone could not be mentioned in that book. –

The book called The World I Found would also have to report on my body and say which parts are subject to my will, etc. For this is a method of isolating the subject, or rather of showing that in an important sense there is no subject; for it alone could not be mentioned in that book. –

The subject that thinks, entertains ideas: there is no such thing.

24 May, 1915

Lernte heute den alten / Logiker Dziewicki kennen von dem mir Russell in seinem Brief schrieb. Ein netter alter Mann.

Today I met Dziewicki, the old logician of whom Russell wrote me in his letter. A nice old man.

24 May, 1915

Wenn wir auch die einfachen Gegenstände nicht aus der Anschauung kennen; die komplexen Gegenstände kennen wir aus der Anschauung, wir wissen aus / der Anschauung daß sie komplex sind. – Und daß sie zuletzt aus einfachen Dingen bestehen müssen?

Wir nehmen zum Beispiel aus unserem Gesichtsfeld einen Teil heraus, wir sehen daß er noch immer komplex ist, daß ein Teil von ihm noch immer komplex aber schon einfacher ist, u.s.w.–

Even though we have no acquaintance with simple objects we do know complex objects by acquaintance, we know by acquaintance that they are complex. —And that in the end they must consist of simple things?

For example, we single out a part of our field of vision, we see that it is still complex, that a part of it is still complex but already simpler, and so on....

Even though we have no acquaintance with simple objects we do know complex objects by acquaintance, we know by acquaintance that they are complex. —And that in the end they must consist of simple things?

For example, we single out a part of our field of vision, we see that it is still complex, that a part of it is still complex but already simpler, and so on....

24 May, 1915

Ist es denkbar daß wir – z.B. – sehen, daß alle Punkte einer Fläche gelb sind, ohne irgend einen Punkt dieser Fläche zu sehen. Fast scheint es so.

Is it conceivable that we - e.g. - see that all points of a surface are yellow, without seeing any single point of this surface. It almost seems so.

Is it conceivable that we - e.g. - see that all points of a surface are yellow, without seeing any single point of this surface. It almost seems so.

24 May, 1915

Der Entstehung der Probleme: die drückende Spannung die sich einmal in eine Frage zusammenballt, und sich objektiviert.

How problems emerge: a pressing tension concentrates itself into a question and objectifies itself.

How problems emerge: a pressing tension concentrates itself into a question and objectifies itself.

24 May, 1915

Wie würden wir, z.B., eine gleichmäßig mit Blau bedeckte Fläche beschreiben?

How would we describe, for example, a surface uniformly covered with blue?

How would we describe, for example, a surface uniformly covered with blue?

24 May, 1915

Wenn wir auch die einfachen Gegenstände nicht aus der Anschauung kennen; die komplexen Gegenstände kennen wir aus der Anschauung, wir wissen aus / der Anschauung daß sie komplex sind. – Und daß sie zuletzt aus einfachen Dingen bestehen müssen?

Wir nehmen zum Beispiel aus unserem Gesichtsfeld einen Teil heraus, wir sehen daß er noch immer komplex ist, daß ein Teil von ihm noch immer komplex aber schon einfacher ist, u.s.w.–

Even though we have no acquaintance with simple objects we do know complex objects by acquaintance, we know by acquaintance that they are complex. —And that in the end they must consist of simple things?

For example, we single out a part of our field of vision, we see that it is still complex, that a part of it is still complex but already simpler, and so on....

Even though we have no acquaintance with simple objects we do know complex objects by acquaintance, we know by acquaintance that they are complex. —And that in the end they must consist of simple things?

For example, we single out a part of our field of vision, we see that it is still complex, that a part of it is still complex but already simpler, and so on....

24 May, 1915

Ist es denkbar daß wir – z.B. – sehen, daß alle Punkte einer Fläche gelb sind, ohne irgend einen Punkt dieser Fläche zu sehen. Fast scheint es so.

Is it conceivable that we - e.g. - see that all points of a surface are yellow, without seeing any single point of this surface. It almost seems so.

Is it conceivable that we - e.g. - see that all points of a surface are yellow, without seeing any single point of this surface. It almost seems so.

24 May, 1915

Der Entstehung der Probleme: die drückende Spannung die sich einmal in eine Frage zusammenballt, und sich objektiviert.

How problems emerge: a pressing tension concentrates itself into a question and objectifies itself.

How problems emerge: a pressing tension concentrates itself into a question and objectifies itself.

24 May, 1915

Wie würden wir, z.B., eine gleichmäßig mit Blau bedeckte Fläche beschreiben?

How would we describe, for example, a surface uniformly covered with blue?

How would we describe, for example, a surface uniformly covered with blue?

25 May, 1915

Erscheint uns das Gesichtsbild eines minimum visibile wirklich als unteilbar? Was Ausdehnung hat ist teilbar. Gibt es Teile in unserem Gesichtsbild die keine Ausdehnung haben? Etwa die der Fixsterne? –

Does the visual image of a minimum visibile really strike us as indivisible? What has extension is divisible. Are there parts of our visual field that have no extension? For instance, images of the fixed stars?

Does the visual image of a minimum visibile really strike us as indivisible? What has extension is divisible. Are there parts of our visual field that have no extension? For instance, images of the fixed stars?

TLP 6·52

We feel that even if all possible scientific questions were answered, the problems of life would still not have been touched at all. To be sure, there would then be no question left, and just this is the answer.

We feel that even if all possible scientific questions were answered, the problems of life would still not have been touched at all. To be sure, there would then be no question left, and just this is the answer.

25 May, 1915

Der Trieb zum Mystischen kommt von der Unbefriedigtheit unserer Wünsche durch die Wissenschaft. Wir fühlen daß selbst, wenn alle möglichen wissenschaftlichen Fragen beantwortet sind unser Problem noch gar nicht / berührt ist. Freilich bleibt dann eben keine Frage mehr; und eben dies ist die Antwort.

The drive towards what is mystical arises out of the frustration of our desires by science. We feel that even if all possible scientific questions were answered, our problem would still not have been touched at all. To be sure, there would then be no question left, and just this is the answer. [Cf. 6.52.]

The drive towards what is mystical arises out of the frustration of our desires by science. We feel that even if all possible scientific questions were answered, our problem would still not have been touched at all. To be sure, there would then be no question left, and just this is the answer. [Cf. 6.52.]

We feel that even if all possible scientific questions were answered, the problems of life would still not have been touched at all. To be sure, there would then be no question left, and just this is the answer.

TLP 4·465**

The logical product of a tautology and a sentence says the same thing as the sentence. This product, therefore, is identical with the sentence. For what is essential to a symbol cannot be altered without altering its sense.

The logical product of a tautology and a proposition says the same thing as the proposition. This product, therefore, is identical with the proposition. For the essence of a sign cannot be altered without altering its sense.

25 May, 1915

Die Tautologie wird von jedem Satze bejaht; die Kontradiktion von jedem verneint. (Man könnte ja an jeden Satz, ohne seinen Sinn zu ändern irgend eine Tautologie mit „und” anhängen und ebenso die Verneinung einer Kontradiktion.)

Und „ohne seinen Sinn zu ändern” heißt: ohne das Wesentliche am Zeichen selbst zu ändern. Denn; man kann das Zeichen nicht ändern ohne seinen Sinn zu ändern. [Cf. 4.465.]

A tautology is affirmed, a contradiction denied, by every proposition. (One could add “and” and any tautology to any proposition, without altering its sense, and in like manner the negation of a contradiction).

And "without altering its sense" means: without altering what is essential about the sign itself. For a sign cannot be altered without altering its sense. [Cf. 4.465.]

A tautology is affirmed, a contradiction denied, by every proposition. (One could add “and” and any tautology to any proposition, without altering its sense, and in like manner the negation of a contradiction).

And "without altering its sense" means: without altering what is essential about the sign itself. For a sign cannot be altered without altering its sense. [Cf. 4.465.]

The logical product of a tautology and a proposition says the same thing as the proposition. This product, therefore, is identical with the proposition. For the essence of a sign cannot be altered without altering its sense.

25 May, 1915

„aRa” muß Sinn haben wenn „aRb” Sinn hat.

"aRa" must make sense if "aRb" makes sense.

"aRa" must make sense if "aRb" makes sense.

25 May, 1915

Erscheint uns das Gesichtsbild eines minimum visibile wirklich als unteilbar? Was Ausdehnung hat ist teilbar. Gibt es Teile in unserem Gesichtsbild die keine Ausdehnung haben? Etwa die der Fixsterne? –

Does the visual image of a minimum visibile really strike us as indivisible? What has extension is divisible. Are there parts of our visual field that have no extension? For instance, images of the fixed stars?

Does the visual image of a minimum visibile really strike us as indivisible? What has extension is divisible. Are there parts of our visual field that have no extension? For instance, images of the fixed stars?

TLP 6·52

We feel that even if all possible scientific questions were answered, the problems of life would still not have been touched at all. To be sure, there would then be no question left, and just this is the answer.

We feel that even if all possible scientific questions were answered, the problems of life would still not have been touched at all. To be sure, there would then be no question left, and just this is the answer.

25 May, 1915

Der Trieb zum Mystischen kommt von der Unbefriedigtheit unserer Wünsche durch die Wissenschaft. Wir fühlen daß selbst, wenn alle möglichen wissenschaftlichen Fragen beantwortet sind unser Problem noch gar nicht / berührt ist. Freilich bleibt dann eben keine Frage mehr; und eben dies ist die Antwort.

The drive towards what is mystical arises out of the frustration of our desires by science. We feel that even if all possible scientific questions were answered, our problem would still not have been touched at all. To be sure, there would then be no question left, and just this is the answer. [Cf. 6.52.]

The drive towards what is mystical arises out of the frustration of our desires by science. We feel that even if all possible scientific questions were answered, our problem would still not have been touched at all. To be sure, there would then be no question left, and just this is the answer. [Cf. 6.52.]

We feel that even if all possible scientific questions were answered, the problems of life would still not have been touched at all. To be sure, there would then be no question left, and just this is the answer.

TLP 4·465**

The logical product of a tautology and a sentence says the same thing as the sentence. This product, therefore, is identical with the sentence. For what is essential to a symbol cannot be altered without altering its sense.

The logical product of a tautology and a proposition says the same thing as the proposition. This product, therefore, is identical with the proposition. For the essence of a sign cannot be altered without altering its sense.

25 May, 1915

Die Tautologie wird von jedem Satze bejaht; die Kontradiktion von jedem verneint. (Man könnte ja an jeden Satz, ohne seinen Sinn zu ändern irgend eine Tautologie mit „und” anhängen und ebenso die Verneinung einer Kontradiktion.)

Und „ohne seinen Sinn zu ändern” heißt: ohne das Wesentliche am Zeichen selbst zu ändern. Denn; man kann das Zeichen nicht ändern ohne seinen Sinn zu ändern. [Cf. 4.465.]

A tautology is affirmed, a contradiction denied, by every proposition. (One could add “and” and any tautology to any proposition, without altering its sense, and in like manner the negation of a contradiction).

And "without altering its sense" means: without altering what is essential about the sign itself. For a sign cannot be altered without altering its sense. [Cf. 4.465.]

A tautology is affirmed, a contradiction denied, by every proposition. (One could add “and” and any tautology to any proposition, without altering its sense, and in like manner the negation of a contradiction).

And "without altering its sense" means: without altering what is essential about the sign itself. For a sign cannot be altered without altering its sense. [Cf. 4.465.]

The logical product of a tautology and a proposition says the same thing as the proposition. This product, therefore, is identical with the proposition. For the essence of a sign cannot be altered without altering its sense.

25 May, 1915

„aRa” muß Sinn haben wenn „aRb” Sinn hat.

"aRa" must make sense if "aRb" makes sense.

"aRa" must make sense if "aRb" makes sense.

26 May, 1915

Wie aber soll ich jetzt das allgemeine Wesen des Satzes erklären? Wir können wohl sagen: alles, was der Fall ist (oder nicht ist) kann durch einen Satz abgebildet werden. Aber hier haben wir den Ausdruck „der Fall sein”! Er ist ebenso problematisch.

But how am I to explain the general nature of the proposition now? We can surely say: everything that is (or is not) the case can be pictured by means of a proposition. But here we have the expression "to be the case"! It is just as problematic.

But how am I to explain the general nature of the proposition now? We can surely say: everything that is (or is not) the case can be pictured by means of a proposition. But here we have the expression "to be the case"! It is just as problematic.

26 May, 1915

Das Gegenstück zum Satze bilden die Gegenstände.

Objects make up a proposition’s complement.

Objects make up a proposition’s complement.

26 May, 1915

Die Gegenstände kann ich nur nennen. Zeichen vertreten sie.

I can only name objects. Signs stand in for them.

I can only name objects. Signs stand in for them.

26 May, 1915

Wie aber soll ich jetzt das allgemeine Wesen des Satzes erklären? Wir können wohl sagen: alles, was der Fall ist (oder nicht ist) kann durch einen Satz abgebildet werden. Aber hier haben wir den Ausdruck „der Fall sein”! Er ist ebenso problematisch.

But how am I to explain the general nature of the proposition now? We can surely say: everything that is (or is not) the case can be pictured by means of a proposition. But here we have the expression "to be the case"! It is just as problematic.

But how am I to explain the general nature of the proposition now? We can surely say: everything that is (or is not) the case can be pictured by means of a proposition. But here we have the expression "to be the case"! It is just as problematic.

26 May, 1915

Das Gegenstück zum Satze bilden die Gegenstände.

Objects make up a proposition’s complement.

Objects make up a proposition’s complement.

26 May, 1915

Die Gegenstände kann ich nur nennen. Zeichen vertreten sie.

I can only name objects. Signs stand in for them.

I can only name objects. Signs stand in for them.

27 May, 1915

Ich kann nur von ihnen sprechen, sie aussprechen kann ich nicht.

I can only speak of them, I cannot give voice to them. [See 3.221.]

I can only speak of them, I cannot give voice to them. [See 3.221.]

27 May, 1915

„Aber könnte es nicht etwas geben was durch einen Satz sich nicht ausdrücken läßt (und auch kein Gegenstand ist)?”. Das ließe sich eben dann durch die Sprache nicht ausdrücken; und wir können auch nicht darnach fragen.

"But couldn’t there be something that cannot be expressed by a proposition (and which is also not an object)?" Then that simply could not be expressed by language; and it is also impossible for us to ask about it.

"But couldn’t there be something that cannot be expressed by a proposition (and which is also not an object)?" Then that simply could not be expressed by language; and it is also impossible for us to ask about it.

27 May, 1915

Wie wenn es etwas außerhalb den Tatsachen gibt? Was unsere Sätze nicht auszudrücken vermögen? Aber da haben wir ja z.B. die Dinge, und wir fühlen gar kein Verlangen / sie in Sätzen auszudrücken. Was sich nicht ausdrücken läßt das drücken wir nicht aus——. Und wie wollen wir fragen ob sich das ausdrücken läßt, was sich nicht ausdrücken läßt?

What if there is something outside the facts? Which our propositions are incapable of expressing? But here we do have things, for instance, and we feel no demand at all to express them in propositions. What cannot be expressed we do not express——. And how do we want to ask whether that can be expressed which cannot be expressed?

What if there is something outside the facts? Which our propositions are incapable of expressing? But here we do have things, for instance, and we feel no demand at all to express them in propositions. What cannot be expressed we do not express——. And how do we want to ask whether that can be expressed which cannot be expressed?

27 May, 1915

Gibt es keinen Bereich außerhalb den Tatsachen?

Is there no realm outside the facts?

Is there no realm outside the facts?

27 May, 1915

Ich kann nur von ihnen sprechen, sie aussprechen kann ich nicht.

I can only speak of them, I cannot give voice to them. [See 3.221.]

I can only speak of them, I cannot give voice to them. [See 3.221.]

27 May, 1915

„Aber könnte es nicht etwas geben was durch einen Satz sich nicht ausdrücken läßt (und auch kein Gegenstand ist)?”. Das ließe sich eben dann durch die Sprache nicht ausdrücken; und wir können auch nicht darnach fragen.

"But couldn’t there be something that cannot be expressed by a proposition (and which is also not an object)?" Then that simply could not be expressed by language; and it is also impossible for us to ask about it.

"But couldn’t there be something that cannot be expressed by a proposition (and which is also not an object)?" Then that simply could not be expressed by language; and it is also impossible for us to ask about it.

27 May, 1915

Wie wenn es etwas außerhalb den Tatsachen gibt? Was unsere Sätze nicht auszudrücken vermögen? Aber da haben wir ja z.B. die Dinge, und wir fühlen gar kein Verlangen / sie in Sätzen auszudrücken. Was sich nicht ausdrücken läßt das drücken wir nicht aus——. Und wie wollen wir fragen ob sich das ausdrücken läßt, was sich nicht ausdrücken läßt?

What if there is something outside the facts? Which our propositions are incapable of expressing? But here we do have things, for instance, and we feel no demand at all to express them in propositions. What cannot be expressed we do not express——. And how do we want to ask whether that can be expressed which cannot be expressed?

What if there is something outside the facts? Which our propositions are incapable of expressing? But here we do have things, for instance, and we feel no demand at all to express them in propositions. What cannot be expressed we do not express——. And how do we want to ask whether that can be expressed which cannot be expressed?

27 May, 1915

Gibt es keinen Bereich außerhalb den Tatsachen?

Is there no realm outside the facts?

Is there no realm outside the facts?

28 May, 1915

„Zusammengesetztes Zeichen” und „Satz” sind gleichbedeutend.

"Composite sign" and "sentence" have the same meaning.

"Composite sign" and "sentence" have the same meaning.

28 May, 1915

Ist es eine Tautologie zu sagen: die Sprache besteht aus Sätzen?

Is it a tautology to say: Language consists of sentences?

Is it a tautology to say: Language consists of sentences?

28 May, 1915

„Zusammengesetztes Zeichen” und „Satz” sind gleichbedeutend.

"Composite sign" and "sentence" have the same meaning.

"Composite sign" and "sentence" have the same meaning.

28 May, 1915

Ist es eine Tautologie zu sagen: die Sprache besteht aus Sätzen?

Is it a tautology to say: Language consists of sentences?

Is it a tautology to say: Language consists of sentences?

TLP 5·62 (3)*

This remark provides the key to deciding the question how much truth there is in solipsism.

For what the solipsist is driving at is quite correct, only it cannot be said, but shows itself.

That the world is my world shows itself in the fact that the limits of language (the only language I understand) mean the limits of my world.

This remark provides the key to the problem how much truth there is in solipsism.

29 May, 1915

Aber ist die Sprache, die einzige / Sprache?

Warum soll es nicht eine Ausdrucksweise geben mit der ich über die Sprache reden kann, so daß diese mir in Koordination mit etwas Anderem erscheinen kann?

But is language the only language?

Why shouldn’t there be a form of expression in which I can speak about language in such a way that it can appear to me in coordination with something else?

But is language the only language?

Why shouldn’t there be a form of expression in which I can speak about language in such a way that it can appear to me in coordination with something else?

This remark provides the key to the problem how much truth there is in solipsism.

29 May, 1915

Nehmen wir an die Musik wäre eine solche Ausdrucksweise: Dann ist jedenfalls charakteristisch für die Wissenschaft, daß in ihr keine musikalischen Themen vorkommen.

Suppose that music were such a mode of expression: In that case, it is at any rate characteristic of science that no musical themes occur in it.

Suppose that music were such a mode of expression: In that case, it is at any rate characteristic of science that no musical themes occur in it.

29 May, 1915

Ich selbst schreibe hier nur Sätze hin. Und warum?

I myself only write sentences here. And why?

I myself only write sentences here. And why?

TLP 5·62 (3)*

This remark provides the key to deciding the question how much truth there is in solipsism.

For what the solipsist is driving at is quite correct, only it cannot be said, but shows itself.

That the world is my world shows itself in the fact that the limits of language (the only language I understand) mean the limits of my world.

This remark provides the key to the problem how much truth there is in solipsism.

29 May, 1915

Wie ist die Sprache unik?

How is language unique?

How is language unique?

This remark provides the key to the problem how much truth there is in solipsism.

TLP 5·62 (3)*

This remark provides the key to deciding the question how much truth there is in solipsism.

For what the solipsist is driving at is quite correct, only it cannot be said, but shows itself.

This remark provides the key to the problem how much truth there is in solipsism.

Aber ist die Sprache, die einzige / Sprache?

Warum soll es nicht eine Ausdrucksweise geben mit der ich über die Sprache reden kann, so daß diese mir in Koordination mit etwas Anderem erscheinen kann?

But is language the only language?

Why shouldn’t there be a form of expression in which I can speak about language in such a way that it can appear to me in coordination with something else?

I myself only write sentences here. And why?

I myself only write sentences here. And why?

TLP 5·62 (3)*

This remark provides the key to deciding the question how much truth there is in solipsism.

For what the solipsist is driving at is quite correct, only it cannot be said, but shows itself.

That the world is my world shows itself in the fact that the limits of language (the only language I understand) mean the limits of my world.

This remark provides the key to the problem how much truth there is in solipsism.

29 May, 1915

Wie ist die Sprache unik?

How is language unique?

How is language unique?

This remark provides the key to the problem how much truth there is in solipsism.

30 May, 1915

Die Worte sind wie die Haut / auf einem tiefen Wasser.

Es ist klar daß es auf dasselbe hinauskommt zu fragen, was ist ein Satz, wie zu fragen was ist eine Tatsache – oder ein Komplex.

Words are like the surface of deep water.

It is clear that it comes to the same thing to ask what a proposition is as to ask what a fact is - or a complex.

Words are like the surface of deep water.

It is clear that it comes to the same thing to ask what a proposition is as to ask what a fact is - or a complex.

30 May, 1915

Und warum soll man nicht sagen: „Es gibt Komplexe; man kann sie mit Namen benennen oder durch Sätze abbilden”?

And why not say: "There are complexes; one can label them with names or depict them in propositions"?

And why not say: "There are complexes; one can label them with names or depict them in propositions"?

30 May, 1915

Der Name eines Komplexes fungiert im Satz wie der Name eines Gegenstandes welchen ich nur durch eine Beschreibung kenne. – Als Beschreibung fungiert der ihn abbildende Satz.

The name of a complex functions in a proposition like the name of an object that I know only by description. ——The proposition depicting it functions as a description.

The name of a complex functions in a proposition like the name of an object that I know only by description. ——The proposition depicting it functions as a description.

30 May, 1915

Aber wenn es nun einfache Gegenstände gibt, ist es richtig ihre Zeichen und jene anderen „Namen” zu nennen?

But if there are simple objects, is it correct to call both the signs for them and those other signs "names"?

But if there are simple objects, is it correct to call both the signs for them and those other signs "names"?

TLP 3·327** 30.5.15 (7,13)**

Signs determine a logical form only in tandem with their logico-syntactical employment.

30 May, 1915

Oder ist Name sozusagen ein logischer Begriff?

„Er kennzeichnet die Gemeinsamkeit einer Form und eines Inhalts”. ——

Je nach der Verschiedenheit der Struktur des Komplexes bezeichnet sein Name in anderer Art & Weise und unterliegt anderen syntaktischen Gesetzen.

Or is “name” a logical concept, so to speak?

"It characterizes a form and a content in common." ——

In accordance with the difference in the structure of the complex, the name of the complex refers in a different way and is subject to different syntactic laws.

Or is “name” a logical concept, so to speak?

"It characterizes a form and a content in common." ——

In accordance with the difference in the structure of the complex, the name of the complex refers in a different way and is subject to different syntactic laws.

30 May, 1915

Der Fehler in dieser Auffassung muß darin liegen, daß sie einerseits komplexe / und einfache Gegenstände einander entgegenstellt andererseits aber sie als verwandt behandelt.

Und doch: Bestandteile und Komplex scheinen einander verwandt, und entgegengesetzt zu sein!

(Wie der Plan einer Stadt und die Karte eines Landes die vor uns in gleicher Größe, und verschiedenen Maßstäben liegen.)

The mistake in this conception must lie in its on the one hand contrasting complexes and simple objects, but on the other hand treating them as related.

And yet: constituents and complex seem to be related and to be opposed!

(Like the plan of a city and the map of a country that are in front of us, the same size, and at different scales).

The mistake in this conception must lie in its on the one hand contrasting complexes and simple objects, but on the other hand treating them as related.

And yet: constituents and complex seem to be related and to be opposed!

(Like the plan of a city and the map of a country that are in front of us, the same size, and at different scales).

30 May, 1915

Woher dies Gefühl!: „Allem was ich sehe, dieser Landschaft, dem Fliegen der Samen in der Luft, all diesem kann ich einen Namen zuordnen; ja, was, wenn nicht dieses, / sollten mir Namen benennen”?!

"I can assign a name to all that I see, to this landscape, to the dust in the wind, to all this; indeed, what should I call a name if not this." Where does this feeling come from?!

"I can assign a name to all that I see, to this landscape, to the dust in the wind, to all this; indeed, what should I call a name if not this." Where does this feeling come from?!

TLP 3·327** 30.5.15 (7,13)**

Signs determine a logical form only in tandem with their logico-syntactical employment.

30 May, 1915

Namen kennzeichnen die Gemeinsamkeit einer Form und eines Inhalts. – Sie kennzeichnen erst mit ihrer syntaktischen Verwendung zusammen eine bestimmte logische Form.

Names characterize what one form and one content have in common. — They characterize one particular logical form only in tandem with their syntactical employment. [Cf. 3·31 (4), 3.327.]

Names characterize what one form and one content have in common. — They characterize one particular logical form only in tandem with their syntactical employment. [Cf. 3·31 (4), 3.327.]

30 May, 1915

Die Worte sind wie die Haut / auf einem tiefen Wasser.

Es ist klar daß es auf dasselbe hinauskommt zu fragen, was ist ein Satz, wie zu fragen was ist eine Tatsache – oder ein Komplex.

Words are like the surface of deep water.

It is clear that it comes to the same thing to ask what a proposition is as to ask what a fact is - or a complex.

Words are like the surface of deep water.

It is clear that it comes to the same thing to ask what a proposition is as to ask what a fact is - or a complex.

30 May, 1915

Und warum soll man nicht sagen: „Es gibt Komplexe; man kann sie mit Namen benennen oder durch Sätze abbilden”?

And why not say: "There are complexes; one can label them with names or depict them in propositions"?

And why not say: "There are complexes; one can label them with names or depict them in propositions"?

30 May, 1915

Der Name eines Komplexes fungiert im Satz wie der Name eines Gegenstandes welchen ich nur durch eine Beschreibung kenne. – Als Beschreibung fungiert der ihn abbildende Satz.

The name of a complex functions in a proposition like the name of an object that I know only by description. ——The proposition depicting it functions as a description.

The name of a complex functions in a proposition like the name of an object that I know only by description. ——The proposition depicting it functions as a description.

30 May, 1915

Aber wenn es nun einfache Gegenstände gibt, ist es richtig ihre Zeichen und jene anderen „Namen” zu nennen?

But if there are simple objects, is it correct to call both the signs for them and those other signs "names"?

But if there are simple objects, is it correct to call both the signs for them and those other signs "names"?

TLP 3·327** 30.5.15 (7,13)**

Signs determine a logical form only in tandem with their logico-syntactical employment.

30 May, 1915

Oder ist Name sozusagen ein logischer Begriff?

„Er kennzeichnet die Gemeinsamkeit einer Form und eines Inhalts”. ——

Je nach der Verschiedenheit der Struktur des Komplexes bezeichnet sein Name in anderer Art & Weise und unterliegt anderen syntaktischen Gesetzen.

Or is “name” a logical concept, so to speak?

"It characterizes a form and a content in common." ——

In accordance with the difference in the structure of the complex, the name of the complex refers in a different way and is subject to different syntactic laws.

Or is “name” a logical concept, so to speak?

"It characterizes a form and a content in common." ——

In accordance with the difference in the structure of the complex, the name of the complex refers in a different way and is subject to different syntactic laws.

30 May, 1915

Der Fehler in dieser Auffassung muß darin liegen, daß sie einerseits komplexe / und einfache Gegenstände einander entgegenstellt andererseits aber sie als verwandt behandelt.

Und doch: Bestandteile und Komplex scheinen einander verwandt, und entgegengesetzt zu sein!

(Wie der Plan einer Stadt und die Karte eines Landes die vor uns in gleicher Größe, und verschiedenen Maßstäben liegen.)

The mistake in this conception must lie in its on the one hand contrasting complexes and simple objects, but on the other hand treating them as related.

And yet: constituents and complex seem to be related and to be opposed!

(Like the plan of a city and the map of a country that are in front of us, the same size, and at different scales).

The mistake in this conception must lie in its on the one hand contrasting complexes and simple objects, but on the other hand treating them as related.

And yet: constituents and complex seem to be related and to be opposed!

(Like the plan of a city and the map of a country that are in front of us, the same size, and at different scales).

30 May, 1915

Woher dies Gefühl!: „Allem was ich sehe, dieser Landschaft, dem Fliegen der Samen in der Luft, all diesem kann ich einen Namen zuordnen; ja, was, wenn nicht dieses, / sollten mir Namen benennen”?!

"I can assign a name to all that I see, to this landscape, to the dust in the wind, to all this; indeed, what should I call a name if not this." Where does this feeling come from?!

"I can assign a name to all that I see, to this landscape, to the dust in the wind, to all this; indeed, what should I call a name if not this." Where does this feeling come from?!

TLP 3·327** 30.5.15 (7,13)**

Signs determine a logical form only in tandem with their logico-syntactical employment.

30 May, 1915

Namen kennzeichnen die Gemeinsamkeit einer Form und eines Inhalts. – Sie kennzeichnen erst mit ihrer syntaktischen Verwendung zusammen eine bestimmte logische Form.

Names characterize what one form and one content have in common. — They characterize one particular logical form only in tandem with their syntactical employment. [Cf. 3·31 (4), 3.327.]

Names characterize what one form and one content have in common. — They characterize one particular logical form only in tandem with their syntactical employment. [Cf. 3·31 (4), 3.327.]

TLP 5·526 (1)

The world can be completely described using fully generalized sentences, that is to say: without first assigning any name to a particular object.

Then to arrive at the ordinary mode of expression, we simply need to say after an expression such as “There is one and only one x such that …”: and that x is a.

The world can be completely described using fully generalized propositions, that is without first correlating any name with a particular object.

31 May, 1915

Mit der Weltbeschreibung durch Namen kann man nicht mehr leisten als mit der allgemeinen Weltbeschreibung!!!

Using names in a description of the world one cannot achieve more than one can with a general world description!!!

Using names in a description of the world one cannot achieve more than one can with a general world description!!!

The world can be completely described using fully generalized propositions, that is without first correlating any name with a particular object.

31 May, 1915

Könnte man also ohne Namen auskommen?? Doch wohl nicht.

So could one do without names?? Not at all.

So could one do without names?? Not at all.

TLP 5·526 (1)

The world can be completely described using fully generalized sentences, that is to say: without first assigning any name to a particular object.

Then to arrive at the ordinary mode of expression, we simply need to say after an expression such as “There is one and only one x such that …”: and that x is a.

The world can be completely described using fully generalized propositions, that is without first correlating any name with a particular object.

31 May, 1915

Die Namen sind notwendig zu einer Aussage, daß dieses Ding jene Eigenschaft besitzt u.s.f.

Sie verknüpfen die Satzform mit ganz bestimmten Gegenständen.

Und wenn die allgemeine Weltbeschreibung wie eine Schablone der Welt ist, so nageln sie die Namen so an die Welt daß sie sich überall mit ihr deckt.

Names are necessary for a statement that this thing possesses that property and so on.

They link a propositional form to quite specific objects.

And if a general description of the world is like a mask for the world, names attach it to the world so that the world is completely covered by it.

Names are necessary for a statement that this thing possesses that property and so on.

They link a propositional form to quite specific objects.

And if a general description of the world is like a mask for the world, names attach it to the world so that the world is completely covered by it.

The world can be completely described using fully generalized propositions, that is without first correlating any name with a particular object.

TLP 5·526 (1)

Sie verknüpfen die Satzform mit ganz bestimmten Gegenständen.

Und wenn die allgemeine Weltbeschreibung wie eine Schablone der Welt ist, so nageln sie die Namen so an die Welt daß sie sich überall mit ihr deckt.

They link a propositional form to quite specific objects.

The world can be completely described using fully generalized propositions, that is without first correlating any name with a particular object.

1 June, 1915

Das große Problem um welches sich alles dreht, was ich schreibe, ist: Ist, a priori, eine Ordnung in der Welt, und wenn, ja, worin besteht sie?

The great problem around which everything I write turns is: Is there an order in the world a priori, and if so, what does it consist in?

The great problem around which everything I write turns is: Is there an order in the world a priori, and if so, what does it consist in?

1 June, 1915

Du siehst in die Nebelwolke / und kannst dir daher einreden das Ziel sei schon nahe.

Aber der Nebel zerrinnt und das Ziel ist noch nicht in Sicht!

You are looking into a foggy mist and so can talk yourself into believing the goal is already nearby.

But the fog melts away and the goal is not yet in sight!

You are looking into a foggy mist and so can talk yourself into believing the goal is already nearby.

But the fog melts away and the goal is not yet in sight!

1 June, 1915

Das große Problem um welches sich alles dreht, was ich schreibe, ist: Ist, a priori, eine Ordnung in der Welt, und wenn, ja, worin besteht sie?

The great problem around which everything I write turns is: Is there an order in the world a priori, and if so, what does it consist in?

The great problem around which everything I write turns is: Is there an order in the world a priori, and if so, what does it consist in?

1 June, 1915

Du siehst in die Nebelwolke / und kannst dir daher einreden das Ziel sei schon nahe.

Aber der Nebel zerrinnt und das Ziel ist noch nicht in Sicht!

You are looking into a foggy mist and so can talk yourself into believing the goal is already nearby.

But the fog melts away and the goal is not yet in sight!

You are looking into a foggy mist and so can talk yourself into believing the goal is already nearby.

But the fog melts away and the goal is not yet in sight!

2 June, 1915

Ich sagte: „Eine Tautologie wird von jedem Satze bejaht”; damit ist aber noch nicht gesagt, warum sie kein Satz ist. Ist denn damit schon gesagt warum ein Satz nicht von p und von ~p bejaht werden kann?!

I said: "A tautology is affirmed by every proposition"; but that doesn’t yet say enough to tell us why it isn’t a proposition. For does that already tell us why a proposition can’t be affirmed by p and ~p?!

I said: "A tautology is affirmed by every proposition"; but that doesn’t yet say enough to tell us why it isn’t a proposition. For does that already tell us why a proposition can’t be affirmed by p and ~p?!

2 June, 1915

Meine Theorie bringt nämlich eigentlich nicht heraus daß der Satz zwei Pole haben muß.

That is to say my theory does not really bring it out that a proposition must have two poles.

That is to say my theory does not really bring it out that a proposition must have two poles.

2 June, 1915

Ich müßte nämlich jetzt in der Redeweise dieser Theorie einen Ausdruck dafür finden, wieviel ein Satz sagt. Und es müßte sich dann eben ergeben daß Tautologien nichts sagen.

For what I should now have to do is to find an expression in the idiom of this theory for how much a proposition says. And it would have to yield the result that tautologies say nothing.

For what I should now have to do is to find an expression in the idiom of this theory for how much a proposition says. And it would have to yield the result that tautologies say nothing.

2 June, 1915

Aber wie ist dies Maß Vielsagendheit zu finden?

But how is this measure of how-much-is-said to be found?

But how is this measure of how-much-is-said to be found?

2 June, 1915

Es ist jedenfalls vorhanden; und unsere Theorie muß es zum Ausdruck bringen können.

However that may be, it is there; and our theory must be able to give it expression.

However that may be, it is there; and our theory must be able to give it expression.

2 June, 1915

Ich sagte: „Eine Tautologie wird von jedem Satze bejaht”; damit ist aber noch nicht gesagt, warum sie kein Satz ist. Ist denn damit schon gesagt warum ein Satz nicht von p und von ~p bejaht werden kann?!

I said: "A tautology is affirmed by every proposition"; but that doesn’t yet say enough to tell us why it isn’t a proposition. For does that already tell us why a proposition can’t be affirmed by p and ~p?!

I said: "A tautology is affirmed by every proposition"; but that doesn’t yet say enough to tell us why it isn’t a proposition. For does that already tell us why a proposition can’t be affirmed by p and ~p?!

2 June, 1915

Meine Theorie bringt nämlich eigentlich nicht heraus daß der Satz zwei Pole haben muß.

That is to say my theory does not really bring it out that a proposition must have two poles.

That is to say my theory does not really bring it out that a proposition must have two poles.

2 June, 1915

Ich müßte nämlich jetzt in der Redeweise dieser Theorie einen Ausdruck dafür finden, wieviel ein Satz sagt. Und es müßte sich dann eben ergeben daß Tautologien nichts sagen.

For what I should now have to do is to find an expression in the idiom of this theory for how much a proposition says. And it would have to yield the result that tautologies say nothing.

For what I should now have to do is to find an expression in the idiom of this theory for how much a proposition says. And it would have to yield the result that tautologies say nothing.

2 June, 1915

Aber wie ist dies Maß Vielsagendheit zu finden?

But how is this measure of how-much-is-said to be found?

But how is this measure of how-much-is-said to be found?

2 June, 1915

Es ist jedenfalls vorhanden; und unsere Theorie muß es zum Ausdruck bringen können.

However that may be, it is there; and our theory must be able to give it expression.

However that may be, it is there; and our theory must be able to give it expression.

TLP 5·14

If a sentence follows from another, then the latter says more than the former, and the former says less than the latter.

If a proposition follows from another, then the latter says more than the former, and the former says less than the latter.

3 June, 1915

Man könnte wohl sagen: Der Satz sagt am meisten, aus welchem am meisten folgt.

One could surely say: That proposition from which the most follows says the most. [Cf. 5.14.]

One could surely say: That proposition from which the most follows says the most. [Cf. 5.14.]

If a proposition follows from another, then the latter says more than the former, and the former says less than the latter.

3 June, 1915

Könnte man sagen: „aus welchem die / meisten, von einander unabhängigen, Sätze folgen”?

Could one say: "From which the most mutually independent propositions follow"?

Could one say: "From which the most mutually independent propositions follow"?

TLP 5·143 (1)

Contradiction is that shared feature of sentences which no sentence has in common with another. Tautology is that shared feature of all sentences which have nothing in common with one another.

Contradiction vanishes so to speak outside all sentences, tautology inside them.

Contradiction is the outer limit of sentences, tautology their substanceless centre.

Contradiction is what propositions have in common that no proposition has in common with another. Tautology is what all propositions have in common that have nothing in common with one another.

3 June, 1915

Aber geht es nicht so?: Wenn p aus q folgt, aber nicht q aus p, dann sagt q mehr als p.

Nun aber folgt aus einer Tautologie gar nichts. ——Sie aber folgt aus jedem Satz.

Analoges gilt von ihrem Gegenteil.

But doesn't it work this way: If p follows from q, but not q from p, then q says more than p?

Now nothing at all follows from a tautology. ——But it follows from every proposition. [Cf. 5.142.]

The analogous point applies to its opposite. [Cf. 5.143 (1).]

But doesn't it work this way: If p follows from q, but not q from p, then q says more than p?

Now nothing at all follows from a tautology. ——But it follows from every proposition. [Cf. 5.142.]

The analogous point applies to its opposite. [Cf. 5.143 (1).]

Contradiction is what propositions have in common that no proposition has in common with another. Tautology is what all propositions have in common that have nothing in common with one another.

TLP 4·466 (4)**

To a specific logical combination of signs corresponds a specific logical combination of their meanings. It is only to the uncombined signs that absolutely any combination corresponds.

That is, sentences that are true for every state of things cannot be combinations of signs at all, for otherwise only certain combinations of objects could correspond to them.

(And what isn’t a logical combination has no combination of objects corresponding to it.)

Tautology and contradiction are limiting cases of the combination of signs, namely their disintegration.

A definite logical combination of signs corresponds to a definite logical combination of their meanings. It is only to the uncombined signs that absolutely any combination corresponds. That is, propositions that are true for every situation cannot be combinations of signs at all, for otherwise, only definite combinations of objects would correspond to them. (And what isn’t a logical combination has no combination of objects corresponding to it.)

3 June, 1915

Aber wie! Wäre da die Kontradiktion nicht der vielsagendste Satz? Aus „p.~p” folgt ja nicht nur „p” sondern auch „~p”! Aus ihnen folgt jeder Satz und sie folgen aus keinem!? Aber ich kann doch aus / einer Kontradiktion nichts schließen, eben weil sie eine Kontradiktion ist!

Aber wenn die Kontradiktion die Klasse aller Sätze ist, so wird die Tautologie das Gemeinsame aller Klassen von Sätzen welche nichts Gemeinsames haben, und verschwindet gänzlich. „p ⌵ ~p” wäre also nur scheinbar ein Zeichen. In Wirklichkeit aber die Auflösung des Satzes.

But how would that work? Won't contradiction be the proposition that says the most then? It’s not only "p" that follows from "p.~p", but also "~p". Every proposition follows from it and it follows from none!? But I surely can’t infer anything from a contradiction, precisely because it is a contradiction!

But if contradiction is the class of all propositions, then tautology becomes that shared feature of any classes of propositions that have nothing in common, and vanishes altogether. "p ⌵ ~p" would then only appear to be a sign. But in reality, the disintegration of the proposition. [Cf. 5.143 (1-2); 4.466 (4).]

But how would that work? Won't contradiction be the proposition that says the most then? It’s not only "p" that follows from "p.~p", but also "~p". Every proposition follows from it and it follows from none!? But I surely can’t infer anything from a contradiction, precisely because it is a contradiction!

But if contradiction is the class of all propositions, then tautology becomes that shared feature of any classes of propositions that have nothing in common, and vanishes altogether. "p ⌵ ~p" would then only appear to be a sign. But in reality, the disintegration of the proposition. [Cf. 5.143 (1-2); 4.466 (4).]

A definite logical combination of signs corresponds to a definite logical combination of their meanings. It is only to the uncombined signs that absolutely any combination corresponds. That is, propositions that are true for every situation cannot be combinations of signs at all, for otherwise, only definite combinations of objects would correspond to them. (And what isn’t a logical combination has no combination of objects corresponding to it.)

TLP 5·143 (2)

Contradiction is that shared feature of sentences which no sentence has in common with another. Tautology is that shared feature of all sentences which have nothing in common with one another.

Contradiction vanishes so to speak outside all sentences, tautology inside them.

Contradiction is the outer limit of sentences, tautology their substanceless centre.

Contradiction is what propositions have in common that no proposition has in common with another. Tautology is what all propositions have in common that have nothing in common with one another.

3 June, 1915

Die Tautologie verschwindet sozusagen innerhalb allen Sätzen die Kontradiktion / außerhalb allen Sätzen.

Tautology vanishes so to speak inside all propositions, contradiction outside them. [See 5.143 (2).]

Tautology vanishes so to speak inside all propositions, contradiction outside them. [See 5.143 (2).]

Contradiction is what propositions have in common that no proposition has in common with another. Tautology is what all propositions have in common that have nothing in common with one another.

3 June, 1915

– Bei diesen Betrachtungen scheine ich übrigens immer unbewußt vom Elementarsatz auszugehen. ——

- Incidentally, in these observations I always seem to be unconsciously starting from the elementary proposition. ——

- Incidentally, in these observations I always seem to be unconsciously starting from the elementary proposition. ——

TLP 5·143 (3)*

Contradiction is that shared feature of sentences which no sentence has in common with another. Tautology is that shared feature of all sentences which have nothing in common with one another.

Contradiction vanishes so to speak outside all sentences, tautology inside them.

Contradiction is the outer limit of sentences, tautology their substanceless centre.

Contradiction is what propositions have in common that no proposition has in common with another. Tautology is what all propositions have in common that have nothing in common with one another.

3 June, 1915

Die Kontradiktion ist die äußere Grenze der Sätze; kein Satz bejaht sie. Die Tautologie ist ihr substanzloser Mittelpunkt. (Man kann den Mittelpunkt einer Kreisfläche als deren innere Begrenzung auffassen.)

Contradiction is the outer limit of propositions; no proposition affirms it. Tautology is their substanceless centre. (One can regard the center of a circular area as its inner limit). [Cf. 5.143 (3).]

Contradiction is the outer limit of propositions; no proposition affirms it. Tautology is their substanceless centre. (One can regard the center of a circular area as its inner limit). [Cf. 5.143 (3).]

Contradiction is what propositions have in common that no proposition has in common with another. Tautology is what all propositions have in common that have nothing in common with one another.

3 June, 1915

(Das erlösende Wort ist übrigens hier noch nicht gesprochen.)

(In fact the redeeming word still hasn’t been uttered here).

(In fact the redeeming word still hasn’t been uttered here).

3 June, 1915

Es ist hier nämlich sehr leicht die logische Addition und das / logische Produkt miteinander zu verwechseln.

The thing is that here it is very easy to confuse logical sum and logical product.

The thing is that here it is very easy to confuse logical sum and logical product.

3 June, 1915

Wir kommen nämlich zu dem scheinbar merkwürdigen Resultat, daß zwei Sätze etwas gemeinsam haben müssen um von einem Satz bejaht werden zu können.

For we get to the seemingly strange result that two propositions must have something in common to be capable of being affirmed by one proposition.

For we get to the seemingly strange result that two propositions must have something in common to be capable of being affirmed by one proposition.

3 June, 1915

(Die Gehörigkeit zu einer Klasse ist aber auch etwas, was Sätze gemeinsam haben können!)

(Belonging to a single class, however, is also something that propositions can have in common!)

(Belonging to a single class, however, is also something that propositions can have in common!)

3 June, 1915

(Hier liegt noch eine entschiedene und entscheidende Unklarheit in meiner Theorie. Daher ein gewisses Gefühl der Unbefriedigung!)

(Here there is still a pronounced and crucial lack of clarity in my theory. Hence a certain feeling of uneasiness!)

(Here there is still a pronounced and crucial lack of clarity in my theory. Hence a certain feeling of uneasiness!)

TLP 5·14

If a sentence follows from another, then the latter says more than the former, and the former says less than the latter.

If a proposition follows from another, then the latter says more than the former, and the former says less than the latter.

3 June, 1915

Man könnte wohl sagen: Der Satz sagt am meisten, aus welchem am meisten folgt.

One could surely say: That proposition from which the most follows says the most. [Cf. 5.14.]

One could surely say: That proposition from which the most follows says the most. [Cf. 5.14.]

If a proposition follows from another, then the latter says more than the former, and the former says less than the latter.

3 June, 1915

Könnte man sagen: „aus welchem die / meisten, von einander unabhängigen, Sätze folgen”?

Could one say: "From which the most mutually independent propositions follow"?

Could one say: "From which the most mutually independent propositions follow"?

TLP 5·143 (1)

Contradiction is that shared feature of sentences which no sentence has in common with another. Tautology is that shared feature of all sentences which have nothing in common with one another.

Contradiction vanishes so to speak outside all sentences, tautology inside them.

Contradiction is the outer limit of sentences, tautology their substanceless centre.

Contradiction is what propositions have in common that no proposition has in common with another. Tautology is what all propositions have in common that have nothing in common with one another.

3 June, 1915

Aber geht es nicht so?: Wenn p aus q folgt, aber nicht q aus p, dann sagt q mehr als p.

Nun aber folgt aus einer Tautologie gar nichts. ——Sie aber folgt aus jedem Satz.

Analoges gilt von ihrem Gegenteil.

But doesn't it work this way: If p follows from q, but not q from p, then q says more than p?

Now nothing at all follows from a tautology. ——But it follows from every proposition. [Cf. 5.142.]

The analogous point applies to its opposite. [Cf. 5.143 (1).]

But doesn't it work this way: If p follows from q, but not q from p, then q says more than p?

Now nothing at all follows from a tautology. ——But it follows from every proposition. [Cf. 5.142.]

The analogous point applies to its opposite. [Cf. 5.143 (1).]

Contradiction is what propositions have in common that no proposition has in common with another. Tautology is what all propositions have in common that have nothing in common with one another.

TLP 4·466 (4)**

To a specific logical combination of signs corresponds a specific logical combination of their meanings. It is only to the uncombined signs that absolutely any combination corresponds.

That is, sentences that are true for every state of things cannot be combinations of signs at all, for otherwise only certain combinations of objects could correspond to them.

(And what isn’t a logical combination has no combination of objects corresponding to it.)

Tautology and contradiction are limiting cases of the combination of signs, namely their disintegration.

A definite logical combination of signs corresponds to a definite logical combination of their meanings. It is only to the uncombined signs that absolutely any combination corresponds. That is, propositions that are true for every situation cannot be combinations of signs at all, for otherwise, only definite combinations of objects would correspond to them. (And what isn’t a logical combination has no combination of objects corresponding to it.)

3 June, 1915

Aber wie! Wäre da die Kontradiktion nicht der vielsagendste Satz? Aus „p.~p” folgt ja nicht nur „p” sondern auch „~p”! Aus ihnen folgt jeder Satz und sie folgen aus keinem!? Aber ich kann doch aus / einer Kontradiktion nichts schließen, eben weil sie eine Kontradiktion ist!

Aber wenn die Kontradiktion die Klasse aller Sätze ist, so wird die Tautologie das Gemeinsame aller Klassen von Sätzen welche nichts Gemeinsames haben, und verschwindet gänzlich. „p ⌵ ~p” wäre also nur scheinbar ein Zeichen. In Wirklichkeit aber die Auflösung des Satzes.

But how would that work? Won't contradiction be the proposition that says the most then? It’s not only "p" that follows from "p.~p", but also "~p". Every proposition follows from it and it follows from none!? But I surely can’t infer anything from a contradiction, precisely because it is a contradiction!

But if contradiction is the class of all propositions, then tautology becomes that shared feature of any classes of propositions that have nothing in common, and vanishes altogether. "p ⌵ ~p" would then only appear to be a sign. But in reality, the disintegration of the proposition. [Cf. 5.143 (1-2); 4.466 (4).]

But how would that work? Won't contradiction be the proposition that says the most then? It’s not only "p" that follows from "p.~p", but also "~p". Every proposition follows from it and it follows from none!? But I surely can’t infer anything from a contradiction, precisely because it is a contradiction!

But if contradiction is the class of all propositions, then tautology becomes that shared feature of any classes of propositions that have nothing in common, and vanishes altogether. "p ⌵ ~p" would then only appear to be a sign. But in reality, the disintegration of the proposition. [Cf. 5.143 (1-2); 4.466 (4).]

A definite logical combination of signs corresponds to a definite logical combination of their meanings. It is only to the uncombined signs that absolutely any combination corresponds. That is, propositions that are true for every situation cannot be combinations of signs at all, for otherwise, only definite combinations of objects would correspond to them. (And what isn’t a logical combination has no combination of objects corresponding to it.)

TLP 5·143 (2)

Contradiction is that shared feature of sentences which no sentence has in common with another. Tautology is that shared feature of all sentences which have nothing in common with one another.

Contradiction vanishes so to speak outside all sentences, tautology inside them.

Contradiction is the outer limit of sentences, tautology their substanceless centre.

Contradiction is what propositions have in common that no proposition has in common with another. Tautology is what all propositions have in common that have nothing in common with one another.

3 June, 1915

Die Tautologie verschwindet sozusagen innerhalb allen Sätzen die Kontradiktion / außerhalb allen Sätzen.

Tautology vanishes so to speak inside all propositions, contradiction outside them. [See 5.143 (2).]

Tautology vanishes so to speak inside all propositions, contradiction outside them. [See 5.143 (2).]

Contradiction is what propositions have in common that no proposition has in common with another. Tautology is what all propositions have in common that have nothing in common with one another.

3 June, 1915

– Bei diesen Betrachtungen scheine ich übrigens immer unbewußt vom Elementarsatz auszugehen. ——

- Incidentally, in these observations I always seem to be unconsciously starting from the elementary proposition. ——

- Incidentally, in these observations I always seem to be unconsciously starting from the elementary proposition. ——

TLP 5·143 (3)*

Contradiction is that shared feature of sentences which no sentence has in common with another. Tautology is that shared feature of all sentences which have nothing in common with one another.

Contradiction vanishes so to speak outside all sentences, tautology inside them.

Contradiction is the outer limit of sentences, tautology their substanceless centre.

Contradiction is what propositions have in common that no proposition has in common with another. Tautology is what all propositions have in common that have nothing in common with one another.

3 June, 1915

Die Kontradiktion ist die äußere Grenze der Sätze; kein Satz bejaht sie. Die Tautologie ist ihr substanzloser Mittelpunkt. (Man kann den Mittelpunkt einer Kreisfläche als deren innere Begrenzung auffassen.)

Contradiction is the outer limit of propositions; no proposition affirms it. Tautology is their substanceless centre. (One can regard the center of a circular area as its inner limit). [Cf. 5.143 (3).]

Contradiction is the outer limit of propositions; no proposition affirms it. Tautology is their substanceless centre. (One can regard the center of a circular area as its inner limit). [Cf. 5.143 (3).]

Contradiction is what propositions have in common that no proposition has in common with another. Tautology is what all propositions have in common that have nothing in common with one another.

3 June, 1915

(Das erlösende Wort ist übrigens hier noch nicht gesprochen.)

(In fact the redeeming word still hasn’t been uttered here).

(In fact the redeeming word still hasn’t been uttered here).

3 June, 1915

Es ist hier nämlich sehr leicht die logische Addition und das / logische Produkt miteinander zu verwechseln.

The thing is that here it is very easy to confuse logical sum and logical product.

The thing is that here it is very easy to confuse logical sum and logical product.

3 June, 1915

Wir kommen nämlich zu dem scheinbar merkwürdigen Resultat, daß zwei Sätze etwas gemeinsam haben müssen um von einem Satz bejaht werden zu können.

For we get to the seemingly strange result that two propositions must have something in common to be capable of being affirmed by one proposition.

For we get to the seemingly strange result that two propositions must have something in common to be capable of being affirmed by one proposition.

3 June, 1915

(Die Gehörigkeit zu einer Klasse ist aber auch etwas, was Sätze gemeinsam haben können!)

(Belonging to a single class, however, is also something that propositions can have in common!)

(Belonging to a single class, however, is also something that propositions can have in common!)

3 June, 1915

(Hier liegt noch eine entschiedene und entscheidende Unklarheit in meiner Theorie. Daher ein gewisses Gefühl der Unbefriedigung!)

(Here there is still a pronounced and crucial lack of clarity in my theory. Hence a certain feeling of uneasiness!)

(Here there is still a pronounced and crucial lack of clarity in my theory. Hence a certain feeling of uneasiness!)

TLP 5·515**

It must become evident from our symbols that it can only be sentences that are connected by “∨”, “.”, etc.

And this is indeed the case, for the symbol “p”, and “q”, itself presupposes “∨”, “~”, etc. If the sign “p” in “p∨q” does not stand for a complex sign, then it cannot make sense by itself: but then the signs “p∨p”, “p.p”, etc., which have the same sense as “p”, cannot make sense either. However, if “p∨p” makes no sense, then “p∨q” cannot make sense either.

It must show itself in our sentential signs that it can only be sentential signs that are connected by “∨”, “.”, etc. And this is indeed so, for the symbol in “p” and “q” itself presupposes “∨”, “.”, etc. If the sign “p” in “p∨q” does not stand for a complex sign, then it cannot make sense by itself: but then the signs “p∨p”, “p.p”, etc., which have the same sense as “p”, must also not make sense. However, if “p∨p” makes no sense, then “p∨q” cannot make sense either.

4 June, 1915

„p.q” hat nur dann Sinn / wenn „p ⌵ q” Sinn hat.

"p.q" only makes sense if "p ⌵ q" makes sense.

"p.q" only makes sense if "p ⌵ q" makes sense.

It must show itself in our sentential signs that it can only be sentential signs that are connected by “∨”, “.”, etc. And this is indeed so, for the symbol in “p” and “q” itself presupposes “∨”, “.”, etc. If the sign “p” in “p∨q” does not stand for a complex sign, then it cannot make sense by itself: but then the signs “p∨p”, “p.p”, etc., which have the same sense as “p”, must also not make sense. However, if “p∨p” makes no sense, then “p∨q” cannot make sense either.

TLP 5·515**

It must become evident from our symbols that it can only be sentences that are connected by “∨”, “.”, etc.

And this is indeed the case, for the symbol “p”, and “q”, itself presupposes “∨”, “~”, etc. If the sign “p” in “p∨q” does not stand for a complex sign, then it cannot make sense by itself: but then the signs “p∨p”, “p.p”, etc., which have the same sense as “p”, cannot make sense either. However, if “p∨p” makes no sense, then “p∨q” cannot make sense either.

It must show itself in our sentential signs that it can only be sentential signs that are connected by “∨”, “.”, etc. And this is indeed so, for the symbol in “p” and “q” itself presupposes “∨”, “.”, etc. If the sign “p” in “p∨q” does not stand for a complex sign, then it cannot make sense by itself: but then the signs “p∨p”, “p.p”, etc., which have the same sense as “p”, must also not make sense. However, if “p∨p” makes no sense, then “p∨q” cannot make sense either.

4 June, 1915

„p.q” hat nur dann Sinn / wenn „p ⌵ q” Sinn hat.

"p.q" only makes sense if "p ⌵ q" makes sense.

"p.q" only makes sense if "p ⌵ q" makes sense.

It must show itself in our sentential signs that it can only be sentential signs that are connected by “∨”, “.”, etc. And this is indeed so, for the symbol in “p” and “q” itself presupposes “∨”, “.”, etc. If the sign “p” in “p∨q” does not stand for a complex sign, then it cannot make sense by itself: but then the signs “p∨p”, “p.p”, etc., which have the same sense as “p”, must also not make sense. However, if “p∨p” makes no sense, then “p∨q” cannot make sense either.

5 June, 1915

„p.q” bejaht „p” und „q”. Das heißt aber doch nicht daß „p.q” der gemeinsame Bestandteil von „p” und „q” ist sondern im Gegenteil daß sowohl „p” als auch „q” in „p.q” enthalten sind.

"p.q" affirms "p" and "q." But that surely does not mean that "p.q" is the common constituent of "p" and "q", but on the contrary that both "p" and "q" are contained in "p.q".

"p.q" affirms "p" and "q." But that surely does not mean that "p.q" is the common constituent of "p" and "q", but on the contrary that both "p" and "q" are contained in "p.q".

5 June, 1915

In diesem Sinne hätten p und ~p sogar etwas gemein zum Beispiel Sätze wie ~p ⌵ q und p ⌵ q. Das heißt: es gibt allerdings Sätze welche sowohl von „p” als auch von „~p” bejaht werden – z.B. die obigen –; es gibt aber keine die sowohl p als auch ~p bejahen.

In this sense, p and ~p would actually have something in common, for example propositions such as ~p ⌵ q and p ⌵ q. That is: there are propositions which are affirmed by both "p" and "~p" —the above ones, for instance —but there are none that affirm p as well as also affirming ~p.

In this sense, p and ~p would actually have something in common, for example propositions such as ~p ⌵ q and p ⌵ q. That is: there are propositions which are affirmed by both "p" and "~p" —the above ones, for instance —but there are none that affirm p as well as also affirming ~p.

5 June, 1915

Damit ein Satz wahr sein kann / muß er auch falsch sein können.

For a proposition to be capable of being true it must also be capable of being false.

For a proposition to be capable of being true it must also be capable of being false.

5 June, 1915

Warum sagt die Tautologie nichts? Weil in ihr von vornherein jede Möglichkeit zugegeben wird; weil …

Why does a tautology say nothing? Because every possibility is admitted in it from the start; because ...

Why does a tautology say nothing? Because every possibility is admitted in it from the start; because ...

TLP 4·461 (1)

A sentence shows what it says: a tautology and a contradiction show that they say nothing.

Because a tautology is unconditionally true, it has no truth-conditions; on no condition is a contradiction true.

Tautologies and contradictions lack sense.

(Like a point from which two arrows go in opposite directions.)

(For example, I know nothing about the weather if I know that it is either raining or not raining.)

Because a tautology is unconditionally true, it has no truth-conditions; on no condition is a contradiction true.

5 June, 1915

Es muß sich im Satz selbst zeigen daß er etwas sagt und an der Tautologie daß sie nichts sagt.

The proposition itself must show that it says something, and the tautology that it says nothing.

The proposition itself must show that it says something, and the tautology that it says nothing.

Because a tautology is unconditionally true, it has no truth-conditions; on no condition is a contradiction true.

5 June, 1915

p.~ p ist dasjenige – etwa das Nichts – welches p und ~p gemeinsam haben.

p.~ p is the one thing—say that nothing—that p and ~p have in common.

p.~ p is the one thing—say that nothing—that p and ~p have in common.

TLP 5·515**

It must become evident from our symbols that it can only be sentences that are connected by “∨”, “.”, etc.

And this is indeed the case, for the symbol “p”, and “q”, itself presupposes “∨”, “~”, etc. If the sign “p” in “p∨q” does not stand for a complex sign, then it cannot make sense by itself: but then the signs “p∨p”, “p.p”, etc., which have the same sense as “p”, cannot make sense either. However, if “p∨p” makes no sense, then “p∨q” cannot make sense either.

It must show itself in our sentential signs that it can only be sentential signs that are connected by “∨”, “.”, etc. And this is indeed so, for the symbol in “p” and “q” itself presupposes “∨”, “.”, etc. If the sign “p” in “p∨q” does not stand for a complex sign, then it cannot make sense by itself: but then the signs “p∨p”, “p.p”, etc., which have the same sense as “p”, must also not make sense. However, if “p∨p” makes no sense, then “p∨q” cannot make sense either.

5 June, 1915

In dem eigentlichen Zeichen für p liegt wirklich schon das / Zeichen „p ⌵ q”. (Denn es ist dann möglich dieses Zeichen ohne Weiteres zu bilden.)

The sign "p ⌵ q" is already contained in the proper sign for p. (For it is then possible to form this sign automatically).

The sign "p ⌵ q" is already contained in the proper sign for p. (For it is then possible to form this sign automatically).

It must show itself in our sentential signs that it can only be sentential signs that are connected by “∨”, “.”, etc. And this is indeed so, for the symbol in “p” and “q” itself presupposes “∨”, “.”, etc. If the sign “p” in “p∨q” does not stand for a complex sign, then it cannot make sense by itself: but then the signs “p∨p”, “p.p”, etc., which have the same sense as “p”, must also not make sense. However, if “p∨p” makes no sense, then “p∨q” cannot make sense either.

5 June, 1915

„p.q” bejaht „p” und „q”. Das heißt aber doch nicht daß „p.q” der gemeinsame Bestandteil von „p” und „q” ist sondern im Gegenteil daß sowohl „p” als auch „q” in „p.q” enthalten sind.

"p.q" affirms "p" and "q." But that surely does not mean that "p.q" is the common constituent of "p" and "q", but on the contrary that both "p" and "q" are contained in "p.q".

5 June, 1915

In diesem Sinne hätten p und ~p sogar etwas gemein zum Beispiel Sätze wie ~p ⌵ q und p ⌵ q. Das heißt: es gibt allerdings Sätze welche sowohl von „p” als auch von „~p” bejaht werden – z.B. die obigen –; es gibt aber keine die sowohl p als auch ~p bejahen.

In this sense, p and ~p would actually have something in common, for example propositions such as ~p ⌵ q and p ⌵ q. That is: there are propositions which are affirmed by both "p" and "~p" —the above ones, for instance —but there are none that affirm p as well as also affirming ~p.

5 June, 1915

Damit ein Satz wahr sein kann / muß er auch falsch sein können.

For a proposition to be capable of being true it must also be capable of being false.

For a proposition to be capable of being true it must also be capable of being false.

5 June, 1915

Warum sagt die Tautologie nichts? Weil in ihr von vornherein jede Möglichkeit zugegeben wird; weil …

Why does a tautology say nothing? Because every possibility is admitted in it from the start; because ...

Because a tautology is unconditionally true, it has no truth-conditions; on no condition is a contradiction true.

(Like a point from which two arrows go in opposite directions.)

5 June, 1915

p.~ p ist dasjenige – etwa das Nichts – welches p und ~p gemeinsam haben.

p.~ p is the one thing—say that nothing—that p and ~p have in common.

p.~ p is the one thing—say that nothing—that p and ~p have in common.

TLP 5·515**

It must become evident from our symbols that it can only be sentences that are connected by “∨”, “.”, etc.

And this is indeed the case, for the symbol “p”, and “q”, itself presupposes “∨”, “~”, etc. If the sign “p” in “p∨q” does not stand for a complex sign, then it cannot make sense by itself: but then the signs “p∨p”, “p.p”, etc., which have the same sense as “p”, cannot make sense either.
