Beiläufig gefragt: handelt die Logik von gewissen Gattungen von Funktionen u. dergl.? Und wenn nicht, was bedeuten dann Fx φz u.s.w. in der Logik?

Dies müssen dann Zeichen allgemeinerer Bedeutung sein!

Roughly speaking: Does logic deal with certain kinds of functions and the like? And if not, what then do Fx, φz, and so on signify in logic?

Then these must be signs of more general sigificance!

Roughly speaking: Does logic deal with certain kinds of functions and the like? And if not, what then do Fx, φz, and so on signify in logic?

Then these must be signs of more general sigificance!

19 June, 1915

Das Aufstellen einer Art logischen Inventars wie ich mir das früher vorstellte scheint es doch wohl nicht zu geben.

There doesn't after all seem to be any setting up of a kind of logical inventory as I previously imagined it.

There doesn't after all seem to be any setting up of a kind of logical inventory as I previously imagined it.

19 June, 1915

Die Bestandteile des Satzes müssen einfach sein = Der Satz muß vollkommen artikuliert sein.

The constituents of a proposition must be simple = A proposition must be completely articulate.

The constituents of a proposition must be simple = A proposition must be completely articulate.

19 June, 1915

Nun scheint dies aber den Tatsachen zu widersprechen? ——

But now does this seem to contradict the facts? ——

But now does this seem to contradict the facts? ——

19 June, 1915

In der Logik nämlich wollen wir scheinbar Idealbilder artikulierter Sätze vorführen. Aber wie ist das möglich?

For in logic we are ostensibly trying to present idealised models of articulated propositions. But how is that possible?

For in logic we are ostensibly trying to present idealised models of articulated propositions. But how is that possible?

19 June, 1915

Oder können wir einen Satz wie „die Uhr liegt auf dem Tisch” ohne weiteres nach den Regeln der Logik behandeln. Nein; da sagen wir z.B. daß die Zeitangabe in dem Satze verschwiegen ist daß er nur scheinbar … etc. etc.

Also ehe wir ihn behandeln können müssen wir ihn wie es scheint auf eine gewisse Art und Weise umgestalten.

Or can we treat a proposition like "the watch is on the table" without further ado according to the rules of logic? No, here we say, for example, that the proposition’s date is omitted, that the proposition only seems to be... etc. etc.

So it seems we have to transform it in a specific way before we can deal with it.

Or can we treat a proposition like "the watch is on the table" without further ado according to the rules of logic? No, here we say, for example, that the proposition’s date is omitted, that the proposition only seems to be... etc. etc.

So it seems we have to transform it in a specific way before we can deal with it.

19 June, 1915

Aber dies ist vielleicht nicht maßgebend, denn könnten wir nicht ebensogut unsere gewohnte logische Schreibweise dem speziellen Satz anpassen?

But perhaps this is not decisive, for couldn’t we just as well adapt our usual logical notation to the special proposition?

But perhaps this is not decisive, for couldn’t we just as well adapt our usual logical notation to the special proposition?

20 June, 1915

Ja, darum handelt es sich: Können wir mit Recht die Logik wie sie etwa in den „Principia Mathematica” steht ohne weiteres auf die gebräuchlichen Sätze anwenden?

Yes, this is the question: Can we legitimately apply logic as written down, say in Principia Mathematica, to ordinary propositions without further ado?

Yes, this is the question: Can we legitimately apply logic as written down, say in Principia Mathematica, to ordinary propositions without further ado?

20 June, 1915

Natürlich dürfen wir nicht außer acht lassen was in unseren Sätzen durch Endungen, Vorsilben Umlaute etc. etc. ausgedrückt ist.

Of course, we shouldn’t disregard what is expressed in our propositions by means of endings, prefixes, suffixes, etc., etc.

Of course, we shouldn’t disregard what is expressed in our propositions by means of endings, prefixes, suffixes, etc., etc.

20 June, 1915

Aber wir wenden ja die Mathematik, und zwar mit bestem Erfolge, auf die gewöhnlichen Sätze nämlich auf die der Physik an!!

But we do apply mathematics, and moreover with the utmost effectiveness, to ordinary propositions, namely to those of physics.

But we do apply mathematics, and moreover with the utmost effectiveness, to ordinary propositions, namely to those of physics.

20 June, 1915

Aber wie merkwürdig: in den bekannten Lehrsätzen der mathematischen Physik erscheinen weder Dinge noch Funktionen noch Relationen noch sonst logische Gegenstandsformen!! Statt der Dinge haben wir da Zahlen und die Funktionen & Relationen sind durchweg rein mathematisch!!

But it is remarkable: in the well-known theorems of mathematical physics there appear neither things nor functions nor relations nor any other logical forms of object! Instead of things what we have here are numbers, and the functions and relations are purely mathematical throughout!

But it is remarkable: in the well-known theorems of mathematical physics there appear neither things nor functions nor relations nor any other logical forms of object! Instead of things what we have here are numbers, and the functions and relations are purely mathematical throughout!

TLP 2·0124

If all objects are given, then all possible states of affairs are given at the same time.

If all objects are given, then thereby all possible elementary facts are also given.

20 June, 1915

Aber es ist doch Tatsache daß diese Sätze auf die solide Wirklichkeit angewandt werden.

But surely it is a fact that these propositions are applied to solid reality.

But surely it is a fact that these propositions are applied to solid reality.

If all objects are given, then thereby all possible elementary facts are also given.

20 June, 1915

Die Variablen in jenen Lehrsätzen stehen durchaus nicht – wie man häufig sagt – für Längen, Gewichte, Zeiträume etc. sondern sie stehen einfach für Zahlen und weiter nichts.

The variables in those theorems definitely do not—as it is often said—stand for lengths, weights, periods of time etc. Rather, they simply stand for numbers and nothing else.

The variables in those theorems definitely do not—as it is often said—stand for lengths, weights, periods of time etc. Rather, they simply stand for numbers and nothing else.

20 June, 1915

Wenn ich nun aber die Zahlen anwenden will dann komme ich zu den Relationen den Dingen etc. etc. Ich sage z.B.: diese Länge ist 5 Meter und spreche da von Relationen und Dingen, und zwar in dem ganz gewöhnlichen Sinne.

However, if I now want to apply numbers then I come to relations, things etc. etc.. I say, for instance “This length is 5 meters”, and here I am talking of relations and things, and in the completely ordinary sense at that.

However, if I now want to apply numbers then I come to relations, things etc. etc.. I say, for instance “This length is 5 meters”, and here I am talking of relations and things, and in the completely ordinary sense at that.

20 June, 1915

Wir kommen hier zur Frage nach der Bedeutung der Variablen in den physikalischen Sätzen. Diese sind ja keine Tautologien.

Here we come to the question about the meaning of variables in propositions of physics. These are, after all, no tautologies.

Here we come to the question about the meaning of variables in propositions of physics. These are, after all, no tautologies.

TLP 2·0124

If all objects are given, then all possible states of affairs are given at the same time.

If all objects are given, then thereby all possible elementary facts are also given.

20 June, 1915

Der physikalische Satz ohne Angabe seiner Anwendung ist offenbar sinnlos. Was hätte es für einen Sinn zu sagen: „k = m ∙ p”?

Also handelt der vervollständigte physikalische Satz doch von den Dingen Relationen u.s.w. (Was eigentlich zu erwarten war.)

A proposition of physics is obviously senseless if its application is not specified. What sort of sense would it have to say: "k = m ∙ p"?

So the complete physical proposition does deal with things, relations, and so on, after all. (Which was to be expected, for that matter.)

A proposition of physics is obviously senseless if its application is not specified. What sort of sense would it have to say: "k = m ∙ p"?

So the complete physical proposition does deal with things, relations, and so on, after all. (Which was to be expected, for that matter.)

If all objects are given, then thereby all possible elementary facts are also given.

20 June, 1915

Es liegt nun alles darin daß ich die Zahlen auf die gewöhnlichen Dinge etc. anwende, was wieder nicht mehr sagt als daß in unseren ganz gewöhnlichen Sätzen Zahlen vorkommen.

Now everything turns on my applying numbers to ordinary things etc., which again says no more than that numbers occur in our quite ordinary sentences.

Now everything turns on my applying numbers to ordinary things etc., which again says no more than that numbers occur in our quite ordinary sentences.

20 June, 1915

Die Schwierigkeit ist eigentlich die: daß wenn wir auch einen ganz bestimmten Sinn ausdrücken wollen die Möglichkeit / besteht daß wir dieses Ziel verfehlen. Es scheint also sozusagen daß wir keine Garantie haben daß unser Satz wirklich ein Bild der Wirklichkeit ist.

Actually, the difficulty is this: even if we want to express a completely definite sense, we may miss this goal. So it seems, so to speak, that we have no guarantee that our proposition is really a picture of reality.

Actually, the difficulty is this: even if we want to express a completely definite sense, we may miss this goal. So it seems, so to speak, that we have no guarantee that our proposition is really a picture of reality.

20 June, 1915

Die Zerlegung der Körper in materielle Punkte wie wir sie in der Physik haben ist weiter nichts als die Analyse in einfache Bestandteile.

The decomposition of bodies into material points, as we have it in physics, is nothing more than an analysis into simple constituents.

The decomposition of bodies into material points, as we have it in physics, is nothing more than an analysis into simple constituents.

20 June, 1915

Aber sollte es möglich sein daß die von uns gewöhnlich gebrauchten Sätze gleichsam nur einen unvollkommenen Sinn haben (ganz abgesehen von ihrer Wahr- oder Falschheit) und die physikalischen Sätze sich sozusagen / dem Stadium nähern wo ein Satz wirklich einen vollkommenen Sinn hat??

But could it be possible that sentences in ordinary use have, as it were, only an incomplete sense (not to speak of their truth or falsity) and the propositions of physics are getting closer, so to speak, to the state where a proposition really has a complete sense??

But could it be possible that sentences in ordinary use have, as it were, only an incomplete sense (not to speak of their truth or falsity) and the propositions of physics are getting closer, so to speak, to the state where a proposition really has a complete sense??

20 June, 1915

Wenn ich sage „das Buch liegt auf dem Tisch” hat dies wirklich einen vollkommen klaren Sinn? (Eine höchst bedeutungsvolle Frage!)

Der Sinn muß doch klar sein denn etwas meinen wir doch mit dem Satz und soviel als wir sicher meinen muß doch klar sein.

When I say "The book is lying on the table" does this really have a completely clear sense? (An extremely important question!)

The sense must surely be clear, for we surely mean something by the proposition and as much as we certainly mean must surely be clear.

When I say "The book is lying on the table" does this really have a completely clear sense? (An extremely important question!)

The sense must surely be clear, for we surely mean something by the proposition and as much as we certainly mean must surely be clear.

20 June, 1915

Wenn der Satz „das Buch liegt auf dem Tisch” einen klaren Sinn hat, dann muß ich, was immer auch der Fall ist, sagen können ob der Satz wahr oder falsch ist. Es könnten aber sehr wohl Fälle eintreten in welchen ich nicht ohne / Weiteres sagen könnte ob das Buch noch „auf dem Tisch liegend” zu nennen ist. Also?

If the proposition "The book is on the table" has a clear sense, then I must, whatever is the case, be able to say whether the proposition is true or false. However, there could very well be cases in which I couldn’t say without further ado whether the book is still to be called "lying on the table". Well—?

If the proposition "The book is on the table" has a clear sense, then I must, whatever is the case, be able to say whether the proposition is true or false. However, there could very well be cases in which I couldn’t say without further ado whether the book is still to be called "lying on the table". Well—?

20 June, 1915

Ist also etwa der Fall der daß ich zwar genau weiß was ich sagen will aber dann im Ausdrucke Fehler mache?

So is this a case in which I know exactly what I want to say, but then express it mistakenly?

So is this a case in which I know exactly what I want to say, but then express it mistakenly?

20 June, 1915

Oder kann diese Unsicherheit auch noch in den Satz eingeschlossen werden?

Or can this uncertainty be included in the proposition as well?

Or can this uncertainty be included in the proposition as well?

20 June, 1915

Aber es kann auch sein daß der Satz „das Buch liegt auf dem Tisch” meinen Sinn zwar vollkommen darstellt daß ich aber die Worte z.B. darauf-liegen hier in einer speziellen Bedeutung gebrauche / und es anderswo eine andere Bedeutung hat. Ich meine mit dem Verbum etwa die ganz spezielle Relation die das Buch jetzt wirklich zu dem Tisch hat.

But it could also be that the proposition "The book is lying on the table" represents my sense perfectly, but I use the words, e.g., “lying on” with a special meaning here, and that they have another meaning elsewhere. What I mean by the verb is, say, a quite special relation which the book now actually has to the table.

But it could also be that the proposition "The book is lying on the table" represents my sense perfectly, but I use the words, e.g., “lying on” with a special meaning here, and that they have another meaning elsewhere. What I mean by the verb is, say, a quite special relation which the book now actually has to the table.

20 June, 1915

Sind also im Grunde die Sätze der Physik und die Sätze des gewöhnlichen Lebens gleich scharf und besteht der Unterschied nur in der konsequenteren Anwendung der Zeichen in der Sprache der Wissenschaft??

Then are the propositions of physics and the propositions of ordinary life in principle equally sharp, and does the difference consist only in the more consistent application of signs in the language of science??

Then are the propositions of physics and the propositions of ordinary life in principle equally sharp, and does the difference consist only in the more consistent application of signs in the language of science??

20 June, 1915

Kann man davon reden oder nicht daß ein Satz einen mehr oder weniger scharfen Sinn hat??

Is it or isn’t it possible to talk of a proposition's having a more or less sharp sense??

Is it or isn’t it possible to talk of a proposition's having a more or less sharp sense??

20 June, 1915

Es scheint klar daß das was wir meinen immer „scharf” sein muß.

Unser Ausdruck dessen was wir meinen kann wieder nur richtig oder falsch sein. Und nun können noch die Worte konsequent oder inkonsequent angewendet sein. Eine andere Möglichkeit scheint es nicht zu geben.

It seems clear that what we mean must always be "sharp".

Once more, our expression of what we mean can only be right or wrong. And now the words can, in addition be applied consistently or inconsistently. There doesn’t seem to be any other possibility.

It seems clear that what we mean must always be "sharp".

Once more, our expression of what we mean can only be right or wrong. And now the words can, in addition be applied consistently or inconsistently. There doesn’t seem to be any other possibility.

20 June, 1915

Wenn ich z.B. sage „der Tisch ist einen Meter lang” so ist es höchst fraglich was ich damit meine. Aber ich meine wohl der Abstand dieser zwei Punkte ist ein Meter und die Punkte gehören zum Tisch.

If I say, for example, "the table is one meter long," it is highly debatable what I mean by that. But I presumably mean the distance between these two points is one meter and that the points belong to the table.

If I say, for example, "the table is one meter long," it is highly debatable what I mean by that. But I presumably mean the distance between these two points is one meter and that the points belong to the table.

20 June, 1915

Wir sagten die Mathematik würde ja schon mit Erfolg auf gewöhnliche Sätze angewandt aber die Sätze der Physik handeln durchwegs von anderen Gegenständen als denen unserer gewöhnlichen Sprache! Müssen unsere Sätze so präpariert werden um mathematisch behandelt werden zu können? Offenbar ja! Wenn Quantitäten in Frage kommen so würde z.B. ein Ausdruck wie „die Länge dieses Tisches” nicht genügen. Diese Länge müßte definiert werden etwa als Abstand zweier Flächen etc. etc.

We said that mathematics has already been applied with success to ordinary propositions, but propositions in physics consistently deal with objects other than those of our ordinary language. Must our propositions undergo such preparation so that they can be handled mathematically? Yes, clearly! When quantities are in question then an expression like, e.g., "the length of this table" would not be enough. This length would have to be defined, say, as the distance between two surfaces etc. etc.

We said that mathematics has already been applied with success to ordinary propositions, but propositions in physics consistently deal with objects other than those of our ordinary language. Must our propositions undergo such preparation so that they can be handled mathematically? Yes, clearly! When quantities are in question then an expression like, e.g., "the length of this table" would not be enough. This length would have to be defined, say, as the distance between two surfaces etc. etc.

20 June, 1915

Ja, die mathematischen Wissenschaften / unterscheiden sich von den nicht mathematischen dadurch daß jene von Dingen handeln von welchen die gewöhnliche Sprache nicht spricht während diese von den allgemein bekannten Dingen redet. ——

Yes, the mathematical sciences differ from the non-mathematical ones in that the former treat of things of which ordinary language does not speak, while the latter talk of things that are generally familiar. ——

Yes, the mathematical sciences differ from the non-mathematical ones in that the former treat of things of which ordinary language does not speak, while the latter talk of things that are generally familiar. ——

20 June, 1915

Ja, darum handelt es sich: Können wir mit Recht die Logik wie sie etwa in den „Principia Mathematica” steht ohne weiteres auf die gebräuchlichen Sätze anwenden?

Yes, this is the question: Can we legitimately apply logic as written down, say in Principia Mathematica, to ordinary propositions without further ado?

Yes, this is the question: Can we legitimately apply logic as written down, say in Principia Mathematica, to ordinary propositions without further ado?

20 June, 1915

Natürlich dürfen wir nicht außer acht lassen was in unseren Sätzen durch Endungen, Vorsilben Umlaute etc. etc. ausgedrückt ist.

Of course, we shouldn’t disregard what is expressed in our propositions by means of endings, prefixes, suffixes, etc., etc.

Of course, we shouldn’t disregard what is expressed in our propositions by means of endings, prefixes, suffixes, etc., etc.

20 June, 1915

Aber wir wenden ja die Mathematik, und zwar mit bestem Erfolge, auf die gewöhnlichen Sätze nämlich auf die der Physik an!!

But we do apply mathematics, and moreover with the utmost effectiveness, to ordinary propositions, namely to those of physics.

But we do apply mathematics, and moreover with the utmost effectiveness, to ordinary propositions, namely to those of physics.

20 June, 1915

Aber wie merkwürdig: in den bekannten Lehrsätzen der mathematischen Physik erscheinen weder Dinge noch Funktionen noch Relationen noch sonst logische Gegenstandsformen!! Statt der Dinge haben wir da Zahlen und die Funktionen & Relationen sind durchweg rein mathematisch!!

But it is remarkable: in the well-known theorems of mathematical physics there appear neither things nor functions nor relations nor any other logical forms of object! Instead of things what we have here are numbers, and the functions and relations are purely mathematical throughout!

But it is remarkable: in the well-known theorems of mathematical physics there appear neither things nor functions nor relations nor any other logical forms of object! Instead of things what we have here are numbers, and the functions and relations are purely mathematical throughout!

TLP 2·0124

If all objects are given, then all possible states of affairs are given at the same time.

If all objects are given, then thereby all possible elementary facts are also given.

20 June, 1915

Aber es ist doch Tatsache daß diese Sätze auf die solide Wirklichkeit angewandt werden.

But surely it is a fact that these propositions are applied to solid reality.

But surely it is a fact that these propositions are applied to solid reality.

If all objects are given, then thereby all possible elementary facts are also given.

20 June, 1915

Die Variablen in jenen Lehrsätzen stehen durchaus nicht – wie man häufig sagt – für Längen, Gewichte, Zeiträume etc. sondern sie stehen einfach für Zahlen und weiter nichts.

The variables in those theorems definitely do not—as it is often said—stand for lengths, weights, periods of time etc. Rather, they simply stand for numbers and nothing else.

The variables in those theorems definitely do not—as it is often said—stand for lengths, weights, periods of time etc. Rather, they simply stand for numbers and nothing else.

20 June, 1915

Wenn ich nun aber die Zahlen anwenden will dann komme ich zu den Relationen den Dingen etc. etc. Ich sage z.B.: diese Länge ist 5 Meter und spreche da von Relationen und Dingen, und zwar in dem ganz gewöhnlichen Sinne.

However, if I now want to apply numbers then I come to relations, things etc. etc.. I say, for instance “This length is 5 meters”, and here I am talking of relations and things, and in the completely ordinary sense at that.

However, if I now want to apply numbers then I come to relations, things etc. etc.. I say, for instance “This length is 5 meters”, and here I am talking of relations and things, and in the completely ordinary sense at that.

20 June, 1915

Wir kommen hier zur Frage nach der Bedeutung der Variablen in den physikalischen Sätzen. Diese sind ja keine Tautologien.

Here we come to the question about the meaning of variables in propositions of physics. These are, after all, no tautologies.

Here we come to the question about the meaning of variables in propositions of physics. These are, after all, no tautologies.

TLP 2·0124

If all objects are given, then all possible states of affairs are given at the same time.

If all objects are given, then thereby all possible elementary facts are also given.

20 June, 1915

Der physikalische Satz ohne Angabe seiner Anwendung ist offenbar sinnlos. Was hätte es für einen Sinn zu sagen: „k = m ∙ p”?

Also handelt der vervollständigte physikalische Satz doch von den Dingen Relationen u.s.w. (Was eigentlich zu erwarten war.)

A proposition of physics is obviously senseless if its application is not specified. What sort of sense would it have to say: "k = m ∙ p"?

So the complete physical proposition does deal with things, relations, and so on, after all. (Which was to be expected, for that matter.)

A proposition of physics is obviously senseless if its application is not specified. What sort of sense would it have to say: "k = m ∙ p"?

So the complete physical proposition does deal with things, relations, and so on, after all. (Which was to be expected, for that matter.)

If all objects are given, then thereby all possible elementary facts are also given.

20 June, 1915

Es liegt nun alles darin daß ich die Zahlen auf die gewöhnlichen Dinge etc. anwende, was wieder nicht mehr sagt als daß in unseren ganz gewöhnlichen Sätzen Zahlen vorkommen.

Now everything turns on my applying numbers to ordinary things etc., which again says no more than that numbers occur in our quite ordinary sentences.

Now everything turns on my applying numbers to ordinary things etc., which again says no more than that numbers occur in our quite ordinary sentences.

20 June, 1915

Die Schwierigkeit ist eigentlich die: daß wenn wir auch einen ganz bestimmten Sinn ausdrücken wollen die Möglichkeit / besteht daß wir dieses Ziel verfehlen. Es scheint also sozusagen daß wir keine Garantie haben daß unser Satz wirklich ein Bild der Wirklichkeit ist.

Actually, the difficulty is this: even if we want to express a completely definite sense, we may miss this goal. So it seems, so to speak, that we have no guarantee that our proposition is really a picture of reality.

Actually, the difficulty is this: even if we want to express a completely definite sense, we may miss this goal. So it seems, so to speak, that we have no guarantee that our proposition is really a picture of reality.

20 June, 1915

Die Zerlegung der Körper in materielle Punkte wie wir sie in der Physik haben ist weiter nichts als die Analyse in einfache Bestandteile.

The decomposition of bodies into material points, as we have it in physics, is nothing more than an analysis into simple constituents.

The decomposition of bodies into material points, as we have it in physics, is nothing more than an analysis into simple constituents.

20 June, 1915

Aber sollte es möglich sein daß die von uns gewöhnlich gebrauchten Sätze gleichsam nur einen unvollkommenen Sinn haben (ganz abgesehen von ihrer Wahr- oder Falschheit) und die physikalischen Sätze sich sozusagen / dem Stadium nähern wo ein Satz wirklich einen vollkommenen Sinn hat??

But could it be possible that sentences in ordinary use have, as it were, only an incomplete sense (not to speak of their truth or falsity) and the propositions of physics are getting closer, so to speak, to the state where a proposition really has a complete sense??

But could it be possible that sentences in ordinary use have, as it were, only an incomplete sense (not to speak of their truth or falsity) and the propositions of physics are getting closer, so to speak, to the state where a proposition really has a complete sense??

20 June, 1915

Wenn ich sage „das Buch liegt auf dem Tisch” hat dies wirklich einen vollkommen klaren Sinn? (Eine höchst bedeutungsvolle Frage!)

Der Sinn muß doch klar sein denn etwas meinen wir doch mit dem Satz und soviel als wir sicher meinen muß doch klar sein.

When I say "The book is lying on the table" does this really have a completely clear sense? (An extremely important question!)

The sense must surely be clear, for we surely mean something by the proposition and as much as we certainly mean must surely be clear.

When I say "The book is lying on the table" does this really have a completely clear sense? (An extremely important question!)

The sense must surely be clear, for we surely mean something by the proposition and as much as we certainly mean must surely be clear.

20 June, 1915

Wenn der Satz „das Buch liegt auf dem Tisch” einen klaren Sinn hat, dann muß ich, was immer auch der Fall ist, sagen können ob der Satz wahr oder falsch ist. Es könnten aber sehr wohl Fälle eintreten in welchen ich nicht ohne / Weiteres sagen könnte ob das Buch noch „auf dem Tisch liegend” zu nennen ist. Also?

If the proposition "The book is on the table" has a clear sense, then I must, whatever is the case, be able to say whether the proposition is true or false. However, there could very well be cases in which I couldn’t say without further ado whether the book is still to be called "lying on the table". Well—?

If the proposition "The book is on the table" has a clear sense, then I must, whatever is the case, be able to say whether the proposition is true or false. However, there could very well be cases in which I couldn’t say without further ado whether the book is still to be called "lying on the table". Well—?

20 June, 1915

Ist also etwa der Fall der daß ich zwar genau weiß was ich sagen will aber dann im Ausdrucke Fehler mache?

So is this a case in which I know exactly what I want to say, but then express it mistakenly?

So is this a case in which I know exactly what I want to say, but then express it mistakenly?

20 June, 1915

Oder kann diese Unsicherheit auch noch in den Satz eingeschlossen werden?

Or can this uncertainty be included in the proposition as well?

Or can this uncertainty be included in the proposition as well?

20 June, 1915

Aber es kann auch sein daß der Satz „das Buch liegt auf dem Tisch” meinen Sinn zwar vollkommen darstellt daß ich aber die Worte z.B. darauf-liegen hier in einer speziellen Bedeutung gebrauche / und es anderswo eine andere Bedeutung hat. Ich meine mit dem Verbum etwa die ganz spezielle Relation die das Buch jetzt wirklich zu dem Tisch hat.

But it could also be that the proposition "The book is lying on the table" represents my sense perfectly, but I use the words, e.g., “lying on” with a special meaning here, and that they have another meaning elsewhere. What I mean by the verb is, say, a quite special relation which the book now actually has to the table.

But it could also be that the proposition "The book is lying on the table" represents my sense perfectly, but I use the words, e.g., “lying on” with a special meaning here, and that they have another meaning elsewhere. What I mean by the verb is, say, a quite special relation which the book now actually has to the table.

20 June, 1915

Sind also im Grunde die Sätze der Physik und die Sätze des gewöhnlichen Lebens gleich scharf und besteht der Unterschied nur in der konsequenteren Anwendung der Zeichen in der Sprache der Wissenschaft??

Then are the propositions of physics and the propositions of ordinary life in principle equally sharp, and does the difference consist only in the more consistent application of signs in the language of science??

Then are the propositions of physics and the propositions of ordinary life in principle equally sharp, and does the difference consist only in the more consistent application of signs in the language of science??

20 June, 1915

Kann man davon reden oder nicht daß ein Satz einen mehr oder weniger scharfen Sinn hat??

Is it or isn’t it possible to talk of a proposition's having a more or less sharp sense??

Is it or isn’t it possible to talk of a proposition's having a more or less sharp sense??

20 June, 1915

Es scheint klar daß das was wir meinen immer „scharf” sein muß.

Unser Ausdruck dessen was wir meinen kann wieder nur richtig oder falsch sein. Und nun können noch die Worte konsequent oder inkonsequent angewendet sein. Eine andere Möglichkeit scheint es nicht zu geben.

It seems clear that what we mean must always be "sharp".

Once more, our expression of what we mean can only be right or wrong. And now the words can, in addition be applied consistently or inconsistently. There doesn’t seem to be any other possibility.

It seems clear that what we mean must always be "sharp".

Once more, our expression of what we mean can only be right or wrong. And now the words can, in addition be applied consistently or inconsistently. There doesn’t seem to be any other possibility.

20 June, 1915

Wenn ich z.B. sage „der Tisch ist einen Meter lang” so ist es höchst fraglich was ich damit meine. Aber ich meine wohl der Abstand dieser zwei Punkte ist ein Meter und die Punkte gehören zum Tisch.

If I say, for example, "the table is one meter long," it is highly debatable what I mean by that. But I presumably mean the distance between these two points is one meter and that the points belong to the table.

If I say, for example, "the table is one meter long," it is highly debatable what I mean by that. But I presumably mean the distance between these two points is one meter and that the points belong to the table.

20 June, 1915

Wir sagten die Mathematik würde ja schon mit Erfolg auf gewöhnliche Sätze angewandt aber die Sätze der Physik handeln durchwegs von anderen Gegenständen als denen unserer gewöhnlichen Sprache! Müssen unsere Sätze so präpariert werden um mathematisch behandelt werden zu können? Offenbar ja! Wenn Quantitäten in Frage kommen so würde z.B. ein Ausdruck wie „die Länge dieses Tisches” nicht genügen. Diese Länge müßte definiert werden etwa als Abstand zweier Flächen etc. etc.

We said that mathematics has already been applied with success to ordinary propositions, but propositions in physics consistently deal with objects other than those of our ordinary language. Must our propositions undergo such preparation so that they can be handled mathematically? Yes, clearly! When quantities are in question then an expression like, e.g., "the length of this table" would not be enough. This length would have to be defined, say, as the distance between two surfaces etc. etc.

We said that mathematics has already been applied with success to ordinary propositions, but propositions in physics consistently deal with objects other than those of our ordinary language. Must our propositions undergo such preparation so that they can be handled mathematically? Yes, clearly! When quantities are in question then an expression like, e.g., "the length of this table" would not be enough. This length would have to be defined, say, as the distance between two surfaces etc. etc.

20 June, 1915

Ja, die mathematischen Wissenschaften / unterscheiden sich von den nicht mathematischen dadurch daß jene von Dingen handeln von welchen die gewöhnliche Sprache nicht spricht während diese von den allgemein bekannten Dingen redet. ——

Yes, the mathematical sciences differ from the non-mathematical ones in that the former treat of things of which ordinary language does not speak, while the latter talk of things that are generally familiar. ——

Yes, the mathematical sciences differ from the non-mathematical ones in that the former treat of things of which ordinary language does not speak, while the latter talk of things that are generally familiar. ——

21 June, 1915

Unsere Schwierigkeit war doch die daß wir immer von einfachen Gegenständen sprachen und nicht einen einzigen anzuführen wußten.

Our difficulty was that we were always speaking of simple objects and didn’t know of a single instance.

Our difficulty was that we were always speaking of simple objects and didn’t know of a single instance.

21 June, 1915

Wenn der Punkt im Raume nicht existiert dann existieren auch seine Koordinaten nicht und wenn die Koordinaten existieren dann existiert auch der Punkt.—So ist es in der Logik.

If a point in space doesn’t exist, then its co-ordinates don’t exist either, and if the coordinates exist then the point exists too. —That's how it is in logic.

If a point in space doesn’t exist, then its co-ordinates don’t exist either, and if the coordinates exist then the point exists too. —That's how it is in logic.

21 June, 1915

Das einfache Zeichen ist wesentlich einfach.

Es fungiert als einfacher Gegenstand. (Was heißt das?)

Seine Zusammensetzung wird vollkommen gleichgültig. Sie verschwindet uns aus den Augen.

A simple sign is essentially simple.

It functions as a simple object. (What does that mean?)

Its composition becomes completely indifferent. It disappears from our sight.

A simple sign is essentially simple.

It functions as a simple object. (What does that mean?)

Its composition becomes completely indifferent. It disappears from our sight.

21 June, 1915

Es scheint immer so, als ob es komplexe Gegenstände gäbe die als einfache fungieren, und dann auch wirklich einfache, wie die materiellen Punkte der Physik, etc.

It always looks as if there were complex objects that function as simples, and then also really simple ones, such as the material points of physics, etc.

It always looks as if there were complex objects that function as simples, and then also really simple ones, such as the material points of physics, etc.

TLP 3·24 (3)*

A sentence about a complex stands in an internal relation to a sentence about one of the constituents of the complex.

A complex can be given only by its description, and this will be right or wrong. A sentence that mentions a complex that does not exist will not be nonsensical, but just false.

When an element of a sentence signifies a complex, this can be gleaned from an indeterminateness in the sentences in which it occurs. We know that everything is not yet determined by the sentence. (After all, the notation for generality contains a prototype.)

The condensation of a symbol for a complex into a simple symbol can be expressed by a definition.

A proposition about a complex stands in an internal relation to a proposition about a constituent part.

21 June, 1915

Daß ein Name einen komplexen Gegenstand bezeichnet sieht man aus einer Unbestimmtheit in den Sätzen in welchen er vorkommt, die / eben von der Allgemeinheit solcher Sätze herrührt. Wir wissen durch diesen Satz ist noch nicht alles bestimmt. Die Allgemeinheitsbezeichnung enthält ja ein Urbild.

When a name signifies a complex, this can be seen in an indeterminateness in the propositions in which it occurs. That is due to the generality of such propositions. We know that not everything is already specified by this proposition. After all, the sign for generality contains a prototype. [Cf. 3.24 (3).]

When a name signifies a complex, this can be seen in an indeterminateness in the propositions in which it occurs. That is due to the generality of such propositions. We know that not everything is already specified by this proposition. After all, the sign for generality contains a prototype. [Cf. 3.24 (3).]

A proposition about a complex stands in an internal relation to a proposition about a constituent part.

21 June, 1915

Alle unsichtbaren Massen etc. etc. müssen unter die Allgemeinheitsbezeichnung kommen.

All invisible masses, etc. etc. must fall under the sign for generality.

All invisible masses, etc. etc. must fall under the sign for generality.

21 June, 1915

Wie ist das wenn sich Sätze der Wahrheit nähern?

What is for propositions to get closer to the truth?

What is for propositions to get closer to the truth?

21 June, 1915

Aber die Logik wie sie etwa in den „Principia Mathematica” steht läßt sich ganz gut auf unsere gewöhnlichen Sätze anwenden z.B. aus / „Alle Menschen sind sterblich” und „Sokrates ist ein Mensch” folgt nach dieser Logik „Sokrates ist sterblich” was offenbar richtig ist obwohl ich, ebenso offenbar, nicht weiß welche Struktur das Ding Sokrates oder die Eigenschaft der Sterblichkeit hat. Diese fungieren eben hier als einfache Gegenstände.

But logic as it stands in Principia Mathematica, say, can quite well be applied to our ordinary propositions. For instance, according to this logic, from "All men are mortal" and "Socrates is a man", "Socrates is mortal" follows. This is obviously correct although I, equally obviously, do not know what structure is possessed by the thing Socrates or the property of mortality. Here they just function as simple objects.

But logic as it stands in Principia Mathematica, say, can quite well be applied to our ordinary propositions. For instance, according to this logic, from "All men are mortal" and "Socrates is a man", "Socrates is mortal" follows. This is obviously correct although I, equally obviously, do not know what structure is possessed by the thing Socrates or the property of mortality. Here they just function as simple objects.

TLP 3·24 (4)

A sentence about a complex stands in an internal relation to a sentence about one of the constituents of the complex.

A complex can be given only by its description, and this will be right or wrong. A sentence that mentions a complex that does not exist will not be nonsensical, but just false.

When an element of a sentence signifies a complex, this can be gleaned from an indeterminateness in the sentences in which it occurs. We know that everything is not yet determined by the sentence. (After all, the notation for generality contains a prototype.)

The condensation of a symbol for a complex into a simple symbol can be expressed by a definition.

A proposition about a complex stands in an internal relation to a proposition about a constituent part.

21 June, 1915

Offenbar garantiert schon der Umstand der es möglich macht daß gewisse Formen durch eine Definition in einen Namen projiziert werden; dafür daß dieser Name dann auch wie ein wirklicher behandelt werden kann.

Obviously the circumstance that makes it possible for certain forms to be projected by means of a definition into a name guarantees of itself that this name can then also be treated like a real one.

Obviously the circumstance that makes it possible for certain forms to be projected by means of a definition into a name guarantees of itself that this name can then also be treated like a real one.

A proposition about a complex stands in an internal relation to a proposition about a constituent part.

TLP 3·24 (3)*

A sentence about a complex stands in an internal relation to a sentence about one of the constituents of the complex.

A complex can be given only by its description, and this will be right or wrong. A sentence that mentions a complex that does not exist will not be nonsensical, but just false.

When an element of a sentence signifies a complex, this can be gleaned from an indeterminateness in the sentences in which it occurs. We know that everything is not yet determined by the sentence. (After all, the notation for generality contains a prototype.)

The condensation of a symbol for a complex into a simple symbol can be expressed by a definition.

A proposition about a complex stands in an internal relation to a proposition about a constituent part.

21 June, 1915

Es ist ja dem klar Sehenden offenbar daß ein Satz wie „Die Uhr liegt auf dem Tisch” eine Menge Unbestimmtheit enthält trotzdem seine Form äußerlich vollkommen klar und einfach erscheint. Wir sehen also daß diese Einfachheit nur konstruiert ist.

To anyone that sees clearly, it is obvious that a proposition like "The watch is lying on the table" contains a multitude of indeterminateness in spite of its form outwardly appearing to be perfectly clear and simple. So we see that this simplicity is only a construal.

To anyone that sees clearly, it is obvious that a proposition like "The watch is lying on the table" contains a multitude of indeterminateness in spite of its form outwardly appearing to be perfectly clear and simple. So we see that this simplicity is only a construal.

A proposition about a complex stands in an internal relation to a proposition about a constituent part.

21 June, 1915

Unsere Schwierigkeit war doch die daß wir immer von einfachen Gegenständen sprachen und nicht einen einzigen anzuführen wußten.

Our difficulty was that we were always speaking of simple objects and didn’t know of a single instance.

Our difficulty was that we were always speaking of simple objects and didn’t know of a single instance.

21 June, 1915

Wenn der Punkt im Raume nicht existiert dann existieren auch seine Koordinaten nicht und wenn die Koordinaten existieren dann existiert auch der Punkt.—So ist es in der Logik.

If a point in space doesn’t exist, then its co-ordinates don’t exist either, and if the coordinates exist then the point exists too. —That's how it is in logic.

If a point in space doesn’t exist, then its co-ordinates don’t exist either, and if the coordinates exist then the point exists too. —That's how it is in logic.

21 June, 1915

Das einfache Zeichen ist wesentlich einfach.

Es fungiert als einfacher Gegenstand. (Was heißt das?)

Seine Zusammensetzung wird vollkommen gleichgültig. Sie verschwindet uns aus den Augen.

A simple sign is essentially simple.

It functions as a simple object. (What does that mean?)

Its composition becomes completely indifferent. It disappears from our sight.

A simple sign is essentially simple.

It functions as a simple object. (What does that mean?)

Its composition becomes completely indifferent. It disappears from our sight.

21 June, 1915

Es scheint immer so, als ob es komplexe Gegenstände gäbe die als einfache fungieren, und dann auch wirklich einfache, wie die materiellen Punkte der Physik, etc.

It always looks as if there were complex objects that function as simples, and then also really simple ones, such as the material points of physics, etc.

It always looks as if there were complex objects that function as simples, and then also really simple ones, such as the material points of physics, etc.

TLP 3·24 (3)*

A sentence about a complex stands in an internal relation to a sentence about one of the constituents of the complex.

A complex can be given only by its description, and this will be right or wrong. A sentence that mentions a complex that does not exist will not be nonsensical, but just false.

When an element of a sentence signifies a complex, this can be gleaned from an indeterminateness in the sentences in which it occurs. We know that everything is not yet determined by the sentence. (After all, the notation for generality contains a prototype.)

The condensation of a symbol for a complex into a simple symbol can be expressed by a definition.

A proposition about a complex stands in an internal relation to a proposition about a constituent part.

21 June, 1915

Daß ein Name einen komplexen Gegenstand bezeichnet sieht man aus einer Unbestimmtheit in den Sätzen in welchen er vorkommt, die / eben von der Allgemeinheit solcher Sätze herrührt. Wir wissen durch diesen Satz ist noch nicht alles bestimmt. Die Allgemeinheitsbezeichnung enthält ja ein Urbild.

When a name signifies a complex, this can be seen in an indeterminateness in the propositions in which it occurs. That is due to the generality of such propositions. We know that not everything is already specified by this proposition. After all, the sign for generality contains a prototype. [Cf. 3.24 (3).]

When a name signifies a complex, this can be seen in an indeterminateness in the propositions in which it occurs. That is due to the generality of such propositions. We know that not everything is already specified by this proposition. After all, the sign for generality contains a prototype. [Cf. 3.24 (3).]

A proposition about a complex stands in an internal relation to a proposition about a constituent part.

21 June, 1915

Alle unsichtbaren Massen etc. etc. müssen unter die Allgemeinheitsbezeichnung kommen.

All invisible masses, etc. etc. must fall under the sign for generality.

All invisible masses, etc. etc. must fall under the sign for generality.

21 June, 1915

Wie ist das wenn sich Sätze der Wahrheit nähern?

What is for propositions to get closer to the truth?

What is for propositions to get closer to the truth?

21 June, 1915

Aber die Logik wie sie etwa in den „Principia Mathematica” steht läßt sich ganz gut auf unsere gewöhnlichen Sätze anwenden z.B. aus / „Alle Menschen sind sterblich” und „Sokrates ist ein Mensch” folgt nach dieser Logik „Sokrates ist sterblich” was offenbar richtig ist obwohl ich, ebenso offenbar, nicht weiß welche Struktur das Ding Sokrates oder die Eigenschaft der Sterblichkeit hat. Diese fungieren eben hier als einfache Gegenstände.

But logic as it stands in Principia Mathematica, say, can quite well be applied to our ordinary propositions. For instance, according to this logic, from "All men are mortal" and "Socrates is a man", "Socrates is mortal" follows. This is obviously correct although I, equally obviously, do not know what structure is possessed by the thing Socrates or the property of mortality. Here they just function as simple objects.

But logic as it stands in Principia Mathematica, say, can quite well be applied to our ordinary propositions. For instance, according to this logic, from "All men are mortal" and "Socrates is a man", "Socrates is mortal" follows. This is obviously correct although I, equally obviously, do not know what structure is possessed by the thing Socrates or the property of mortality. Here they just function as simple objects.

TLP 3·24 (4)

A sentence about a complex stands in an internal relation to a sentence about one of the constituents of the complex.

A complex can be given only by its description, and this will be right or wrong. A sentence that mentions a complex that does not exist will not be nonsensical, but just false.

When an element of a sentence signifies a complex, this can be gleaned from an indeterminateness in the sentences in which it occurs. We know that everything is not yet determined by the sentence. (After all, the notation for generality contains a prototype.)

The condensation of a symbol for a complex into a simple symbol can be expressed by a definition.

A proposition about a complex stands in an internal relation to a proposition about a constituent part.

21 June, 1915

Offenbar garantiert schon der Umstand der es möglich macht daß gewisse Formen durch eine Definition in einen Namen projiziert werden; dafür daß dieser Name dann auch wie ein wirklicher behandelt werden kann.

Obviously the circumstance that makes it possible for certain forms to be projected by means of a definition into a name guarantees of itself that this name can then also be treated like a real one.

Obviously the circumstance that makes it possible for certain forms to be projected by means of a definition into a name guarantees of itself that this name can then also be treated like a real one.

A proposition about a complex stands in an internal relation to a proposition about a constituent part.

TLP 3·24 (3)*

A sentence about a complex stands in an internal relation to a sentence about one of the constituents of the complex.

A complex can be given only by its description, and this will be right or wrong. A sentence that mentions a complex that does not exist will not be nonsensical, but just false.

When an element of a sentence signifies a complex, this can be gleaned from an indeterminateness in the sentences in which it occurs. We know that everything is not yet determined by the sentence. (After all, the notation for generality contains a prototype.)

The condensation of a symbol for a complex into a simple symbol can be expressed by a definition.

A proposition about a complex stands in an internal relation to a proposition about a constituent part.

21 June, 1915

Es ist ja dem klar Sehenden offenbar daß ein Satz wie „Die Uhr liegt auf dem Tisch” eine Menge Unbestimmtheit enthält trotzdem seine Form äußerlich vollkommen klar und einfach erscheint. Wir sehen also daß diese Einfachheit nur konstruiert ist.

To anyone that sees clearly, it is obvious that a proposition like "The watch is lying on the table" contains a multitude of indeterminateness in spite of its form outwardly appearing to be perfectly clear and simple. So we see that this simplicity is only a construal.

To anyone that sees clearly, it is obvious that a proposition like "The watch is lying on the table" contains a multitude of indeterminateness in spite of its form outwardly appearing to be perfectly clear and simple. So we see that this simplicity is only a construal.

A proposition about a complex stands in an internal relation to a proposition about a constituent part.

22 June, 1915

Arbeite sehr viel! Trotz der widerlichsten Umstände!

Work a great deal! Despite the most disgusting circumstances!

22 June, 1915

Es ist also auch dem unbefangenen Geist klar daß der Sinn des Satzes „die Uhr liegt auf dem Tisch” komplizierter ist als der Satz selbst.

Then it is also clear to the unprejudiced mind that the sense of the proposition "The watch is lying on the table" is more complicated than the proposition itself.

Then it is also clear to the unprejudiced mind that the sense of the proposition "The watch is lying on the table" is more complicated than the proposition itself.

TLP 4·002 (5)**

Human beings have the capacity to construct languages by which every sense can be expressed, without having an inkling of how and what each word means. – Just as we speak without knowing how the individual sounds are produced.

Everyday language is a part of the human organism and no less complicated than it.

It is not humanly possible to gather the logic of language from it in a direct way.

Language disguises thought. So much so, that from the outer form of the clothes one cannot infer the form of the thought beneath, because the outer form of the clothes is not designed to reveal the form of the body, but for entirely different purposes.

The tacit conventions involved in understanding everyday language are extremely complicated.

Human beings have the capacity to construct languages in which every sense can be expressed, without having any idea how and what each word means, just as we speak without knowing how the individual sounds are produced.

22 June, 1915

Die Abmachungen unserer Sprache sind außerordentlich kompliziert. Es wird enorm viel zu jedem Satz dazugedacht was / nicht gesagt wird. (Diese Abmachungen sind ganz wie die „Conventions” Whiteheads. Sie sind wohl Definitionen mit einer gewissen Allgemeinheit der Form.)

The conventions of our language are extraordinarily complicated. There is a great deal added in thought to each proposition that is not said. (These arrangements are quite like Whitehead's "Conventions". They are surely definitions with a certain generality of form).

The conventions of our language are extraordinarily complicated. There is a great deal added in thought to each proposition that is not said. (These arrangements are quite like Whitehead's "Conventions". They are surely definitions with a certain generality of form).

Human beings have the capacity to construct languages in which every sense can be expressed, without having any idea how and what each word means, just as we speak without knowing how the individual sounds are produced.

22 June, 1915

Ich will nur die Vagheit der gewöhnlichen Sätze rechtfertigen, denn sie läßt sich rechtfertigen.

I want only to justify the vagueness of ordinary sentences, for it can be justified.

I want only to justify the vagueness of ordinary sentences, for it can be justified.

22 June, 1915

Es ist klar: Ich weiß was ich mit dem vagen Satz meine. Nun versteht es aber ein Anderer nicht und sagt: „ja aber wenn du das meinst, hättest du – das und das – dazu setzen müssen”; und nun wird es noch einer nicht verstehen und den Satz noch ausführlicher verlangen. Ich werde dann antworten: Ja das versteht sich doch von selbst.

Sage ich jemand „die Uhr liegt auf dem Tisch” und nun sagt er „ja aber wenn die Uhr so läge würdest Du da / auch noch sagen „sie liegt auf dem Tisch””. Und ich würde unsicher. Das zeigt, daß ich nicht wüßte was ich mit „liegen” im allgemeinen meinte. Wenn man mich so in die Enge triebe um mir zu zeigen daß ich nicht wisse was ich meine, würde ich sagen: „Ich weiß was ich meine; ich meine eben das” und würde dabei etwa auf den betreffenden Komplex mit dem Finger zeigen. Und in diesem Komplex habe ich nun tatsächlich die zwei Gegenstände in einer Relation. – Das heißt aber wirklich nur: Die Tatsache läßt sich irgendwie auch durch diese Form abbilden.

It’s clear: I know what I mean by a vague proposition. But now someone else doesn’t understand it and says: "Yes, but if you mean that, you should have added such and such"; and now another person won’t understand it and will demand a yet more detailed proposition. I shall then reply: Now that obviously goes without saying.

I tell someone "The watch is lying on the table" and now he says "Yes, but if the watch were lying like that, would you still say ‘it is lying on the table’?" And I would become uncertain. This shows that I didn’t know what I meant by "lying" in general. If someone cornered me in this way to show me that I didn’t know what I meant, I would say: "I know what I mean; I mean just this" and would point to the complex in question with my finger. And in this complex I do actually have the two objects in a relation. – But all this really means is: The fact can somehow be depicted by using this form too.

It’s clear: I know what I mean by a vague proposition. But now someone else doesn’t understand it and says: "Yes, but if you mean that, you should have added such and such"; and now another person won’t understand it and will demand a yet more detailed proposition. I shall then reply: Now that obviously goes without saying.

I tell someone "The watch is lying on the table" and now he says "Yes, but if the watch were lying like that, would you still say ‘it is lying on the table’?" And I would become uncertain. This shows that I didn’t know what I meant by "lying" in general. If someone cornered me in this way to show me that I didn’t know what I meant, I would say: "I know what I mean; I mean just this" and would point to the complex in question with my finger. And in this complex I do actually have the two objects in a relation. – But all this really means is: The fact can somehow be depicted by using this form too.

22 June, 1915

Wenn ich dies nun tue und die Gegenstände mit Namen bezeichne, werden sie dadurch einfach?

Now if I do this and refer to the objects by means of names, does that make them simple?

Now if I do this and refer to the objects by means of names, does that make them simple?

22 June, 1915

Dieser Gegenstand ist für mich einfach!

This object is simple for me!

This object is simple for me!

22 June, 1915

Nenne ich z.B. irgend einen Stab „A” eine Kugel „B” so kann ich von A sagen es lehnt an der Wand aber nicht von B. Hier macht sich die interne Natur von A und B bemerkbar.

If, for instance, I call some rod "A", and a ball "B", then I can say that A is leaning against the wall, but not B. Here the internal nature of A and B makes itself felt.

If, for instance, I call some rod "A", and a ball "B", then I can say that A is leaning against the wall, but not B. Here the internal nature of A and B makes itself felt.

22 June, 1915

Wenn ein Name einen Gegenstand bezeichnet so steht er damit in einer Beziehung zu ihm die ganz von der logischen Art des Gegenstandes bedingt ist und diese wieder charakterisiert.

If a name refers to an object then it stands in a relationship to it which is completely determined by the logical kind of the object and which characterizes that logical kind.

If a name refers to an object then it stands in a relationship to it which is completely determined by the logical kind of the object and which characterizes that logical kind.

22 June, 1915

Und das ist klar daß der Gegenstand eine bestimmte logische Art haben muß er ist so zusammengesetzt oder so einfach als er eben ist.

And it is clear that the object must be of a particular logical kind, it is just as complex, or as simple, as it is.

And it is clear that the object must be of a particular logical kind, it is just as complex, or as simple, as it is.

22 June, 1915

„Die Uhr sitzt auf dem Tisch” ist sinnlos!

"The watch is sitting on the table" is senseless!

"The watch is sitting on the table" is senseless!

22 June, 1915

Nur der zusammengesetzte Teil des Satzes kann wahr oder falsch / sein.

Only the composite part of the proposition can be true or false.

Only the composite part of the proposition can be true or false.

TLP 3·24 (4)

A sentence about a complex stands in an internal relation to a sentence about one of the constituents of the complex.

A complex can be given only by its description, and this will be right or wrong. A sentence that mentions a complex that does not exist will not be nonsensical, but just false.

When an element of a sentence signifies a complex, this can be gleaned from an indeterminateness in the sentences in which it occurs. We know that everything is not yet determined by the sentence. (After all, the notation for generality contains a prototype.)

The condensation of a symbol for a complex into a simple symbol can be expressed by a definition.

A proposition about a complex stands in an internal relation to a proposition about a constituent part.

22 June, 1915

Der Name faßt seine ganze komplexe Bedeutung in Eins zusammen.

The name condenses its whole complex meaning into one.

The name condenses its whole complex meaning into one.

A proposition about a complex stands in an internal relation to a proposition about a constituent part.

22 June, 1915

Es ist also auch dem unbefangenen Geist klar daß der Sinn des Satzes „die Uhr liegt auf dem Tisch” komplizierter ist als der Satz selbst.

Then it is also clear to the unprejudiced mind that the sense of the proposition "The watch is lying on the table" is more complicated than the proposition itself.

Then it is also clear to the unprejudiced mind that the sense of the proposition "The watch is lying on the table" is more complicated than the proposition itself.

TLP 4·002 (5)**

Human beings have the capacity to construct languages by which every sense can be expressed, without having an inkling of how and what each word means. – Just as we speak without knowing how the individual sounds are produced.

Everyday language is a part of the human organism and no less complicated than it.

It is not humanly possible to gather the logic of language from it in a direct way.

Language disguises thought. So much so, that from the outer form of the clothes one cannot infer the form of the thought beneath, because the outer form of the clothes is not designed to reveal the form of the body, but for entirely different purposes.

The tacit conventions involved in understanding everyday language are extremely complicated.

Human beings have the capacity to construct languages in which every sense can be expressed, without having any idea how and what each word means, just as we speak without knowing how the individual sounds are produced.

22 June, 1915

Die Abmachungen unserer Sprache sind außerordentlich kompliziert. Es wird enorm viel zu jedem Satz dazugedacht was / nicht gesagt wird. (Diese Abmachungen sind ganz wie die „Conventions” Whiteheads. Sie sind wohl Definitionen mit einer gewissen Allgemeinheit der Form.)

The conventions of our language are extraordinarily complicated. There is a great deal added in thought to each proposition that is not said. (These arrangements are quite like Whitehead's "Conventions". They are surely definitions with a certain generality of form).

The conventions of our language are extraordinarily complicated. There is a great deal added in thought to each proposition that is not said. (These arrangements are quite like Whitehead's "Conventions". They are surely definitions with a certain generality of form).

Human beings have the capacity to construct languages in which every sense can be expressed, without having any idea how and what each word means, just as we speak without knowing how the individual sounds are produced.

22 June, 1915

Ich will nur die Vagheit der gewöhnlichen Sätze rechtfertigen, denn sie läßt sich rechtfertigen.

I want only to justify the vagueness of ordinary sentences, for it can be justified.

I want only to justify the vagueness of ordinary sentences, for it can be justified.

22 June, 1915

Es ist klar: Ich weiß was ich mit dem vagen Satz meine. Nun versteht es aber ein Anderer nicht und sagt: „ja aber wenn du das meinst, hättest du – das und das – dazu setzen müssen”; und nun wird es noch einer nicht verstehen und den Satz noch ausführlicher verlangen. Ich werde dann antworten: Ja das versteht sich doch von selbst.

Sage ich jemand „die Uhr liegt auf dem Tisch” und nun sagt er „ja aber wenn die Uhr so läge würdest Du da / auch noch sagen „sie liegt auf dem Tisch””. Und ich würde unsicher. Das zeigt, daß ich nicht wüßte was ich mit „liegen” im allgemeinen meinte. Wenn man mich so in die Enge triebe um mir zu zeigen daß ich nicht wisse was ich meine, würde ich sagen: „Ich weiß was ich meine; ich meine eben das” und würde dabei etwa auf den betreffenden Komplex mit dem Finger zeigen. Und in diesem Komplex habe ich nun tatsächlich die zwei Gegenstände in einer Relation. – Das heißt aber wirklich nur: Die Tatsache läßt sich irgendwie auch durch diese Form abbilden.

It’s clear: I know what I mean by a vague proposition. But now someone else doesn’t understand it and says: "Yes, but if you mean that, you should have added such and such"; and now another person won’t understand it and will demand a yet more detailed proposition. I shall then reply: Now that obviously goes without saying.

I tell someone "The watch is lying on the table" and now he says "Yes, but if the watch were lying like that, would you still say ‘it is lying on the table’?" And I would become uncertain. This shows that I didn’t know what I meant by "lying" in general. If someone cornered me in this way to show me that I didn’t know what I meant, I would say: "I know what I mean; I mean just this" and would point to the complex in question with my finger. And in this complex I do actually have the two objects in a relation. – But all this really means is: The fact can somehow be depicted by using this form too.

It’s clear: I know what I mean by a vague proposition. But now someone else doesn’t understand it and says: "Yes, but if you mean that, you should have added such and such"; and now another person won’t understand it and will demand a yet more detailed proposition. I shall then reply: Now that obviously goes without saying.

I tell someone "The watch is lying on the table" and now he says "Yes, but if the watch were lying like that, would you still say ‘it is lying on the table’?" And I would become uncertain. This shows that I didn’t know what I meant by "lying" in general. If someone cornered me in this way to show me that I didn’t know what I meant, I would say: "I know what I mean; I mean just this" and would point to the complex in question with my finger. And in this complex I do actually have the two objects in a relation. – But all this really means is: The fact can somehow be depicted by using this form too.

22 June, 1915

Wenn ich dies nun tue und die Gegenstände mit Namen bezeichne, werden sie dadurch einfach?

Now if I do this and refer to the objects by means of names, does that make them simple?

Now if I do this and refer to the objects by means of names, does that make them simple?

22 June, 1915

Dieser Gegenstand ist für mich einfach!

This object is simple for me!

This object is simple for me!

22 June, 1915

Nenne ich z.B. irgend einen Stab „A” eine Kugel „B” so kann ich von A sagen es lehnt an der Wand aber nicht von B. Hier macht sich die interne Natur von A und B bemerkbar.

If, for instance, I call some rod "A", and a ball "B", then I can say that A is leaning against the wall, but not B. Here the internal nature of A and B makes itself felt.

If, for instance, I call some rod "A", and a ball "B", then I can say that A is leaning against the wall, but not B. Here the internal nature of A and B makes itself felt.

22 June, 1915

Wenn ein Name einen Gegenstand bezeichnet so steht er damit in einer Beziehung zu ihm die ganz von der logischen Art des Gegenstandes bedingt ist und diese wieder charakterisiert.

If a name refers to an object then it stands in a relationship to it which is completely determined by the logical kind of the object and which characterizes that logical kind.

If a name refers to an object then it stands in a relationship to it which is completely determined by the logical kind of the object and which characterizes that logical kind.

22 June, 1915

Und das ist klar daß der Gegenstand eine bestimmte logische Art haben muß er ist so zusammengesetzt oder so einfach als er eben ist.

And it is clear that the object must be of a particular logical kind, it is just as complex, or as simple, as it is.

And it is clear that the object must be of a particular logical kind, it is just as complex, or as simple, as it is.

22 June, 1915

„Die Uhr sitzt auf dem Tisch” ist sinnlos!

"The watch is sitting on the table" is senseless!

"The watch is sitting on the table" is senseless!

22 June, 1915

Nur der zusammengesetzte Teil des Satzes kann wahr oder falsch / sein.

Only the composite part of the proposition can be true or false.

Only the composite part of the proposition can be true or false.

TLP 3·24 (4)

A sentence about a complex stands in an internal relation to a sentence about one of the constituents of the complex.

A complex can be given only by its description, and this will be right or wrong. A sentence that mentions a complex that does not exist will not be nonsensical, but just false.

When an element of a sentence signifies a complex, this can be gleaned from an indeterminateness in the sentences in which it occurs. We know that everything is not yet determined by the sentence. (After all, the notation for generality contains a prototype.)

The condensation of a symbol for a complex into a simple symbol can be expressed by a definition.

A proposition about a complex stands in an internal relation to a proposition about a constituent part.

22 June, 1915

Der Name faßt seine ganze komplexe Bedeutung in Eins zusammen.

The name condenses its whole complex meaning into one.

The name condenses its whole complex meaning into one.

A proposition about a complex stands in an internal relation to a proposition about a constituent part.

29 March, 1916

Viel Ungewohntes zu tun gezwungen. Ich brauche große Kraft das auszuhalten. Oft bin ich der Verzweiflung nahe. Ich habe schon seit mehr als einer Woche nichts mehr gearbeitet. Ich habe keine Zeit! Gott! Aber es ist ja natürlich, denn wenn ich tot sein werde, werde ich auch keine Zeit zum Arbeiten haben. Jetzt Inspektion. Meine Seele schrumpft zusammen. Gott erleuchte mich! Gott erleuchte mich! Gott erleuchte meine Seele.

Forced to do many strange things. I need great strength to bear it. I’m often close to despair. I haven't done any work in over a week. I have no time! God! But it's quite natural, because if I'm going to die, I won't have any time to work either. Inspection now. My soul shrivels up. God enlighten me! God enlighten me! God enlighten my soul.

30 March, 1916

Tu Du dein Bestes! Mehr kannst du nicht tun: und sei heiter. Laß' dir an dir selbst genügen. Denn andere werden dich nicht stützen oder doch nur für kurze Zeit! (Dann wirst du diesen lästig werden). Hilf dir selbst und hilf anderen mit deiner ganzen Kraft. Und dabei sei heiter! Aber wieviel Kraft soll man für sich und wieviel für die anderen brauchen? Schwer ist es gut zu leben!! Aber das gute Leben ist schön. „Aber nicht mein sondern dein Wille geschehe.”

Do your best. You can’t do more. And be cheerful. Let yourself be content with yourself. For others will not support you, or at most only for a short time! (Then you’ll become a burden to them). Help yourself and help others with all your strength. And be cheerful as you do so. But how much strength ought one to use for onerself and how much for others? It's hard to live a good life!! But the good life is beautiful. "Yet Thy will be done, not mine."

2 April, 1916

War krank. Heute noch sehr schwach. Heute sagte mir mein Kommandant er wolle mich ins Hinterland abschieben lassen. Wenn das geschieht werde ich mich umbringen.

Was ill. Still very weak today. Today my commander told me that he wanted to have me posted to the rear. If that happens, I’ll kill myself.

10 April, 1916

Lebe mit Mühe. Bin noch nicht erleuchtet / worden. Sah mich heute im Spiegel, ich bin ganz eingefallen! Ich kann ja auch schon lange nicht mehr arbeiten.

Live with difficulty. Haven't been enlightened yet. Saw myself in the mirror today, I am completely haggard! I haven't been able to work any more for a long time.

13 April, 1916

Taumle und falle noch immer im Dunkel. Bin noch nicht zum Leben erwacht.

Still stumble and fall in the dark. Haven't been born again yet.

15 April, 1916

In 8 Tagen gehen wir in Feuerstellung. Möchte es mir vergönnt sein mein Leben in einer schweren Aufgabe aufs Spiel zu setzen!

In 8 days we’ll go to the firing line. If only I may be allowed to risk my life in some difficult mission!

 TLP 5·556 b 1

There can be no hierarchy of the forms of elementary sentences. We can anticipate only what we ourselves construct.

There can be no hierarchy of the forms of elementary propositions.

15 April, 1916

Nur was wir selbst konstruieren, können wir voraussehen!

We can anticipate only what we ourselves construct. [See 5.556.]

We can anticipate only what we ourselves construct. [See 5.556.]

There can be no hierarchy of the forms of elementary propositions.

15 April, 1916

Aber wo bleibt da der Begriff des einfachen Gegenstandes?

But then where does that leave the concept of a simple object?

But then where does that leave the concept of a simple object?

15 April, 1916

Dieser Begriff kommt hier überhaupt noch nicht in Betracht.

This concept has not so far been taken into consideration here at all.

This concept has not so far been taken into consideration here at all.

15 April, 1916

Wir müssen die einfachen Funktionen darum konstruieren können weil wir jedem Zeichen eine Bedeutung geben können müssen.

We must be able to construct simple functions because we must be able to give each sign a meaning.

We must be able to construct simple functions because we must be able to give each sign a meaning.

15 April, 1916

Denn das einzige Zeichen welches für seine Bedeutung bürgt ist Funktion und Argument.

For the only sign which guarantees its meaning is function and argument.

For the only sign which guarantees its meaning is function and argument.

TLP 5·556 b 1

There can be no hierarchy of the forms of elementary sentences. We can anticipate only what we ourselves construct.

There can be no hierarchy of the forms of elementary propositions.

15 April, 1916

Nur was wir selbst konstruieren, können wir voraussehen!

We can anticipate only what we ourselves construct. [See 5.556.]

We can anticipate only what we ourselves construct. [See 5.556.]

There can be no hierarchy of the forms of elementary propositions.

15 April, 1916

Aber wo bleibt da der Begriff des einfachen Gegenstandes?

But then where does that leave the concept of a simple object?

But then where does that leave the concept of a simple object?

15 April, 1916

Dieser Begriff kommt hier überhaupt noch nicht in Betracht.

This concept has not so far been taken into consideration here at all.

This concept has not so far been taken into consideration here at all.

15 April, 1916

Wir müssen die einfachen Funktionen darum konstruieren können weil wir jedem Zeichen eine Bedeutung geben können müssen.

We must be able to construct simple functions because we must be able to give each sign a meaning.

We must be able to construct simple functions because we must be able to give each sign a meaning.

15 April, 1916

Denn das einzige Zeichen welches für seine Bedeutung bürgt ist Funktion und Argument.

For the only sign which guarantees its meaning is function and argument.

For the only sign which guarantees its meaning is function and argument.

16 April, 1916

φx ∙ ψy

φx ∙ ψy

φx ∙ ψy

16 April, 1916

Jeder einfache Satz läßt sich auf die Form φx bringen.

Any simple proposition can be brought into the form φx.

Any simple proposition can be brought into the form φx.

16 April, 1916

Darum darf man aus dieser Form alle einfachen Sätze zusammenstellen.

That’s why one may compose all simple propositions from this form.

That’s why one may compose all simple propositions from this form.

TLP 4·51*

Suppose I was given all elementary sentences. Then I can simply ask: what sentences I can construct out of them? –These are all the sentences, and this is how they are delimited.

Suppose we were given all simple propositions. Then we can simply ask what propositions I can construct out of them. And these are all the propositions and that is how they are limited.

16 April, 1916

Angenommen mir wären alle einfachen Sätze gegeben: Dann läßt sich einfach fragen welche Sätze kann ich aus ihnen bilden. Und das sind alle Sätze und so sind sie begrenzt.

Suppose I was given all simple propositions. Then I can simply ask what propositions I can construct out of them. And these are all the propositions and this is how they are delimited. [See 4.51.]

Suppose I was given all simple propositions. Then I can simply ask what propositions I can construct out of them. And these are all the propositions and this is how they are delimited. [See 4.51.]

Suppose we were given all simple propositions. Then we can simply ask what propositions I can construct out of them. And these are all the propositions and that is how they are limited.

16 April, 1916

(p) : p = aRx.xRy … zRb

(p) : p = aRx

/ F (x̂(φx) . = . φ ≡ ψ ⊃ψ Fψ

Φ≡ψ .⊃ψ. [F (x̂ (ψx)) = ψ ≡ x ⊃xFx] =

[F(X̂(ψx)) = t ε ẑ (Φz) ≡t xt ⊃x Fx]

Suppose we were given all simple propositions. Then we can simply ask what propositions I can construct out of them. And these are all the propositions and that is how they are limited.

Angenommen mir wären alle einfachen Sätze gegeben: Dann läßt sich einfach fragen welche Sätze kann ich aus ihnen bilden. Und das sind alle Sätze und so sind sie begrenzt.

16 April, 1916
