(p) : p = aRx

/ F (x̂(φx) . = . φ ≡ ψ ⊃ψ Fψ

Φ≡ψ .⊃ψ. [F (x̂ (ψx)) = ψ ≡ x ⊃xFx] =

[F(X̂(ψx)) = t ε ẑ (Φz) ≡t xt ⊃x Fx]

17 April, 1916

Die obige Definition kann in ihrer Allgemeinheit nur eine Schriftzeichenregel sein die mit dem Sinne der Zeichen nichts zu tun hat.

Aber kann es eine solche Regel geben?

The above definition can in its generality only be a rule for a written notation which has nothing to do with the sense of the signs.

But can there be such a rule?

The above definition can in its generality only be a rule for a written notation which has nothing to do with the sense of the signs.

But can there be such a rule?

17 April, 1916

Nur dann ist die Definition möglich wenn sie selbst kein Satz ist.

Dann kann ein Satz nicht von allen Sätzen handeln, wohl aber eine Definition.

The definition is only possible if it is itself not a proposition.

In that case a proposition cannot be about all propositions, while a definition can.

The definition is only possible if it is itself not a proposition.

In that case a proposition cannot be about all propositions, while a definition can.

17 April, 1916

Die obige Definition kann in ihrer Allgemeinheit nur eine Schriftzeichenregel sein die mit dem Sinne der Zeichen nichts zu tun hat.

Aber kann es eine solche Regel geben?

The above definition can in its generality only be a rule for a written notation which has nothing to do with the sense of the signs.

But can there be such a rule?

The above definition can in its generality only be a rule for a written notation which has nothing to do with the sense of the signs.

But can there be such a rule?

17 April, 1916

Nur dann ist die Definition möglich wenn sie selbst kein Satz ist.

Dann kann ein Satz nicht von allen Sätzen handeln, wohl aber eine Definition.

The definition is only possible if it is itself not a proposition.

In that case a proposition cannot be about all propositions, while a definition can.

The definition is only possible if it is itself not a proposition.

In that case a proposition cannot be about all propositions, while a definition can.

18 April, 1916

Morgen oder übermorgen in die Feuerstellung. Also Mut! Gott wird helfen.

On the firing line tomorrow or the day after. So pluck up courage! God will help.

20 April, 1916

Gott bessere mich! Dann werde ich auch froher werden. Heute wahrscheinlich schon in Feuerstellung. Gott helfe mir.

God make me better! Then I'll become happier too. Probably already in firing line today. God help me.

23 April, 1916

Seit ein paar Tagen in Feuerstellung. Den ganzen Tag über schwere körperliche Arbeit außerstande zu denken. Gott helfe mir; ich habe ungeheuer viel zu leiden. Habe heute angesucht auf den Beobachtungsstand zu kommen. Beim Halbzug haßt mich alles weil mich keiner versteht. Und weil ich kein Heiliger bin! Gott helfe mir!

On the firing line for a couple of days. Unable to think due to hard physical labor all day. God help me; I have suffered immensely. Have applied today to be moved to the observation post. Everyone in the squad hates me, because no one understands me. And because I'm no saint! God help me!

23 April, 1916

Die obige Definition handelt aber gar nicht von allen Sätzen denn sie enthält wesentlich wirkliche Variable. Sie ist ganz analog einer Operation als deren Basis auch ihr eigenes Resultat genommen werden kann.

However the above definition just does not deal with all propositions, for it essentially contains real variables. It is quite analogous to an operation whose own result can be taken as its basis.

However the above definition just does not deal with all propositions, for it essentially contains real variables. It is quite analogous to an operation whose own result can be taken as its basis.

23 April, 1916

Die obige Definition handelt aber gar nicht von allen Sätzen denn sie enthält wesentlich wirkliche Variable. Sie ist ganz analog einer Operation als deren Basis auch ihr eigenes Resultat genommen werden kann.

However the above definition just does not deal with all propositions, for it essentially contains real variables. It is quite analogous to an operation whose own result can be taken as its basis.

However the above definition just does not deal with all propositions, for it essentially contains real variables. It is quite analogous to an operation whose own result can be taken as its basis.

26 April, 1916

Die Offiziere der Batterie können mich scheinbar sehr gut leiden. Dies erspart mir manche Unannehmlichkeit. Gott sei gedankt. Dein Wille geschehe! Geh Du deiner Wege! Dein Wille geschehe!

The battery officers seem to have taken a liking to me. This saves me from much trouble. Thank God. Thy will be done. Thou goest thy way. Thy will be done.

 TLP 5·252 a+

Only in this way is advancing from term to term in a series of forms possible (from type to type in Russell and Whitehead’s hierarchies). (Russell and Whitehead did not admit the possibility of advancing in this way, but they relied on it again and again.)

This is the only possible way of stepping from one type to another in the type hierarchy.

26 April, 1916

So und nur so ist das Fortschreiten von einer Type zur anderen möglich.

In this way, and only in this way, is advancing from one type to another possible. [Cf. 5.252.]

In this way, and only in this way, is advancing from one type to another possible. [Cf. 5.252.]

This is the only possible way of stepping from one type to another in the type hierarchy.

26 April, 1916

Und man kann sagen alle Typen stehen in Hierarchien.

And one can say all types belong to hierarchies.

And one can say all types belong to hierarchies.

26 April, 1916

Und die Hierarchie ist nur möglich durch den Aufbau durch die / Operationen.

And hierarchies are only possible only by being constructed by means of operations.

And hierarchies are only possible only by being constructed by means of operations.

TLP 5·5561

Empirical reality is delimited by the totality of objects. Here too, the limit reveals itself in the totality of elementary sentences.

Hierarchies are and must be independent of reality.

Empirical reality is limited by the totality of objects. The limit also shows itself in the totality of objects. Hierarchies are and must be independent of reality.

26 April, 1916

Die empirische Realität ist begrenzt durch die Zahl der Gegenstände.

Die Grenze zeigt sich wieder in der Gesamtheit der einfachen Sätze.

Empirical reality is delimited by the number of objects.

Here too, the limit shows itself in the totality of simple propositions. [See 5.5561.]

Empirical reality is delimited by the number of objects.

Here too, the limit shows itself in the totality of simple propositions. [See 5.5561.]

Empirical reality is limited by the totality of objects. The limit also shows itself in the totality of objects. Hierarchies are and must be independent of reality.

TLP 5·5561

Empirical reality is delimited by the totality of objects. Here too, the limit reveals itself in the totality of elementary sentences.

Hierarchies are and must be independent of reality.

Empirical reality is limited by the totality of objects. The limit also shows itself in the totality of objects. Hierarchies are and must be independent of reality.

26 April, 1916

Die Hierarchien sind und müssen unabhängig sein von der Realität.

Die Bedeutungen ihrer Glieder werden erst durch Zuordnung der Gegenstände zu den Namen bestimmt.

Hierarchies are and must be independent of reality. [See 5.5561.]

The meanings of their terms are only determined by correlating objects and names.

Hierarchies are and must be independent of reality. [See 5.5561.]

The meanings of their terms are only determined by correlating objects and names.

Empirical reality is limited by the totality of objects. The limit also shows itself in the totality of objects. Hierarchies are and must be independent of reality.

In this way, and only in this way, is advancing from one type to another possible. [Cf. 5.252.]

In this way, and only in this way, is advancing from one type to another possible. [Cf. 5.252.]

And one can say all types belong to hierarchies.

And hierarchies are only possible only by being constructed by means of operations.

And hierarchies are only possible only by being constructed by means of operations.

Hierarchies are and must be independent of reality.

Empirical reality is limited by the totality of objects. The limit also shows itself in the totality of objects. Hierarchies are and must be independent of reality.

Die Grenze zeigt sich wieder in der Gesamtheit der einfachen Sätze.

Empirical reality is delimited by the number of objects.

Here too, the limit shows itself in the totality of simple propositions. [See 5.5561.]

TLP 5·5561

Empirical reality is delimited by the totality of objects. Here too, the limit reveals itself in the totality of elementary sentences.

Hierarchies are and must be independent of reality.

Empirical reality is limited by the totality of objects. The limit also shows itself in the totality of objects. Hierarchies are and must be independent of reality.

26 April, 1916

Die Hierarchien sind und müssen unabhängig sein von der Realität.

Hierarchies are and must be independent of reality. [See 5.5561.]

The meanings of their terms are only determined by correlating objects and names.

Hierarchies are and must be independent of reality. [See 5.5561.]

The meanings of their terms are only determined by correlating objects and names.

Empirical reality is limited by the totality of objects. The limit also shows itself in the totality of objects. Hierarchies are and must be independent of reality.

27 April, 1916

Die Mannschaft mit wenigen Ausnahmen haßt mich als Freiwilligen. So bin ich jetzt fast immer umgeben von Leuten die mich hassen. Und dies ist das Einzige womit ich mich noch nicht abfinden kann. Hier sind aber böse, herzlose Menschen. Es ist mir fast unmöglich eine Spur von Menschlichkeit in ihnen zu finden. Gott helfe mir zu leben. Hatte / heute eine Ahnung daß heute nacht Alarm sein werde. Und wirklich ist heute nacht Bereitschaft. Gott sei mit mir! Amen.

As a volunteer, the crew, with a few exceptions, hate me. So now I’m almost always surrounded by people who hate me. And this is the only thing that I still can’t bear. But the men here are evil and heartless. It’s almost impossible for me to find a trace of humanity in them. God help me to live. Had a premonition today that there would be an alert tonight. And indeed there is stand-by duty tonight. God be with me. Amen.

27 April, 1916

φx . ψy

Sagen wir ich wollte eine Funktion von 3 unter einander unauswechselbaren Argumenten / darstellen.

φx . ψy

Suppose I wanted to represent a function of 3 non-interchangeable arguments.

φx . ψy

Suppose I wanted to represent a function of 3 non-interchangeable arguments.

27 April, 1916

φ(x) : φ( ), x

φ(x) : φ( ), x

φ(x) : φ( ), x

27 April, 1916

Soll nun aber in der Logik von unvertauschbaren Argumenten die Rede sein? Wenn ja, so setzt dies doch etwas über die Beschaffenheit der Realität voraus.

But should there be any mention of non-interchangeable arguments in logic? If so, this surely presupposes something about the nature of reality.

But should there be any mention of non-interchangeable arguments in logic? If so, this surely presupposes something about the nature of reality.

27 April, 1916

φx . ψy = xφψy = xRy

Fx.Fy.xRy = F(xRy)

F(xRy) = Fx.Fy.φx. ψy

~(∃x).φx. ψ∃◇◇◇ψz .⊃ψ. ~(∃x) ψx

φx . ψy = xφψy = xRy

Fx.Fy.xRy = F(xRy)

F(xRy) = Fx.Fy.φx. ψy

~(∃x).φx. ψ∃◇◇◇ψz .⊃ψ. ~(∃x) ψx

φx . ψy = xφψy = xRy

Fx.Fy.xRy = F(xRy)

F(xRy) = Fx.Fy.φx. ψy

~(∃x).φx. ψ∃◇◇◇ψz .⊃ψ. ~(∃x) ψx

27 April, 1916

φx . ψy

Sagen wir ich wollte eine Funktion von 3 unter einander unauswechselbaren Argumenten / darstellen.

φx . ψy

Suppose I wanted to represent a function of 3 non-interchangeable arguments.

φx . ψy

27 April, 1916

φ(x) : φ( ), x

φ(x) : φ( ), x

F(xRy) = Fx.Fy.φx. ψy

~(∃x).φx. ψ∃◇◇◇ψz .⊃ψ. ~(∃x) ψx

28 April, 1916

Nachts Ruhe. Schrieb an Russell. Hatte heute nacht einen schlechten Traum. Gott schütze mich.

Quiet night. Wrote to Russell. Had a bad dream last night. God protect me.

29 April, 1916

Nachmittag bei den Aufklärern. Wurden beschossen. Dachte an Gott. Dein Wille geschehe! Gott sei mit mir.

Afternoon with the spotters. Was shot at. Thought of God. Thy will be done. God be with me.

30 April, 1916

Gehe heute während eines Feuerüberfalls wieder zu den Aufklärern: Nur Gott braucht der Mensch.

Went to the spotters again today during a surprise burst of fire. Man needs only God.

2 May, 1916

Habe mich fortwährend gegen / die Gemeinheit der Leute zu wehren.

Have to constantly defend myself against people’s nastiness.

3 May, 1916

Habe es schwer! Gott beschütze mich und stehe mir bei. Amen. Möchte der schwerste Kelch an mir vorüber gehen. Aber Dein Wille geschehe. Die Arbeit schläft in meinem Kopfe.

It’s very hard! God protect me and stand by me. Amen. Would that the bitter cup passed me by. But thy will be done. The work is asleep in my head.

4 May, 1916

Komme morgen vielleicht auf mein Ansuchen zu den Aufklärern hinauf. Dann wird für mich erst der Krieg anfangen. Und kann sein – auch das Leben! Vielleicht bringt mir die Nähe des Todes das Licht des Lebens! Möchte Gott mich erleuchten! / Ich bin ein Wurm aber durch Gott werde ich zum Menschen. Gott stehe mir bei. Amen.

Perhaps tomorrow I will go above with the observers at my request. Only then will the war begin for me. And – perhaps – life too! Perhaps nearness to death will bring light into my life! May God enlighten me. I am a worm but through God I will become a human being. God stand by me. Amen.

5 May, 1916

Bin wie der Prinz im verwünschten Schloß auf dem Aufklärerstand. Jetzt bei Tag ist alles ruhig aber in der Nacht! Da muß es fürchterlich zugehen! Ob ich es aushalten werde???? Die heutige Nacht wird es zeigen. Gott stehe mir bei!!

Am like the prince in the enchanted castle in the observation post. Now during the day everything is quiet, but at night! It must be frightful there! Will I endure it???? Tonight will tell. God stand by me.

6 May, 1916

In steter Lebensgefahr. Die Nacht verlief durch die Gnade Gottes gut. Von Zeit zu Zeit werde ich verzagt. Das ist die Schuld der falschen / Lebensauffassung! Verstehe die Menschen! Immer wenn du sie hassen willst trachte sie statt dessen zu verstehen. Lebe im innern Frieden! Wie aber kommst du zum innern Frieden? Nur indem ich Gottgefällig lebe! Nur so ist es möglich, das Leben zu ertragen.

In constant mortal danger. The night went well, by the grace of God. From time to time I despaired. That is due to a false view of life! Understand people. Whenever you feel like hating them, try to understand them instead. Live in inner peace. But how do you get to inner peace? Only if I live in a way pleasing to God. Only in this way is it possible to endure life.

 TLP 6·371

The whole modern world view is based on the illusion that the so-called laws of nature are explanations of natural phenomena.

The whole modern world view is based on the illusion that the so-called laws of nature explain natural phenomena.

6 May, 1916

Der ganzen Weltanschauung der Modernen liegt diese Täuschung zu Grunde, daß die sogenannten Naturgesetze die Erklärungen der Naturerscheinungen seien.

The whole modern world view is based on the illusion that the so-called laws of nature explain natural phenomena. [See 6.371.]

The whole modern world view is based on the illusion that the so-called laws of nature explain natural phenomena. [See 6.371.]

The whole modern world view is based on the illusion that the so-called laws of nature explain natural phenomena.

TLP 6·372

So moderns stop at the laws of nature, treating them as sacrosanct, which is how the ancients treated God and Fate.

And actually they are both right, and both wrong. The ancients, though, were more clear-sighted in that they recognised a distinct terminus, whereas according to the new dispensation things are supposed to look as if everything were explained.

So moderns stop at the laws of nature, treating them as sacrosanct, which is how the ancients treated God and Fate. And actually they are both right, and both wrong. But the ancients were much clearer in that they recognised a clear terminus, while the moderns make it seem as if everything is explained.

6 May, 1916

So bleiben sie bei den Naturgesetzen als bei etwas Unantastbarem stehen wie die Älteren bei Gott und dem Schicksal.

So moderns stop at the laws of nature, treating them as sacrosanct, which is how the ancients treated God and Fate. [See 6.372.]

So moderns stop at the laws of nature, treating them as sacrosanct, which is how the ancients treated God and Fate. [See 6.372.]

So moderns stop at the laws of nature, treating them as sacrosanct, which is how the ancients treated God and Fate. And actually they are both right, and both wrong. But the ancients were much clearer in that they recognised a clear terminus, while the moderns make it seem as if everything is explained.

TLP 6·372

So moderns stop at the laws of nature, treating them as sacrosanct, which is how the ancients treated God and Fate.

And actually they are both right, and both wrong. The ancients, though, were more clear-sighted in that they recognised a distinct terminus, whereas according to the new dispensation things are supposed to look as if everything were explained.

So moderns stop at the laws of nature, treating them as sacrosanct, which is how the ancients treated God and Fate. And actually they are both right, and both wrong. But the ancients were much clearer in that they recognised a clear terminus, while the moderns make it seem as if everything is explained.

6 May, 1916

Und sie haben ja beide recht und unrecht. Die Alten sind allerdings insofern klarer als sie einen klaren Abschluß anerkannten während es bei dem neuen System scheinen soll als sei alles begründet.

And actually they are both right, and both wrong. But the ancients were more clear-sighted in that they recognised a distinct terminus, whereas according to the new dispensation things are supposed to look as if everything were explained. [See 6.372.]

And actually they are both right, and both wrong. But the ancients were more clear-sighted in that they recognised a distinct terminus, whereas according to the new dispensation things are supposed to look as if everything were explained. [See 6.372.]

So moderns stop at the laws of nature, treating them as sacrosanct, which is how the ancients treated God and Fate. And actually they are both right, and both wrong. But the ancients were much clearer in that they recognised a clear terminus, while the moderns make it seem as if everything is explained.

TLP 6·371

The whole modern world view is based on the illusion that the so-called laws of nature are explanations of natural phenomena.

The whole modern world view is based on the illusion that the so-called laws of nature explain natural phenomena.

6 May, 1916

Der ganzen Weltanschauung der Modernen liegt diese Täuschung zu Grunde, daß die sogenannten Naturgesetze die Erklärungen der Naturerscheinungen seien.

The whole modern world view is based on the illusion that the so-called laws of nature explain natural phenomena. [See 6.371.]

The whole modern world view is based on the illusion that the so-called laws of nature explain natural phenomena. [See 6.371.]

The whole modern world view is based on the illusion that the so-called laws of nature explain natural phenomena.

TLP 6·372

So moderns stop at the laws of nature, treating them as sacrosanct, which is how the ancients treated God and Fate.

And actually they are both right, and both wrong. The ancients, though, were more clear-sighted in that they recognised a distinct terminus, whereas according to the new dispensation things are supposed to look as if everything were explained.

So moderns stop at the laws of nature, treating them as sacrosanct, which is how the ancients treated God and Fate. And actually they are both right, and both wrong. But the ancients were much clearer in that they recognised a clear terminus, while the moderns make it seem as if everything is explained.

6 May, 1916

So bleiben sie bei den Naturgesetzen als bei etwas Unantastbarem stehen wie die Älteren bei Gott und dem Schicksal.

So moderns stop at the laws of nature, treating them as sacrosanct, which is how the ancients treated God and Fate. [See 6.372.]

So moderns stop at the laws of nature, treating them as sacrosanct, which is how the ancients treated God and Fate. [See 6.372.]

So moderns stop at the laws of nature, treating them as sacrosanct, which is how the ancients treated God and Fate. And actually they are both right, and both wrong. But the ancients were much clearer in that they recognised a clear terminus, while the moderns make it seem as if everything is explained.

TLP 6·372

So moderns stop at the laws of nature, treating them as sacrosanct, which is how the ancients treated God and Fate.

And actually they are both right, and both wrong. The ancients, though, were more clear-sighted in that they recognised a distinct terminus, whereas according to the new dispensation things are supposed to look as if everything were explained.

So moderns stop at the laws of nature, treating them as sacrosanct, which is how the ancients treated God and Fate. And actually they are both right, and both wrong. But the ancients were much clearer in that they recognised a clear terminus, while the moderns make it seem as if everything is explained.

6 May, 1916

Und sie haben ja beide recht und unrecht. Die Alten sind allerdings insofern klarer als sie einen klaren Abschluß anerkannten während es bei dem neuen System scheinen soll als sei alles begründet.

And actually they are both right, and both wrong. But the ancients were more clear-sighted in that they recognised a distinct terminus, whereas according to the new dispensation things are supposed to look as if everything were explained. [See 6.372.]

And actually they are both right, and both wrong. But the ancients were more clear-sighted in that they recognised a distinct terminus, whereas according to the new dispensation things are supposed to look as if everything were explained. [See 6.372.]

So moderns stop at the laws of nature, treating them as sacrosanct, which is how the ancients treated God and Fate. And actually they are both right, and both wrong. But the ancients were much clearer in that they recognised a clear terminus, while the moderns make it seem as if everything is explained.

7 May, 1916

Nacht verlief ruhig. Gott sei Dank. Nur ich bin ein Elender.

Night passed quietly. Thank God. Only I am a wretch.

8 May, 1916

Ruhige Nacht. Gott mit mir!

Quiet night. God with me!

9 May, 1916

Hätte jetzt reichlich Zeit und Ruhe zum Arbeiten. Aber es rührt sich nichts. Mein Stoff ist weit von mir entfernt. Der Tod gibt dem Leben erst seine Bedeutung.

Have had plenty of time and peace to work now. But nothing is moving. My material is far away from me. Only death gives life its meaning.

10 May, 1916

Durch die Gnade Gottes geht es mir jetzt sehr gut. Arbeiten kann ich leider nicht. Aber Dein Wille geschehe! Amen. In der Gefahr wird er / mich nicht verlassen!! ——.

By the grace of God things are going very well for me now. Unfortunately I can't work. But Thy will be done! Amen. He won't forsake me in danger!! ——.

11 May, 1916

Übermorgen Stellungswechsel. Sehr unangenehm! Aber Dein Wille geschehe.

A change of post the day after tomorrow. Very nasty! But Thy will be done.

11 May, 1916

∣ p ∣ (a,a)

Es gibt eben auch Operationen / mit zwei Basen. Und die ‘ ∣ ’-Operation ist von dieser Art.

∣ p ∣ (a,a)

There are also operations with two bases. And the ' ∣ '-operation is of this kind.

∣ p ∣ (a,a)

There are also operations with two bases. And the ' ∣ '-operation is of this kind.

11 May, 1916

∣ (ξ,η) … ist ein beliebiges Glied der Reihe der Operationsresultate.

∣ (ξ,η) ... is an arbitrary term of the series of results of as operation.

∣ (ξ,η) ... is an arbitrary term of the series of results of as operation.

11 May, 1916

(∃x).φx

Ist denn (∃x) etc. wirklich eine Operation?

(∃x).φx

Then is (∃x) etc. really an operation?

(∃x).φx

Then is (∃x) etc. really an operation?

11 May, 1916

Was wäre aber ihre Basis?

But what would be its base?

But what would be its base?

11 May, 1916

∣ p ∣ (a,a)

Es gibt eben auch Operationen / mit zwei Basen. Und die ‘ ∣ ’-Operation ist von dieser Art.

∣ p ∣ (a,a)

There are also operations with two bases. And the ' ∣ '-operation is of this kind.

∣ p ∣ (a,a)

There are also operations with two bases. And the ' ∣ '-operation is of this kind.

11 May, 1916

∣ (ξ,η) ... is an arbitrary term of the series of results of as operation.

∣ (ξ,η) ... is an arbitrary term of the series of results of as operation.

11 May, 1916

(∃x).φx

Ist denn (∃x) etc. wirklich eine Operation?

(∃x).φx

Then is (∃x) etc. really an operation?

(∃x).φx

Then is (∃x) etc. really an operation?

11 May, 1916

Was wäre aber ihre Basis?

But what would be its base?

But what would be its base?

16 May, 1916

In der dritten Stellung. Wie immer viel Mühsal. Aber auch große Gnade. Bin schwach wie immer! Kann nicht arbeiten. Schlafe heute im Infanteriefeuer, werde wahrscheinlich zugrunde gehen. Gott sei mit mir! In Ewigkeit Amen! Ich bin ein schwacher Mensch aber Er hat mich bis nun erhalten. Gott sei gelobt in Ewigkeit, Amen. Ich übergebe meine Seele dem / Herrn.

In the third position. As always, much fatigue. But also great blessings. Am weak as always. Can't work. Sleep during infantry fire today. Will probably perish. God be with me. In eternity, amen. I am a weak human being but He has preserved me so far. God be praised in eternity, amen. I commit my soul to the Lord.

21 May, 1916

Gott mache aus mir einen besseren Menschen!

God make me a better man.

21 May, 1916

(∃x).(y).φ(x, y); (y).(∃x).φ(x, y); (x) (∃y).φx, y.

(∃y) (x) φ(xy) . (∃x) (∃y) φ(x, y); (x).(y) φ(x y)

(∃x).(y).φ(x, y); (y).(∃x).φ(x, y); (x) (∃y).φx, y.

(∃y) (x) φ(xy) . (∃x) (∃y) φ(x, y); (x).(y) φ(x y)

(∃x).(y).φ(x, y); (y).(∃x).φ(x, y); (x) (∃y).φx, y.

(∃y) (x) φ(xy) . (∃x) (∃y) φ(x, y); (x).(y) φ(x y)

21 May, 1916

(∃x).(y).φ(x, y); (y).(∃x).φ(x, y); (x) (∃y).φx, y.

(∃y) (x) φ(xy) . (∃x) (∃y) φ(x, y); (x).(y) φ(x y)

(∃x).(y).φ(x, y); (y).(∃x).φ(x, y); (x) (∃y).φx, y.

24 May, 1916

Fo(x, y, z …)

Fo(x, y, z …)

Fo(x, y, z …)

24 May, 1916

Fo(x, y, z …)

Fo(x, y, z …)

Fo(x, y, z …)

25 May, 1916

Werden beschossen. Wie Gott will!

Fired upon. As God wills.

 TLP 5·621

The world and life are one.

The world and life are one.

25 May, 1916

Was weiß ich über Gott und / den Zweck des Lebens?

Ich weiß daß diese Welt ist.

Daß ich in ihr stehe wie mein Auge in seinem Gesichtsfeld.

Daß etwas an ihr problematisch ist was wir ihren Sinn nennen.

Daß dieser Sinn nicht in ihr liegt sondern außer ihr.

Daß das Leben die Welt ist.

Daß mein Wille die Welt durchdringt.

Daß mein Wille gut oder böse ist.

Daß also Gut und Böse mit dem Sinn der Welt / irgendwie zusammenhängt.

Den Sinn des Lebens, d.i. den Sinn der Welt, können wir Gott nennen.

Und das Gleichnis von Gott als einem Vater daran knüpfen.

Das Gebet ist der Gedanke an den Sinn des Lebens.

Ich kann die Geschehnisse der Welt nicht nach meinem Willen lenken sondern bin vollkommen machtlos.

Nur so kann ich mich unabhängig von der Welt machen – und sie also doch in gewissem Sinne beherrschen – indem ich auf einen Einfluß auf die Geschehnisse verzichte.

What do I know about God and the purpose of life?

I know that this world exists.

That I am in it like my eye in its field of vision.

That something about it is problematic, which we call its meaning.

That this meaning does not reside in it but outside it. [Cf. 6.41.]

That life is the world. [Cf. 5.621.]

That my will pervades the world.

That my will is good or evil.

That good and evil are thus somehow connected with the meaning of the world.

The meaning of life, i.e. the meaning of the world, we can call God.

And connect this with the comparison of God to a father.

Praying is thinking about the meaning of life.

I cannot control the world’s events with my will: on the contrary, I am completely powerless.

Only in this way can I make myself independent of the world - and thus still control it in a certain sense - by renouncing any influence on events.

What do I know about God and the purpose of life?

I know that this world exists.

That I am in it like my eye in its field of vision.

That something about it is problematic, which we call its meaning.

That this meaning does not reside in it but outside it. [Cf. 6.41.]

That life is the world. [Cf. 5.621.]

That my will pervades the world.

That my will is good or evil.

That good and evil are thus somehow connected with the meaning of the world.

The meaning of life, i.e. the meaning of the world, we can call God.

And connect this with the comparison of God to a father.

Praying is thinking about the meaning of life.

I cannot control the world’s events with my will: on the contrary, I am completely powerless.

Only in this way can I make myself independent of the world - and thus still control it in a certain sense - by renouncing any influence on events.

The world and life are one.

TLP 5·621

The world and life are one.

The world and life are one.

25 May, 1916

Was weiß ich über Gott und / den Zweck des Lebens?

Ich weiß daß diese Welt ist.

Daß ich in ihr stehe wie mein Auge in seinem Gesichtsfeld.

Daß etwas an ihr problematisch ist was wir ihren Sinn nennen.

Daß dieser Sinn nicht in ihr liegt sondern außer ihr.

Daß das Leben die Welt ist.

Daß mein Wille die Welt durchdringt.

Daß mein Wille gut oder böse ist.

Daß also Gut und Böse mit dem Sinn der Welt / irgendwie zusammenhängt.

Den Sinn des Lebens, d.i. den Sinn der Welt, können wir Gott nennen.

Und das Gleichnis von Gott als einem Vater daran knüpfen.

Das Gebet ist der Gedanke an den Sinn des Lebens.

Ich kann die Geschehnisse der Welt nicht nach meinem Willen lenken sondern bin vollkommen machtlos.

Nur so kann ich mich unabhängig von der Welt machen – und sie also doch in gewissem Sinne beherrschen – indem ich auf einen Einfluß auf die Geschehnisse verzichte.

What do I know about God and the purpose of life?

I know that this world exists.

That I am in it like my eye in its field of vision.

That something about it is problematic, which we call its meaning.

That this meaning does not reside in it but outside it. [Cf. 6.41.]

That life is the world. [Cf. 5.621.]

That my will pervades the world.

That my will is good or evil.

That good and evil are thus somehow connected with the meaning of the world.

The meaning of life, i.e. the meaning of the world, we can call God.

And connect this with the comparison of God to a father.

Praying is thinking about the meaning of life.

I cannot control the world’s events with my will: on the contrary, I am completely powerless.

Only in this way can I make myself independent of the world - and thus still control it in a certain sense - by renouncing any influence on events.

What do I know about God and the purpose of life?

I know that this world exists.

That I am in it like my eye in its field of vision.

That something about it is problematic, which we call its meaning.

That this meaning does not reside in it but outside it. [Cf. 6.41.]

That life is the world. [Cf. 5.621.]

That my will pervades the world.

That my will is good or evil.

That good and evil are thus somehow connected with the meaning of the world.

The meaning of life, i.e. the meaning of the world, we can call God.

And connect this with the comparison of God to a father.

Praying is thinking about the meaning of life.

I cannot control the world’s events with my will: on the contrary, I am completely powerless.

Only in this way can I make myself independent of the world - and thus still control it in a certain sense - by renouncing any influence on events.

The world and life are one.

27 May, 1916

Briefe von Mining und Mama. Heute oder morgen soll russischer Angriff sein. Nun wie Gott will. Ich bin sehr tief in die Sünde gefallen. Aber Gott wird mir vergeben.

Letters from Mining and Mama. Today or tomorrow there will be a Russian attack. As God wills then. I have fallen very deeply into sin. But God will forgive me.

28 May, 1916

In den letzten Wochen sehr unruhigen Schlaf. Immer träume ich vom Dienst. Träume die mich immer an die Grenze des Erwachens führen. In den letzten 2 Monaten nur 3 Mal onaniert. Meine Umgebung ekelt mich gegen meinen Willen an. Nicht wie Menschen sondern wie Fratzen erscheinen sie mir oft. Gemeines Gesindel. Ich hasse sie nicht aber sie ekeln mich an. Heute strenge Bereitschaft. Mein Kommandant ist sehr liebenswürdig mit mir. Denke an das Ziel des Lebens. Das ist noch das Beste was du machen kannst. Ich sollte glücklicher sein. Oh, wenn mein Geist stärker wäre!!! Nun Gott mit mir! Amen.

Very unsettled sleep in the last few weeks. I always dream of my duties. Dreams that always bring me to the edge of awakening. Only masturbated 3 times in the last 2 months. / Against my will, my company disgusts me. They often seem to me not like human beings but caricatures. Common rabble. I don't hate them but they disgust me. Full alert today. My commander is very gracious with me. Thinking about the purpose of life. That’s still the best thing you can do. I should be happier. Oh if my spirit were stronger!!! Now God be with me! Amen.

29 May, 1916

Gott mit mir.

God with me.

TLP 6·373

The world is independent of my will.

The world is independent of my will.

5 July, 1916

Die Welt ist unabhängig von meinem Willen.

The world is independent of my will. [6.373.]

The world is independent of my will. [6.373.]

The world is independent of my will.

TLP 6·374*

Even if all we wish for were to happen, still this would only be so by the grace of Fate, so to say, for there is no logical connection between the will and the world that would guarantee it, and the supposed physical connection in its turn is surely not something we could will.

Even if all we wish for were to happen, still this would only be a favour of fate, so to say, for there is no logical connection between the will and the world that could guarantee it, and the supposed physical connection itself is surely not something we could will.

5 July, 1916

Auch wenn alles was wir wünschen geschähe so wäre dies doch nur sozusagen eine Gnade des Schicksals denn es ist kein logischer Zusammenhang zwischen Willen und Welt der dies verbürgte und den angenommenen physikalischen konnten wir doch nicht wieder wollen.

Even if all we wish for were to happen, still this would only be so by the grace of fate, so to say, for there is no logical connection between the will and the world that would guarantee it, and the supposed physical connection in its turn is surely not something we could will. [See 6.374.]

Even if all we wish for were to happen, still this would only be so by the grace of fate, so to say, for there is no logical connection between the will and the world that would guarantee it, and the supposed physical connection in its turn is surely not something we could will. [See 6.374.]

Even if all we wish for were to happen, still this would only be a favour of fate, so to say, for there is no logical connection between the will and the world that could guarantee it, and the supposed physical connection itself is surely not something we could will.

TLP 6·43 (1)**

If good or bad willing changes the world, it can only change the limits of the world, not the facts; not what can be expressed by language.

In short, the world will in this way have to become entirely different in kind. It must, so to speak, wax or wane as a whole.

The world of a happy person is a different one from that of an unhappy person.

If good or bad willing changes the world, it can only change the limits of the world, not the facts; not what can be expressed in language, but only what language expresses.

5 July, 1916

Wenn das gute oder böse Wollen eine Wirkung auf die Welt hat so kann es sie nur auf die Grenzen der Welt haben, / nicht auf die Tatsachen, auf das was durch die Sprache nicht abgebildet sondern nur in der Sprache gezeigt werden kann.

If good or bad willing has an effect on the world, it can only have an effect on the limits of the world, on what cannot be depicted by language but can only can be shown in language, not on the facts. [Cf. 6.43 (1).]

If good or bad willing has an effect on the world, it can only have an effect on the limits of the world, on what cannot be depicted by language but can only can be shown in language, not on the facts. [Cf. 6.43 (1).]

If good or bad willing changes the world, it can only change the limits of the world, not the facts; not what can be expressed in language, but only what language expresses.

TLP 6·43 (2)

If good or bad willing changes the world, it can only change the limits of the world, not the facts; not what can be expressed by language.

In short, the world will in this way have to become entirely different in kind. It must, so to speak, wax or wane as a whole.

The world of a happy person is a different one from that of an unhappy person.

If good or bad willing changes the world, it can only change the limits of the world, not the facts; not what can be expressed in language, but only what language expresses.

5 July, 1916

Kurz die Welt muß dann dadurch überhaupt eine andere werden.

In short, the world will in this way have to become entirely different in kind. [See 6.43 (2).]

In short, the world will in this way have to become entirely different in kind. [See 6.43 (2).]

If good or bad willing changes the world, it can only change the limits of the world, not the facts; not what can be expressed in language, but only what language expresses.

TLP 6·43 (2)

If good or bad willing changes the world, it can only change the limits of the world, not the facts; not what can be expressed by language.

In short, the world will in this way have to become entirely different in kind. It must, so to speak, wax or wane as a whole.

The world of a happy person is a different one from that of an unhappy person.

If good or bad willing changes the world, it can only change the limits of the world, not the facts; not what can be expressed in language, but only what language expresses.

5 July, 1916

Sie muß sozusagen als Ganzes zunehmen oder abnehmen. Wie durch Dazukommen oder Wegfallen eines Sinnes.

It must, so to speak, wax or wane as a whole. As if by adding or losing meaning.

It must, so to speak, wax or wane as a whole. As if by adding or losing meaning.

If good or bad willing changes the world, it can only change the limits of the world, not the facts; not what can be expressed in language, but only what language expresses.

TLP 6·431

Similarly, in death the world does not change, but ends.

In death, too, the world does not change, but comes to an end.

5 July, 1916

Wie auch beim Tode die Welt sich nicht ändert, sondern aufhört zu sein.

Similarly, in death the world does not change, but ceases to exist. [See 6.431.]

Similarly, in death the world does not change, but ceases to exist. [See 6.431.]

In death, too, the world does not change, but comes to an end.

TLP 6·373

The world is independent of my will.

The world is independent of my will.

5 July, 1916

Die Welt ist unabhängig von meinem Willen.

The world is independent of my will. [6.373.]

The world is independent of my will. [6.373.]

The world is independent of my will.

TLP 6·374*

Even if all we wish for were to happen, still this would only be so by the grace of Fate, so to say, for there is no logical connection between the will and the world that would guarantee it, and the supposed physical connection in its turn is surely not something we could will.

Even if all we wish for were to happen, still this would only be a favour of fate, so to say, for there is no logical connection between the will and the world that could guarantee it, and the supposed physical connection itself is surely not something we could will.

5 July, 1916

Auch wenn alles was wir wünschen geschähe so wäre dies doch nur sozusagen eine Gnade des Schicksals denn es ist kein logischer Zusammenhang zwischen Willen und Welt der dies verbürgte und den angenommenen physikalischen konnten wir doch nicht wieder wollen.

Even if all we wish for were to happen, still this would only be so by the grace of fate, so to say, for there is no logical connection between the will and the world that would guarantee it, and the supposed physical connection in its turn is surely not something we could will. [See 6.374.]

Even if all we wish for were to happen, still this would only be so by the grace of fate, so to say, for there is no logical connection between the will and the world that would guarantee it, and the supposed physical connection in its turn is surely not something we could will. [See 6.374.]

Even if all we wish for were to happen, still this would only be a favour of fate, so to say, for there is no logical connection between the will and the world that could guarantee it, and the supposed physical connection itself is surely not something we could will.

TLP 6·43 (1)**

If good or bad willing changes the world, it can only change the limits of the world, not the facts; not what can be expressed by language.

In short, the world will in this way have to become entirely different in kind. It must, so to speak, wax or wane as a whole.

The world of a happy person is a different one from that of an unhappy person.

If good or bad willing changes the world, it can only change the limits of the world, not the facts; not what can be expressed in language, but only what language expresses.

5 July, 1916

Wenn das gute oder böse Wollen eine Wirkung auf die Welt hat so kann es sie nur auf die Grenzen der Welt haben, / nicht auf die Tatsachen, auf das was durch die Sprache nicht abgebildet sondern nur in der Sprache gezeigt werden kann.

If good or bad willing has an effect on the world, it can only have an effect on the limits of the world, on what cannot be depicted by language but can only can be shown in language, not on the facts. [Cf. 6.43 (1).]

If good or bad willing has an effect on the world, it can only have an effect on the limits of the world, on what cannot be depicted by language but can only can be shown in language, not on the facts. [Cf. 6.43 (1).]

If good or bad willing changes the world, it can only change the limits of the world, not the facts; not what can be expressed in language, but only what language expresses.

TLP 6·43 (2)

If good or bad willing changes the world, it can only change the limits of the world, not the facts; not what can be expressed by language.

In short, the world will in this way have to become entirely different in kind. It must, so to speak, wax or wane as a whole.

The world of a happy person is a different one from that of an unhappy person.

If good or bad willing changes the world, it can only change the limits of the world, not the facts; not what can be expressed in language, but only what language expresses.

5 July, 1916

Kurz die Welt muß dann dadurch überhaupt eine andere werden.

In short, the world will in this way have to become entirely different in kind. [See 6.43 (2).]

In short, the world will in this way have to become entirely different in kind. [See 6.43 (2).]

If good or bad willing changes the world, it can only change the limits of the world, not the facts; not what can be expressed in language, but only what language expresses.

TLP 6·43 (2)

If good or bad willing changes the world, it can only change the limits of the world, not the facts; not what can be expressed by language.

In short, the world will in this way have to become entirely different in kind. It must, so to speak, wax or wane as a whole.

The world of a happy person is a different one from that of an unhappy person.

If good or bad willing changes the world, it can only change the limits of the world, not the facts; not what can be expressed in language, but only what language expresses.

5 July, 1916

Sie muß sozusagen als Ganzes zunehmen oder abnehmen. Wie durch Dazukommen oder Wegfallen eines Sinnes.

It must, so to speak, wax or wane as a whole. As if by adding or losing meaning.

It must, so to speak, wax or wane as a whole. As if by adding or losing meaning.

TLP 6·431

Similarly, in death the world does not change, but ends.

In death, too, the world does not change, but comes to an end.

5 July, 1916

Wie auch beim Tode die Welt sich nicht ändert, sondern aufhört zu sein.

Similarly, in death the world does not change, but ceases to exist. [See 6.431.]

Similarly, in death the world does not change, but ceases to exist. [See 6.431.]

In death, too, the world does not change, but comes to an end.

6 July, 1916

Kolossale Strapazen im letzten Monat. Habe viel über alles / mögliche nachgedacht kann aber merkwürdigerweise nicht die Verbindung mit meinen mathematischen Gedankengängen herstellen.

Enormous hardship in the last month. Have thought a lot about every possible subject but strangely I can’t make the connection with my mathematical trains of thought.

6 July, 1916

Und insofern hat wohl auch Dostojewski recht wenn er sagt daß der welcher glücklich ist den Zweck des Daseins erfüllt.

And in this respect Dostoevsky is surely right when he says that he who is happy is fulfilling the purpose of existence.

And in this respect Dostoevsky is surely right when he says that he who is happy is fulfilling the purpose of existence.

6 July, 1916

Oder man könnte auch so sagen der erfüllt den Zweck des Daseins der keinen Zweck außer dem Leben mehr braucht. Das heißt nämlich der befriedigt ist.

Or one could also say that he who fulfills the purpose of existence does not need any purpose beyond life. That is to say, the one who is satisfied.

Or one could also say that he who fulfills the purpose of existence does not need any purpose beyond life. That is to say, the one who is satisfied.

TLP 6·521 (1)

The solution of the problem of life is felt once this problem is disappearing.

(Isn’t this why those to whom, after prolonged doubts, the meaning of life became clear have then been unable to say what that meaning amounted to?)

The solution of the problem of life is the vanishing of the problem.

6 July, 1916

Die Lösung des Problems des Lebens merkt man am Verschwinden dieses Problems.

The solution of the problem of life is felt once this problem is disappearing. [6.521 (1).]

The solution of the problem of life is felt once this problem is disappearing. [6.521 (1).]

The solution of the problem of life is the vanishing of the problem.

6 July, 1916

Kann man aber so leben daß das Leben aufhört problematisch zu sein? Daß / man im Ewigen lebt und nicht in der Zeit?

But can one live in such a way that life ceases to be problematic? That one lives in eternity and not in time?

But can one live in such a way that life ceases to be problematic? That one lives in eternity and not in time?

6 July, 1916

Und insofern hat wohl auch Dostojewski recht wenn er sagt daß der welcher glücklich ist den Zweck des Daseins erfüllt.

And in this respect Dostoevsky is surely right when he says that he who is happy is fulfilling the purpose of existence.

And in this respect Dostoevsky is surely right when he says that he who is happy is fulfilling the purpose of existence.

6 July, 1916

Oder man könnte auch so sagen der erfüllt den Zweck des Daseins der keinen Zweck außer dem Leben mehr braucht. Das heißt nämlich der befriedigt ist.

Or one could also say that he who fulfills the purpose of existence does not need any purpose beyond life. That is to say, the one who is satisfied.

Or one could also say that he who fulfills the purpose of existence does not need any purpose beyond life. That is to say, the one who is satisfied.

TLP 6·521 (1)

The solution of the problem of life is felt once this problem is disappearing.

(Isn’t this why those to whom, after prolonged doubts, the meaning of life became clear have then been unable to say what that meaning amounted to?)

The solution of the problem of life is the vanishing of the problem.

6 July, 1916

Die Lösung des Problems des Lebens merkt man am Verschwinden dieses Problems.

The solution of the problem of life is felt once this problem is disappearing. [6.521 (1).]

The solution of the problem of life is felt once this problem is disappearing. [6.521 (1).]

The solution of the problem of life is the vanishing of the problem.

6 July, 1916

Kann man aber so leben daß das Leben aufhört problematisch zu sein? Daß / man im Ewigen lebt und nicht in der Zeit?

But can one live in such a way that life ceases to be problematic? That one lives in eternity and not in time?

But can one live in such a way that life ceases to be problematic? That one lives in eternity and not in time?

7 July, 1916

Aber die Verbindung wird hergestellt werden!

But the connection will be made!

 TLP 6·521 (2)*

The solution of the problem of life is felt once this problem is disappearing.

(Isn’t this why those to whom, after prolonged doubts, the meaning of life became clear have then been unable to say what that meaning amounted to?)

The solution of the problem of life is the vanishing of the problem.

7 July, 1916

Ist nicht dies der Grund warum Menschen denen der Sinn des Lebens nach langen Zweifeln klar wurde warum diese dann nicht sagen konnten worin dieser Sinn bestand.

Isn’t this why those to whom, after prolonged doubts, the meaning of life became clear have then been unable to say what that meaning amounted to? [See 6.521 (2).]

Isn’t this why those to whom, after prolonged doubts, the meaning of life became clear have then been unable to say what that meaning amounted to? [See 6.521 (2).]

The solution of the problem of life is the vanishing of the problem.

7 July, 1916

Wenn ich mir eine „Art von Gegenständen” denken kann ohne zu wissen ob es solche Gegenstände gibt so muß ich mir ihr Urbild konstruiert haben.

If I can imagine a "kind of object" without knowing whether such objects exist, then I must have constructed their prototype for myself.

If I can imagine a "kind of object" without knowing whether such objects exist, then I must have constructed their prototype for myself.

7 July, 1916

Beruht hierauf nicht die Methode der Mechanik?

Isn't the method of mechanics based on this?

Isn't the method of mechanics based on this?

TLP 6·521 (2)*

The solution of the problem of life is felt once this problem is disappearing.

(Isn’t this why those to whom, after prolonged doubts, the meaning of life became clear have then been unable to say what that meaning amounted to?)

The solution of the problem of life is the vanishing of the problem.

7 July, 1916

Ist nicht dies der Grund warum Menschen denen der Sinn des Lebens nach langen Zweifeln klar wurde warum diese dann nicht sagen konnten worin dieser Sinn bestand.

Isn’t this why those to whom, after prolonged doubts, the meaning of life became clear have then been unable to say what that meaning amounted to? [See 6.521 (2).]

Isn’t this why those to whom, after prolonged doubts, the meaning of life became clear have then been unable to say what that meaning amounted to? [See 6.521 (2).]

The solution of the problem of life is the vanishing of the problem.

7 July, 1916

Wenn ich mir eine „Art von Gegenständen” denken kann ohne zu wissen ob es solche Gegenstände gibt so muß ich mir ihr Urbild konstruiert haben.

If I can imagine a "kind of object" without knowing whether such objects exist, then I must have constructed their prototype for myself.

If I can imagine a "kind of object" without knowing whether such objects exist, then I must have constructed their prototype for myself.

7 July, 1916

Beruht hierauf nicht die Methode der Mechanik?

Isn't the method of mechanics based on this?

Isn't the method of mechanics based on this?

8 July, 1916

Leider, leider! Ich habe keine Ruhe zum Arbeiten!

Very unfortunately, I have no peace for work!

8 July, 1916

An einen Gott glauben heißt die Frage nach / dem Sinne des Lebens verstehen.

To believe in a God means to understand the question of the meaning of life.

To believe in a God means to understand the question of the meaning of life.

8 July, 1916

An einen Gott glauben heißt sehen daß es mit den Tatsachen der Welt noch nicht abgetan ist.

To believe in a God means to see that the facts of the world are not the end of the matter.

To believe in a God means to see that the facts of the world are not the end of the matter.

8 July, 1916

An Gott glauben heißt sehen daß das Leben einen Sinn hat.

To believe in God means to see that life has a meaning.

To believe in God means to see that life has a meaning.

8 July, 1916

Die Welt ist mir gegeben, d.h. mein Wille tritt an die Welt ganz von außen als an etwas Fertiges heran.

The world is given to me, i.e. my will enters the world completely from outside as into something that is already complete.

The world is given to me, i.e. my will enters the world completely from outside as into something that is already complete.

8 July, 1916

(Was mein Wille ist das weiß ich noch nicht.)

(What my will is I don’t yet know.)

(What my will is I don’t yet know.)

8 July, 1916

Daher haben wir das Gefühl / daß wir von einem fremden Willen abhängig sind.

That is why we have the feeling of being dependent on an alien will.

That is why we have the feeling of being dependent on an alien will.

8 July, 1916

Wie dem auch sei, jedenfalls sind wir in einem gewissen Sinne abhängig, und das wovon wir abhängig sind können wir Gott nennen.

Be that as it may, at any rate we are dependent in a certain sense, and what we are dependent on we can call God.

Be that as it may, at any rate we are dependent in a certain sense, and what we are dependent on we can call God.

8 July, 1916

Gott wäre in diesem Sinne einfach das Schicksal oder, was dasselbe ist: die – von unserem Willen unabhängige – Welt.

In this sense God would simply be fate, or, what is the same thing: the world, independent of our will.

In this sense God would simply be fate, or, what is the same thing: the world, independent of our will.

8 July, 1916

Vom Schicksal kann ich mich unabhängig machen.

I can make myself independent of fate.

I can make myself independent of fate.

8 July, 1916

Es gibt zwei Gottheiten die Welt und mein unabhängiges Ich.

There are two deities: the world and my independent I.

There are two deities: the world and my independent I.

8 July, 1916

Ich bin entweder glücklich oder unglücklich, das ist alles. Man kann sagen: gut oder böse gibt es nicht.

I am either happy or unhappy, that's all. One can say: good or evil don’t exist.

I am either happy or unhappy, that's all. One can say: good or evil don’t exist.

8 July, 1916

Wer glücklich ist der darf keine Furcht haben. Auch nicht vor dem Tode.

He who is happy must have no fear. Not even of death.

He who is happy must have no fear. Not even of death.

8 July, 1916

Nur wer nicht in der Zeit sondern in der Gegenwart lebt ist glücklich.

Only he who lives not in time but in the present is happy.

Only he who lives not in time but in the present is happy.

8 July, 1916

Für das Leben in der Gegenwart gibt es keinen Tod.

For one who lives in the present, there is no death.

For one who lives in the present, there is no death.

TLP 6·4311 (la)

Death is not an event in life. One does not live to experience death.

If we mean by eternity not infinite temporal duration but timelessness, then someone who lives in the present lives eternally.

Our life is endless, in the same sense in which our visual field is limitless.

Death is not an event in life.

8 July, 1916

Der Tod ist kein Ereignis des Lebens. Er ist keine Tatsache der Welt.

Death is not an event in life. It is not a fact in the world. [Cf. 6.4311 (la).]

Death is not an event in life. It is not a fact in the world. [Cf. 6.4311 (la).]

Death is not an event in life.

TLP 6·4311 (2)

Death is not an event in life. One does not live to experience death.

If we mean by eternity not infinite temporal duration but timelessness, then someone who lives in the present lives eternally.

Our life is endless, in the same sense in which our visual field is limitless.

Death is not an event in life.

8 July, 1916

Wenn man unter Ewigkeit / nicht unendliche Zeitdauer sondern Unzeitlichkeit versteht, dann kann man sagen daß der ewig lebt der in der Gegenwart lebt.

If we mean by eternity not infinite temporal duration but timelessness, then we can say that he who lives in the present lives eternally. [See 6.4311 (2).]

If we mean by eternity not infinite temporal duration but timelessness, then we can say that he who lives in the present lives eternally. [See 6.4311 (2).]

Death is not an event in life.

8 July, 1916

Um glücklich zu leben muß ich in Übereinstimmung sein mit der Welt. Und dies heißt ja „glücklich sein”.

In order to live happily, I must be in agreement with the world. And this is what "being happy" means.

In order to live happily, I must be in agreement with the world. And this is what "being happy" means.

8 July, 1916

Ich bin dann sozusagen in Übereinstimmung mit jenem fremden Willen von dem ich abhängig erscheine. Das heißt: „ich tue den Willen Gottes”.

I am then, so to speak, in agreement with that alien will on which I appear dependent. In other words: "I do the will of God".

I am then, so to speak, in agreement with that alien will on which I appear dependent. In other words: "I do the will of God".

8 July, 1916

Die Furcht vor dem Tode ist das beste Zeichen eines falschen d.h. schlechten Lebens.

Fear of death is the best sign of a false, i.e. bad, life.

Fear of death is the best sign of a false, i.e. bad, life.

8 July, 1916

Wenn mein Gewissen mich aus dem Gleichgewicht bringt, so bin ich nicht in Übereinstimmung mit Etwas. Aber was ist dies? Ist es die Welt?

When my conscience upsets my equilibrium, I am not in agreement with something. But what is this? Is it the world?

When my conscience upsets my equilibrium, I am not in agreement with something. But what is this? Is it the world?

8 July, 1916

Gewiß ist es richtig zu sagen: Das Gewissen ist die Stimme Gottes.

Certainly it is correct to say: Conscience is the voice of God.

Certainly it is correct to say: Conscience is the voice of God.

8 July, 1916

Zum Beispiel: es macht mich unglücklich zu denken daß ich den und den beleidigt habe. Ist das mein Gewissen.

For example: it makes me unhappy to think that I have offended such and such a person. Is that my conscience?

For example: it makes me unhappy to think that I have offended such and such a person. Is that my conscience?

8 July, 1916

Kann man sagen: „handle nach deinem Gewissen, es sei beschaffen wie es mag”?

Can one say, "Act according to your conscience, whatever it may be"?

Can one say, "Act according to your conscience, whatever it may be"?

8 July, 1916

Lebe glücklich!

Live happily.

Live happily.

8 July, 1916

An einen Gott glauben heißt die Frage nach / dem Sinne des Lebens verstehen.

To believe in a God means to understand the question of the meaning of life.

To believe in a God means to understand the question of the meaning of life.

8 July, 1916

An einen Gott glauben heißt sehen daß es mit den Tatsachen der Welt noch nicht abgetan ist.

To believe in a God means to see that the facts of the world are not the end of the matter.

To believe in a God means to see that the facts of the world are not the end of the matter.

8 July, 1916

An Gott glauben heißt sehen daß das Leben einen Sinn hat.

To believe in God means to see that life has a meaning.

To believe in God means to see that life has a meaning.

8 July, 1916

Die Welt ist mir gegeben, d.h. mein Wille tritt an die Welt ganz von außen als an etwas Fertiges heran.

The world is given to me, i.e. my will enters the world completely from outside as into something that is already complete.

The world is given to me, i.e. my will enters the world completely from outside as into something that is already complete.

8 July, 1916

(Was mein Wille ist das weiß ich noch nicht.)

(What my will is I don’t yet know.)

(What my will is I don’t yet know.)

8 July, 1916

Daher haben wir das Gefühl / daß wir von einem fremden Willen abhängig sind.

That is why we have the feeling of being dependent on an alien will.

That is why we have the feeling of being dependent on an alien will.

8 July, 1916

Wie dem auch sei, jedenfalls sind wir in einem gewissen Sinne abhängig, und das wovon wir abhängig sind können wir Gott nennen.

Be that as it may, at any rate we are dependent in a certain sense, and what we are dependent on we can call God.

Be that as it may, at any rate we are dependent in a certain sense, and what we are dependent on we can call God.

8 July, 1916

Gott wäre in diesem Sinne einfach das Schicksal oder, was dasselbe ist: die – von unserem Willen unabhängige – Welt.

In this sense God would simply be fate, or, what is the same thing: the world, independent of our will.

In this sense God would simply be fate, or, what is the same thing: the world, independent of our will.

8 July, 1916

Vom Schicksal kann ich mich unabhängig machen.

I can make myself independent of fate.

I can make myself independent of fate.

8 July, 1916

Es gibt zwei Gottheiten die Welt und mein unabhängiges Ich.

There are two deities: the world and my independent I.

There are two deities: the world and my independent I.

8 July, 1916

Ich bin entweder glücklich oder unglücklich, das ist alles. Man kann sagen: gut oder böse gibt es nicht.

I am either happy or unhappy, that's all. One can say: good or evil don’t exist.

I am either happy or unhappy, that's all. One can say: good or evil don’t exist.

8 July, 1916

Wer glücklich ist der darf keine Furcht haben. Auch nicht vor dem Tode.

He who is happy must have no fear. Not even of death.

He who is happy must have no fear. Not even of death.

8 July, 1916

Nur wer nicht in der Zeit sondern in der Gegenwart lebt ist glücklich.

Only he who lives not in time but in the present is happy.

Only he who lives not in time but in the present is happy.

8 July, 1916

Für das Leben in der Gegenwart gibt es keinen Tod.

For one who lives in the present, there is no death.

For one who lives in the present, there is no death.

TLP 6·4311 (la)

Death is not an event in life. One does not live to experience death.

If we mean by eternity not infinite temporal duration but timelessness, then someone who lives in the present lives eternally.

Our life is endless, in the same sense in which our visual field is limitless.

Death is not an event in life.

8 July, 1916

Der Tod ist kein Ereignis des Lebens. Er ist keine Tatsache der Welt.

Death is not an event in life. It is not a fact in the world. [Cf. 6.4311 (la).]

Death is not an event in life. It is not a fact in the world. [Cf. 6.4311 (la).]

Death is not an event in life.

TLP 6·4311 (2)

Death is not an event in life. One does not live to experience death.

If we mean by eternity not infinite temporal duration but timelessness, then someone who lives in the present lives eternally.

Our life is endless, in the same sense in which our visual field is limitless.

Death is not an event in life.

8 July, 1916

Wenn man unter Ewigkeit / nicht unendliche Zeitdauer sondern Unzeitlichkeit versteht, dann kann man sagen daß der ewig lebt der in der Gegenwart lebt.

If we mean by eternity not infinite temporal duration but timelessness, then we can say that he who lives in the present lives eternally. [See 6.4311 (2).]

If we mean by eternity not infinite temporal duration but timelessness, then we can say that he who lives in the present lives eternally. [See 6.4311 (2).]

Death is not an event in life.

8 July, 1916

Um glücklich zu leben muß ich in Übereinstimmung sein mit der Welt. Und dies heißt ja „glücklich sein”.

In order to live happily, I must be in agreement with the world. And this is what "being happy" means.

In order to live happily, I must be in agreement with the world. And this is what "being happy" means.

8 July, 1916

Ich bin dann sozusagen in Übereinstimmung mit jenem fremden Willen von dem ich abhängig erscheine. Das heißt: „ich tue den Willen Gottes”.

I am then, so to speak, in agreement with that alien will on which I appear dependent. In other words: "I do the will of God".

I am then, so to speak, in agreement with that alien will on which I appear dependent. In other words: "I do the will of God".

8 July, 1916

Die Furcht vor dem Tode ist das beste Zeichen eines falschen d.h. schlechten Lebens.

Fear of death is the best sign of a false, i.e. bad, life.

Fear of death is the best sign of a false, i.e. bad, life.

8 July, 1916

Wenn mein Gewissen mich aus dem Gleichgewicht bringt, so bin ich nicht in Übereinstimmung mit Etwas. Aber was ist dies? Ist es die Welt?

When my conscience upsets my equilibrium, I am not in agreement with something. But what is this? Is it the world?

When my conscience upsets my equilibrium, I am not in agreement with something. But what is this? Is it the world?

8 July, 1916

Gewiß ist es richtig zu sagen: Das Gewissen ist die Stimme Gottes.

Certainly it is correct to say: Conscience is the voice of God.

Certainly it is correct to say: Conscience is the voice of God.

8 July, 1916

Zum Beispiel: es macht mich unglücklich zu denken daß ich den und den beleidigt habe. Ist das mein Gewissen.

For example: it makes me unhappy to think that I have offended such and such a person. Is that my conscience?

For example: it makes me unhappy to think that I have offended such and such a person. Is that my conscience?

8 July, 1916

Kann man sagen: „handle nach deinem Gewissen, es sei beschaffen wie es mag”?

Can one say, "Act according to your conscience, whatever it may be"?

Can one say, "Act according to your conscience, whatever it may be"?

8 July, 1916

Lebe glücklich!

Live happily.

Live happily.

9 July, 1916

Ärgere dich nicht über die Menschen. Die Menschen sind graue Schufte. Und doch darfst du dich nicht über sie ärgern. Ihre Worte dürfen nicht in dich dringen. Wenn sie mich nicht anreden ist es noch leicht / die Ruhe zu bewahren. Aber wenn sie dir gegenüber frech und grob werden dann wallt es in mir auf. Ärgere dich nicht. Ärgern nützt dich gar nichts.

Don’t get annoyed with people. People are grey villains. And yet you mustn’t get annoyed with them. Their words mustn’t get under your skin. If they don’t speak to me, it’s still easy to stay calm. But when they become insulting and rude to you, then it wells up in me. Don’t get annoyed. Getting annoyed doesn’t do you any good.

9 July, 1916

Wenn man nicht die allgemeinste Satzform angeben könnte, dann müßte ein Moment kommen, wo wir plötzlich eine neue Erfahrung machen, sozusagen eine logische.

If the most general propositional form could not be given, then a time would have to come when we suddenly had a new experience, a logical one, as it were.

If the most general propositional form could not be given, then a time would have to come when we suddenly had a new experience, a logical one, as it were.

9 July, 1916

Dies ist natürlich unmöglich.

That is impossible, of course.

That is impossible, of course.

9 July, 1916

Nicht vergessen, daß (∃x) fx nicht heißt; es gibt ein x so daß fx, sondern: es gibt einen wahren Satz „fx”.

Don't forget that (∃x) fx does not mean: There is an x such that fx, but: There is a true proposition "fx".

Don't forget that (∃x) fx does not mean: There is an x such that fx, but: There is a true proposition "fx".

9 July, 1916

Der Satz fa spricht von bestimmten / Gegenständen, der allgemeine Satz von allen Gegenständen.

The proposition fa speaks of particular objects, the general proposition of all objects.

The proposition fa speaks of particular objects, the general proposition of all objects.

9 July, 1916

Wenn man nicht die allgemeinste Satzform angeben könnte, dann müßte ein Moment kommen, wo wir plötzlich eine neue Erfahrung machen, sozusagen eine logische.

If the most general propositional form could not be given, then a time would have to come when we suddenly had a new experience, a logical one, as it were.

If the most general propositional form could not be given, then a time would have to come when we suddenly had a new experience, a logical one, as it were.

9 July, 1916

Dies ist natürlich unmöglich.

That is impossible, of course.

That is impossible, of course.

9 July, 1916

Nicht vergessen, daß (∃x) fx nicht heißt; es gibt ein x so daß fx, sondern: es gibt einen wahren Satz „fx”.

Don't forget that (∃x) fx does not mean: There is an x such that fx, but: There is a true proposition "fx".

Don't forget that (∃x) fx does not mean: There is an x such that fx, but: There is a true proposition "fx".

9 July, 1916

Der Satz fa spricht von bestimmten / Gegenständen, der allgemeine Satz von allen Gegenständen.

The proposition fa speaks of particular objects, the general proposition of all objects.

The proposition fa speaks of particular objects, the general proposition of all objects.

11 July, 1916

Der bestimmte Gegenstand ist eine sehr merkwürdige Erscheinung.

The particular object is a very remarkable phenomenon.

The particular object is a very remarkable phenomenon.

11 July, 1916

Statt „alle Gegenstände” könnte man sagen: alle bestimmten Gegenstände.

Instead of "all objects" one could say: all particular objects.

Instead of "all objects" one could say: all particular objects.

TLP 5·524 (1)*

Once the objects are given, then thereby all objects are given to us.

Once the elementary sentences are given, then thereby all elementary sentences are given.

Once objects are given, that itself gives us all objects.

11 July, 1916

Wenn alle bestimmten Gegenstände gegeben sind, sind „alle Gegenstände” gegeben. Kurz mit den bestimmten Gegenständen sind alle Gegenstände gegeben.

Once the particular objects are given, then “all objects” are given. In short, all objects are given along with the particular objects. [Cf. 5.524 (1).]

Once the particular objects are given, then “all objects” are given. In short, all objects are given along with the particular objects. [Cf. 5.524 (1).]

Once objects are given, that itself gives us all objects.

TLP 5·524 (1)*

Once the objects are given, then thereby all objects are given to us.

Once the elementary sentences are given, then thereby all elementary sentences are given.

Once objects are given, that itself gives us all objects.

11 July, 1916

Wenn es Gegenstände gibt, gibt es damit auch „alle Gegenstände”.

Once objects are given, then thereby “all objects” are given. [Cf. 5.524 (1).]

Once objects are given, then thereby “all objects” are given. [Cf. 5.524 (1).]

Once objects are given, that itself gives us all objects.

11 July, 1916

Darum muß sich auch die Einheit der Elementarsätze und der allgemeinen Sätze herstellen lassen.

That’s why the unity of elementary propositions and general propositions must be established.

That’s why the unity of elementary propositions and general propositions must be established.

TLP 5·524 (2)

Once the objects are given, then thereby all objects are given to us.

Once the elementary sentences are given, then thereby all elementary sentences are given.

Once objects are given, that itself gives us all objects.

11 July, 1916

Wenn nämlich die Elementarsätze gegeben sind, so sind damit auch alle Elementarsätze gegeben und damit der allgemeine Satz. – Und ist damit nicht schon die Einheit hergestellt.

Once the elementary propositions are given, then thereby all elementary propositions are given. And with that, hasn’t the unity already been established?

Once the elementary propositions are given, then thereby all elementary propositions are given. And with that, hasn’t the unity already been established?

Once objects are given, that itself gives us all objects.

11 July, 1916

Der bestimmte Gegenstand ist eine sehr merkwürdige Erscheinung.

The particular object is a very remarkable phenomenon.

The particular object is a very remarkable phenomenon.

11 July, 1916

Statt „alle Gegenstände” könnte man sagen: alle bestimmten Gegenstände.

Instead of "all objects" one could say: all particular objects.

Instead of "all objects" one could say: all particular objects.

TLP 5·524 (1)*

Once the objects are given, then thereby all objects are given to us.

Once the elementary sentences are given, then thereby all elementary sentences are given.

Once objects are given, that itself gives us all objects.

11 July, 1916

Wenn alle bestimmten Gegenstände gegeben sind, sind „alle Gegenstände” gegeben. Kurz mit den bestimmten Gegenständen sind alle Gegenstände gegeben.

Once the particular objects are given, then “all objects” are given. In short, all objects are given along with the particular objects. [Cf. 5.524 (1).]

Once the particular objects are given, then “all objects” are given. In short, all objects are given along with the particular objects. [Cf. 5.524 (1).]

Once objects are given, that itself gives us all objects.

TLP 5·524 (1)*

Once the objects are given, then thereby all objects are given to us.

Once the elementary sentences are given, then thereby all elementary sentences are given.

Once objects are given, that itself gives us all objects.

11 July, 1916

Wenn es Gegenstände gibt, gibt es damit auch „alle Gegenstände”.

Once objects are given, then thereby “all objects” are given. [Cf. 5.524 (1).]

Once objects are given, then thereby “all objects” are given. [Cf. 5.524 (1).]

Once objects are given, that itself gives us all objects.

11 July, 1916

Darum muß sich auch die Einheit der Elementarsätze und der allgemeinen Sätze herstellen lassen.

That’s why the unity of elementary propositions and general propositions must be established.

That’s why the unity of elementary propositions and general propositions must be established.

TLP 5·524 (2)

Once the objects are given, then thereby all objects are given to us.

Once the elementary sentences are given, then thereby all elementary sentences are given.

Once objects are given, that itself gives us all objects.

11 July, 1916

Wenn nämlich die Elementarsätze gegeben sind, so sind damit auch alle Elementarsätze gegeben und damit der allgemeine Satz. – Und ist damit nicht schon die Einheit hergestellt.

Once the elementary propositions are given, then thereby all elementary propositions are given. And with that, hasn’t the unity already been established?

Once the elementary propositions are given, then thereby all elementary propositions are given. And with that, hasn’t the unity already been established?

Once objects are given, that itself gives us all objects.

12 July, 1916

Immer wieder fühlt man daß auch im Elementarsatz von allen Gegenständen die Rede ist.

(∃x) . φx . x = a

Time and again, one has the feeling that even in an elementary proposition all objects are mentioned.

(∃x) . φx . x = a

Time and again, one has the feeling that even in an elementary proposition all objects are mentioned.

(∃x) . φx . x = a

12 July, 1916

Immer wieder fühlt man daß auch im Elementarsatz von allen Gegenständen die Rede ist.

(∃x) . φx . x = a

Time and again, one has the feeling that even in an elementary proposition all objects are mentioned.

(∃x) . φx . x = a

Time and again, one has the feeling that even in an elementary proposition all objects are mentioned.

(∃x) . φx . x = a

13 July, 1916

Wenn zwei Operationen gegeben sind die sich nicht auf eine reduzieren lassen, so muß sich zum mindesten / eine allgemeine Form ihrer Kombination aufstellen lassen.

If two operations are given which can’t be reduced to one, then it must at least be possible to set up a general form of their combination.

If two operations are given which can’t be reduced to one, then it must at least be possible to set up a general form of their combination.

TLP 5·503*

Obviously, it is easy to state how sentences may and may not be constructed by means of this operation. Hence there must be an exact way in which this can find expression.

Obviously, it is easy to express how propositions may and may not be constructed using this operation. So there must be some way of expressing this exactly.

13 July, 1916

φx, ψy ∣ χz, (∃x) ∙ , (x) ∙

Da sich offenbar leicht erklären läßt wie mit diesen Operationen sich Sätze bilden lassen und wie Sätze nicht zu bilden sind so muß sich dies auch irgendwie exakt ausdrücken lassen.

φx, ψy ∣ χz, (∃x) ∙ , (x) ∙

Obviously, it is easy to explain how propositions may and may not be constructed by means of this operation. Hence there must also somehow be an exact way in which this can find expression.

φx, ψy ∣ χz, (∃x) ∙ , (x) ∙

Obviously, it is easy to explain how propositions may and may not be constructed by means of this operation. Hence there must also somehow be an exact way in which this can find expression.

Obviously, it is easy to express how propositions may and may not be constructed using this operation. So there must be some way of expressing this exactly.

13 July, 1916

Wenn zwei Operationen gegeben sind die sich nicht auf eine reduzieren lassen, so muß sich zum mindesten / eine allgemeine Form ihrer Kombination aufstellen lassen.

If two operations are given which can’t be reduced to one, then it must at least be possible to set up a general form of their combination.

If two operations are given which can’t be reduced to one, then it must at least be possible to set up a general form of their combination.

TLP 5·503*

Obviously, it is easy to state how sentences may and may not be constructed by means of this operation. Hence there must be an exact way in which this can find expression.

Obviously, it is easy to express how propositions may and may not be constructed using this operation. So there must be some way of expressing this exactly.

13 July, 1916

φx, ψy ∣ χz, (∃x) ∙ , (x) ∙

Da sich offenbar leicht erklären läßt wie mit diesen Operationen sich Sätze bilden lassen und wie Sätze nicht zu bilden sind so muß sich dies auch irgendwie exakt ausdrücken lassen.

φx, ψy ∣ χz, (∃x) ∙ , (x) ∙
