Obviously, it is easy to express how propositions may and may not be constructed using this operation. So there must be some way of expressing this exactly.

14 July, 1916

Die Gnade der Arbeit.

The blessing of work.

14 July, 1916

Und dieser Ausdruck muß auch schon in der allgemeinen Form des Operationszeichens gegeben sein.

And this expression must also already be given in the general form of the operation sign.

And this expression must also already be given in the general form of the operation sign.

14 July, 1916

Ja muß dies nicht der einzige legitime Ausdruck der Anwendung der Operation sein. Offenbar / ja!

After all, mustn’t this be the only legitimate expression of the application of an operation? Obviously the answer is yes!

After all, mustn’t this be the only legitimate expression of the application of an operation? Obviously the answer is yes!

14 July, 1916

Denn wenn die Operationsform überhaupt ausgedrückt werden kann, dann muß sie es so, daß sie nur richtig angewendet werden kann.

For if the operation form can be expressed at all, then it must be expressed in such a way that it can only be applied correctly.

For if the operation form can be expressed at all, then it must be expressed in such a way that it can only be applied correctly.

14 July, 1916

Was aber ist der richtige Ausdruck für (∃x) . φx?

But what is the correct expression for (∃x) . φx?

But what is the correct expression for (∃x) . φx?

14 July, 1916

(∃α) . [φα ∣ ψβ …]

∣ (ξ,η) … = φ0 (x, y, …)

(∃x).φ0 (x, y, …), (∃y):(∃x).φ0 (x, y …)

(∃α)∴(∃α):(∃α).φ0(α,α,α, …)

(∃α){φ0 (α …)} …

(∃α) . [φα ∣ ψβ …]

∣ (ξ,η) … = φ0 (x, y, …)

(∃x).φ0 (x, y, …), (∃y):(∃x).φ0 (x, y …)

(∃α)∴(∃α):(∃α).φ0(α,α,α, …)

(∃α){φ0 (α …)} …

(∃α) . [φα ∣ ψβ …]

∣ (ξ,η) … = φ0 (x, y, …)

(∃x).φ0 (x, y, …), (∃y):(∃x).φ0 (x, y …)

(∃α)∴(∃α):(∃α).φ0(α,α,α, …)

(∃α){φ0 (α …)} …

14 July, 1916

Jetzt noch das Abwechseln zwischen (∃x) und (x) ausdrücken. Dann aber die Allgemeinheit der Form wie in der Ancestral Relation!

Now to express the alternation between (∃x) and (x). In this case, however, generality of form as in the ancestral relation.

Now to express the alternation between (∃x) and (x). In this case, however, generality of form as in the ancestral relation.

14 July, 1916

aRx . xRy . yRz … uRb

∙ xRy{aRx} …

aRx . xRy . yRz … uRb

∙ xRy{aRx} …

aRx . xRy . yRz … uRb

∙ xRy{aRx} …

14 July, 1916

Und dieser Ausdruck muß auch schon in der allgemeinen Form des Operationszeichens gegeben sein.

And this expression must also already be given in the general form of the operation sign.

And this expression must also already be given in the general form of the operation sign.

14 July, 1916

Ja muß dies nicht der einzige legitime Ausdruck der Anwendung der Operation sein. Offenbar / ja!

After all, mustn’t this be the only legitimate expression of the application of an operation? Obviously the answer is yes!

After all, mustn’t this be the only legitimate expression of the application of an operation? Obviously the answer is yes!

14 July, 1916

Denn wenn die Operationsform überhaupt ausgedrückt werden kann, dann muß sie es so, daß sie nur richtig angewendet werden kann.

For if the operation form can be expressed at all, then it must be expressed in such a way that it can only be applied correctly.

For if the operation form can be expressed at all, then it must be expressed in such a way that it can only be applied correctly.

14 July, 1916

Was aber ist der richtige Ausdruck für (∃x) . φx?

But what is the correct expression for (∃x) . φx?

But what is the correct expression for (∃x) . φx?

14 July, 1916

∣ (ξ,η) … = φ0 (x, y, …)

14 July, 1916

aRx . xRy . yRz … uRb

∙ xRy{aRx} …

aRx . xRy . yRz … uRb

∙ xRy{aRx} …

15 July, 1916

(∃(aRx.xRy …zRb))

aRb ⌵ aRx.xRb ⌵ aRx xRy ∙ yRb ⌵ … ⌵ aRx ∙ xRy ∙ yRZ ∙ … uRb

Hier kann vernünftigerweise nicht von einer Existenz von Dingen die Rede sein da auch der Satz aRb schon den Bedingungen entspricht.

(∃(aRx.xRy …zRb))

aRb ⌵ aRx.xRb ⌵ aRx xRy ∙ yRb ⌵ … ⌵ aRx ∙ xRy ∙ yRZ ∙ … uRb

Here it isn’t appropriate to talk of things existing since the proposition aRb already meets the conditions.

(∃(aRx.xRy …zRb))

aRb ⌵ aRx.xRb ⌵ aRx xRy ∙ yRb ⌵ … ⌵ aRx ∙ xRy ∙ yRZ ∙ … uRb

Here it isn’t appropriate to talk of things existing since the proposition aRb already meets the conditions.

15 July, 1916

Nichts scheint einfacher zu sein als ein Satz wie „a ist ein Nachkomme von b”!

Nothing seems simpler than a proposition such as "a is a descendant of b"!

Nothing seems simpler than a proposition such as "a is a descendant of b"!

15 July, 1916

(∃(aRx.xRy …zRb))

aRb ⌵ aRx.xRb ⌵ aRx xRy ∙ yRb ⌵ … ⌵ aRx ∙ xRy ∙ yRZ ∙ … uRb

Hier kann vernünftigerweise nicht von einer Existenz von Dingen die Rede sein da auch der Satz aRb schon den Bedingungen entspricht.

(∃(aRx.xRy …zRb))

aRb ⌵ aRx.xRb ⌵ aRx xRy ∙ yRb ⌵ … ⌵ aRx ∙ xRy ∙ yRZ ∙ … uRb

Here it isn’t appropriate to talk of things existing since the proposition aRb already meets the conditions.

(∃(aRx.xRy …zRb))

aRb ⌵ aRx.xRb ⌵ aRx xRy ∙ yRb ⌵ … ⌵ aRx ∙ xRy ∙ yRZ ∙ … uRb

Here it isn’t appropriate to talk of things existing since the proposition aRb already meets the conditions.

15 July, 1916

Nichts scheint einfacher zu sein als ein Satz wie „a ist ein Nachkomme von b”!

Nothing seems simpler than a proposition such as "a is a descendant of b"!

Nothing seems simpler than a proposition such as "a is a descendant of b"!

16 July, 1916

Furchtbare Witterung. Im Gebirge, schlecht, ganz unzureichend geschützt eisige Kälte, Regen und Nebel. Qualvolles Leben. Furchtbar schwierig sich nicht zu verlieren. Denn ich bin ja ein schwacher Mensch. Aber der Geist hilft mir. Am besten wär's ich wäre schon krank dann hätte ich wenigstens ein bißchen Ruhe.

Terrible weather. In the mountains, miserable, quite hopelessly protected from icy cold, rain, and fog. A life full of torment. Terribly difficult not to lose oneself. Because I am indeed a weak man. But the spirit helps me. It would be best if I were already ill, then at least I would have a little rest.

16 July, 1916

xRy. – – ξ ∙ ξRη

xRy ∙ yRz

xRy ∙ yRz ∙ zRu ∙ ξRη (– – Rξ) …

xRy. – – ξ ∙ ξRη

xRy ∙ yRz

xRy ∙ yRz ∙ zRu ∙ ξRη (– – Rξ) …

xRy. – – ξ ∙ ξRη

xRy ∙ yRz

xRy ∙ yRz ∙ zRu ∙ ξRη (– – Rξ) …

16 July, 1916

xRy. – – ξ ∙ ξRη

xRy ∙ yRz

xRy ∙ yRz ∙ zRu ∙ ξRη (– – Rξ) …

xRy. – – ξ ∙ ξRη

xRy ∙ yRz

xRy ∙ yRz ∙ zRu ∙ ξRη (– – Rξ) …

xRy. – – ξ ∙ ξRη

xRy ∙ yRz

xRy ∙ yRz ∙ zRu ∙ ξRη (– – Rξ) …

19 July, 1916

Ärgere mich noch immer. Bin ein schwacher Mensch.

Still get annoyed. Am a weak man.

20 July, 1916

Arbeite nur fort damit du gut wirst.

Keep on working so that you may become good.

20 July, 1916

Meine alte Einteilung aller Satzformen war im Grunde richtig nur daß eine andere Art der Allgemeinheit benötigt wird.

My old classification of all propositional forms was correct in principle except that a different kind of generality is required.

My old classification of all propositional forms was correct in principle except that a different kind of generality is required.

20 July, 1916

Der Mensch kann sich nicht ohne weiteres glücklich machen.

Man cannot make himself happy without difficulty.

Man cannot make himself happy without difficulty.

20 July, 1916

Wer in der Gegenwart lebt, lebt ohne Furcht und Hoffnung.

Whoever lives in the present lives without fear and hope.

Whoever lives in the present lives without fear and hope.

20 July, 1916

Meine alte Einteilung aller Satzformen war im Grunde richtig nur daß eine andere Art der Allgemeinheit benötigt wird.

My old classification of all propositional forms was correct in principle except that a different kind of generality is required.

My old classification of all propositional forms was correct in principle except that a different kind of generality is required.

20 July, 1916

Der Mensch kann sich nicht ohne weiteres glücklich machen.

Man cannot make himself happy without difficulty.

Man cannot make himself happy without difficulty.

20 July, 1916

Wer in der Gegenwart lebt, lebt ohne Furcht und Hoffnung.

Whoever lives in the present lives without fear and hope.

Whoever lives in the present lives without fear and hope.

21 July, 1916

Was für eine Bewandtnis hat es eigentlich mit dem menschlichen / Willen? Ich will „Willen” vor allem den Träger von Gut und Böse nennen.

What is the real significance of the human will? First and foremost, I want to speak of "will" as the bearer of good and evil.

What is the real significance of the human will? First and foremost, I want to speak of "will" as the bearer of good and evil.

21 July, 1916

Stellen wir uns einen Menschen vor der keines seiner Glieder gebrauchen und daher im gewöhnlichen Sinne seinen Willen nicht betätigen könnte. Er könnte aber denken und wünschen und einem anderen seine Gedanken mitteilen. Könnte also auch durch den Anderen Böses oder Gutes tun. Dann ist klar daß die Ethik auch für ihn Geltung hätte und er im ethischen Sinne Träger eines Willens ist.

Let us imagine a person who could use none of his limbs and so couldn’t exercise his will in the ordinary sense. He could, however, think and want and communicate his thoughts to another. So he could also do evil or good through the other. Then it is clear that ethics would apply to him too, and that he is the bearer of a will in the ethical sense.

Let us imagine a person who could use none of his limbs and so couldn’t exercise his will in the ordinary sense. He could, however, think and want and communicate his thoughts to another. So he could also do evil or good through the other. Then it is clear that ethics would apply to him too, and that he is the bearer of a will in the ethical sense.

21 July, 1916

Ist nun ein prinzipieller Unterschied zwischen diesem / Willen und dem der den menschlichen Körper in Bewegung setzt?

Now is there any relevant difference between this will and the one which sets the human body in motion?

Now is there any relevant difference between this will and the one which sets the human body in motion?

21 July, 1916

Oder liegt hier der Fehler darin daß auch schon das Wünschen (resp. Denken) eine Handlung des Willens ist? (Und in diesem Sinne wäre allerdings der Mensch ohne Willen nicht lebendig.)

Or is the mistake here that even this wanting ( thinking) is an activity of the will? (And in this sense, indeed, a man without will would not be alive.)

Or is the mistake here that even this wanting ( thinking) is an activity of the will? (And in this sense, indeed, a man without will would not be alive.)

21 July, 1916

Ist aber ein Wesen denkbar das nur vorstellen (etwa sehen) aber gar nicht wollen könnte. In irgend einem Sinne scheint dies unmöglich. Wäre es aber möglich dann könnte es auch eine Welt geben ohne Ethik.

But is a being conceivable that could only represent (see, perhaps) but not will at all? In some sense this seems impossible. But if it were possible then there could also be a world without ethics.

But is a being conceivable that could only represent (see, perhaps) but not will at all? In some sense this seems impossible. But if it were possible then there could also be a world without ethics.

21 July, 1916

Was für eine Bewandtnis hat es eigentlich mit dem menschlichen / Willen? Ich will „Willen” vor allem den Träger von Gut und Böse nennen.

What is the real significance of the human will? First and foremost, I want to speak of "will" as the bearer of good and evil.

What is the real significance of the human will? First and foremost, I want to speak of "will" as the bearer of good and evil.

21 July, 1916

Stellen wir uns einen Menschen vor der keines seiner Glieder gebrauchen und daher im gewöhnlichen Sinne seinen Willen nicht betätigen könnte. Er könnte aber denken und wünschen und einem anderen seine Gedanken mitteilen. Könnte also auch durch den Anderen Böses oder Gutes tun. Dann ist klar daß die Ethik auch für ihn Geltung hätte und er im ethischen Sinne Träger eines Willens ist.

Let us imagine a person who could use none of his limbs and so couldn’t exercise his will in the ordinary sense. He could, however, think and want and communicate his thoughts to another. So he could also do evil or good through the other. Then it is clear that ethics would apply to him too, and that he is the bearer of a will in the ethical sense.

Let us imagine a person who could use none of his limbs and so couldn’t exercise his will in the ordinary sense. He could, however, think and want and communicate his thoughts to another. So he could also do evil or good through the other. Then it is clear that ethics would apply to him too, and that he is the bearer of a will in the ethical sense.

21 July, 1916

Ist nun ein prinzipieller Unterschied zwischen diesem / Willen und dem der den menschlichen Körper in Bewegung setzt?

Now is there any relevant difference between this will and the one which sets the human body in motion?

Now is there any relevant difference between this will and the one which sets the human body in motion?

21 July, 1916

Oder liegt hier der Fehler darin daß auch schon das Wünschen (resp. Denken) eine Handlung des Willens ist? (Und in diesem Sinne wäre allerdings der Mensch ohne Willen nicht lebendig.)

Or is the mistake here that even this wanting ( thinking) is an activity of the will? (And in this sense, indeed, a man without will would not be alive.)

Or is the mistake here that even this wanting ( thinking) is an activity of the will? (And in this sense, indeed, a man without will would not be alive.)

21 July, 1916

Ist aber ein Wesen denkbar das nur vorstellen (etwa sehen) aber gar nicht wollen könnte. In irgend einem Sinne scheint dies unmöglich. Wäre es aber möglich dann könnte es auch eine Welt geben ohne Ethik.

But is a being conceivable that could only represent (see, perhaps) but not will at all? In some sense this seems impossible. But if it were possible then there could also be a world without ethics.

But is a being conceivable that could only represent (see, perhaps) but not will at all? In some sense this seems impossible. But if it were possible then there could also be a world without ethics.

24 July, 1916

Werden beschossen. Und bei jedem Schuß zuckt meine Seele zusammen. Ich möchte so gerne noch weiter leben!

Taking fire. And with every shot my soul flinches. I want so much to stay alive!

 TLP 5·621

The world and life are one.

The world and life are one.

24 July, 1916

Die Welt und das Leben sind Eins.

The world and life are one. [5.621.]

The world and life are one. [5.621.]

The world and life are one.

24 July, 1916

Das physiologische Leben ist natürlich nicht „das Leben”. Und auch nicht das psychologische. Das Leben, ist die Welt.

Of course, physiological life is not "life". And neither is psychological life. Life is the world.

Of course, physiological life is not "life". And neither is psychological life. Life is the world.

TLP 6·421 (2)

It is clear that ethics cannot be proclaimed.

(Ethics and aesthetics are one.)

Clearly, ethics cannot be put into words.

24 July, 1916

Die Ethik handelt nicht von der Welt. Die Ethik muß eine Bedingung der Welt sein wie die Logik.

Ethics is not about the world. Ethics must be a condition of the world, like logic.

Ethics is not about the world. Ethics must be a condition of the world, like logic.

Clearly, ethics cannot be put into words.

TLP 6·421 (3)*

It is clear that ethics cannot be proclaimed.

(Ethics and aesthetics are one.)

Clearly, ethics cannot be put into words.

24 July, 1916

Ethik und Ästhetik sind Eins.

Ethics and aesthetics are one and the same. [See 6.421.]

Ethics and aesthetics are one and the same. [See 6.421.]

Clearly, ethics cannot be put into words.

TLP 5·621

The world and life are one.

The world and life are one.

24 July, 1916

Die Welt und das Leben sind Eins.

The world and life are one. [5.621.]

The world and life are one. [5.621.]

The world and life are one.

24 July, 1916

Das physiologische Leben ist natürlich nicht „das Leben”. Und auch nicht das psychologische. Das Leben, ist die Welt.

Of course, physiological life is not "life". And neither is psychological life. Life is the world.

Of course, physiological life is not "life". And neither is psychological life. Life is the world.

TLP 6·421 (2)

It is clear that ethics cannot be proclaimed.

(Ethics and aesthetics are one.)

Clearly, ethics cannot be put into words.

24 July, 1916

Die Ethik handelt nicht von der Welt. Die Ethik muß eine Bedingung der Welt sein wie die Logik.

Ethics is not about the world. Ethics must be a condition of the world, like logic.

Ethics is not about the world. Ethics must be a condition of the world, like logic.

Clearly, ethics cannot be put into words.

TLP 6·421 (3)*

It is clear that ethics cannot be proclaimed.

(Ethics and aesthetics are one.)

Clearly, ethics cannot be put into words.

24 July, 1916

Ethik und Ästhetik sind Eins.

Ethics and aesthetics are one and the same. [See 6.421.]

Ethics and aesthetics are one and the same. [See 6.421.]

Clearly, ethics cannot be put into words.

26 July, 1916

Rührenden Brief von David. Er schreibt, sein Bruder sei in Frankreich gefallen. Schrecklich! Dieser liebe freundliche Brief öffnet mir die Augen darüber wie ich hier in der Verbannung lebe. Es mag eine heilsame / Verbannung sein aber ich fühle sie jetzt als Verbannung. Ich bin unter lauter Larven verbannt und muß mit diesen unter den widerlichsten Umständen leben. Und in dieser Umgebung soll ich ein gutes Leben führen und mich läutern. Aber das ist furchtbar schwer! Ich bin zu schwach. Ich bin zu schwach! Gott helfe mir.

Moving letter from David. He writes that his brother died in France. Dreadful! This dear friendly letter opens my eyes to the way in which I live in exile here. It may be a salutary exile, but at the moment I feel it as an exile. I’m exiled among monsters and must live with them in the most repulsive circumstances. And in this company I ought to lead a good life and purify myself. But that's terribly difficult! I’m too weak. I’m too weak. God help me.

29 July, 1916

Wurde gestern beschossen. War verzagt! Ich hatte Angst vor dem Tode!

Was under fire yesterday. Was despondent! I was afraid of death!

 TLP 6·43 (3)

If good or bad willing changes the world, it can only change the limits of the world, not the facts; not what can be expressed by language.

In short, the world will in this way have to become entirely different in kind. It must, so to speak, wax or wane as a whole.

The world of a happy person is a different one from that of an unhappy person.

If good or bad willing changes the world, it can only change the limits of the world, not the facts; not what can be expressed in language, but only what language expresses.

29 July, 1916

Denn daß der Wunsch mit seiner Erfüllung in keinem logischen Zusammenhang steht ist eine logische Tatsache. Und daß die Welt des Glücklichen / eine andere ist als die Welt des Unglücklichen ist auch klar.

For it is a fact of logic that wanting has no logical connection with its fulfillment. And it is also clear that the world of the happy man is a different one from that of the unhappy man. [Cf. 6.43.]

For it is a fact of logic that wanting has no logical connection with its fulfillment. And it is also clear that the world of the happy man is a different one from that of the unhappy man. [Cf. 6.43.]

If good or bad willing changes the world, it can only change the limits of the world, not the facts; not what can be expressed in language, but only what language expresses.

29 July, 1916

Ist sehen eine Tätigkeit?

Is seeing an activity?

Is seeing an activity?

29 July, 1916

Kann man gut wollen, böse wollen und nicht wollen?

Is it possible to will good, to will evil, and not to will?

Is it possible to will good, to will evil, and not to will?

29 July, 1916

Oder ist nur der glücklich der nicht will?

Or is only he happy who does not will?

Or is only he happy who does not will?

29 July, 1916

„Seinen Nächsten lieben” das hieße, Wollen!

"To love one's neighbor" would amount to willing!

"To love one's neighbor" would amount to willing!

29 July, 1916

Kann man aber wünschen und doch nicht unglücklich sein wenn der Wunsch nicht in Erfüllung geht?

(Und diese Möglichkeit / besteht ja immer.)

But can one want and yet not be unhappy if the wish is not fulfilled?

(And this possibility always exists).

But can one want and yet not be unhappy if the wish is not fulfilled?

(And this possibility always exists).

29 July, 1916

Ist es, nach den allgemeinen Begriffen, gut, seinem Nächsten nichts zu wünschen, weder Gutes noch Schlechtes?

Is it, in general terms, good to want nothing for one's neighbor, neither good nor bad?

Is it, in general terms, good to want nothing for one's neighbor, neither good nor bad?

29 July, 1916

Und doch scheint in einem gewissen Sinne das nicht Wünschen das einzig Gute zu sein.

And yet not wanting seems to be the only good, in a certain sense.

And yet not wanting seems to be the only good, in a certain sense.

29 July, 1916

Hier mache ich noch grobe Fehler! Kein Zweifel!

I am still making serious mistakes here! No doubt!

I am still making serious mistakes here! No doubt!

29 July, 1916

Allgemein wird angenommen, daß es böse ist dem Anderen Unglück zu wünschen. Kann das richtig sein? Kann es schlechter sein / als dem anderen Glück zu wünschen?

Es scheint da sozusagen darauf anzukommen, wie man wünscht.

It is generally supposed that it is evil to want the other person to be unhappy. Can that be right? Can it be worse than wanting the other to be happy?

It seems to depend on how one wishes, in a sense.

It is generally supposed that it is evil to want the other person to be unhappy. Can that be right? Can it be worse than wanting the other to be happy?

It seems to depend on how one wishes, in a sense.

29 July, 1916

Man scheint nicht mehr sagen zu können als: Lebe glücklich!

It seems one can't say anything more than: Live happily!

It seems one can't say anything more than: Live happily!

TLP 6·43 (3)

If good or bad willing changes the world, it can only change the limits of the world, not the facts; not what can be expressed by language.

In short, the world will in this way have to become entirely different in kind. It must, so to speak, wax or wane as a whole.

The world of a happy person is a different one from that of an unhappy person.

If good or bad willing changes the world, it can only change the limits of the world, not the facts; not what can be expressed in language, but only what language expresses.

29 July, 1916

Die Welt des Glücklichen ist eine andere als die des Unglücklichen.

The world of the happy man is a different one from that of the unhappy man. [6.43 (3).]

The world of the happy man is a different one from that of the unhappy man. [6.43 (3).]

If good or bad willing changes the world, it can only change the limits of the world, not the facts; not what can be expressed in language, but only what language expresses.

29 July, 1916

Die Welt des Glücklichen ist eine glückliche Welt.

The world of the happy man is a happy world.

The world of the happy man is a happy world.

29 July, 1916

Kann es also eine Welt geben die weder glücklich noch unglücklich ist?

Then can there be a world that is neither happy nor unhappy?

Then can there be a world that is neither happy nor unhappy?

TLP 6·43 (3)

If good or bad willing changes the world, it can only change the limits of the world, not the facts; not what can be expressed by language.

In short, the world will in this way have to become entirely different in kind. It must, so to speak, wax or wane as a whole.

The world of a happy person is a different one from that of an unhappy person.

If good or bad willing changes the world, it can only change the limits of the world, not the facts; not what can be expressed in language, but only what language expresses.

29 July, 1916

Denn daß der Wunsch mit seiner Erfüllung in keinem logischen Zusammenhang steht ist eine logische Tatsache. Und daß die Welt des Glücklichen / eine andere ist als die Welt des Unglücklichen ist auch klar.

For it is a fact of logic that wanting has no logical connection with its fulfillment. And it is also clear that the world of the happy man is a different one from that of the unhappy man. [Cf. 6.43.]

For it is a fact of logic that wanting has no logical connection with its fulfillment. And it is also clear that the world of the happy man is a different one from that of the unhappy man. [Cf. 6.43.]

If good or bad willing changes the world, it can only change the limits of the world, not the facts; not what can be expressed in language, but only what language expresses.

29 July, 1916

Ist sehen eine Tätigkeit?

Is seeing an activity?

Is seeing an activity?

29 July, 1916

Kann man gut wollen, böse wollen und nicht wollen?

Is it possible to will good, to will evil, and not to will?

Is it possible to will good, to will evil, and not to will?

29 July, 1916

Oder ist nur der glücklich der nicht will?

Or is only he happy who does not will?

Or is only he happy who does not will?

29 July, 1916

„Seinen Nächsten lieben” das hieße, Wollen!

"To love one's neighbor" would amount to willing!

"To love one's neighbor" would amount to willing!

29 July, 1916

Kann man aber wünschen und doch nicht unglücklich sein wenn der Wunsch nicht in Erfüllung geht?

(Und diese Möglichkeit / besteht ja immer.)

But can one want and yet not be unhappy if the wish is not fulfilled?

(And this possibility always exists).

But can one want and yet not be unhappy if the wish is not fulfilled?

(And this possibility always exists).

29 July, 1916

Ist es, nach den allgemeinen Begriffen, gut, seinem Nächsten nichts zu wünschen, weder Gutes noch Schlechtes?

Is it, in general terms, good to want nothing for one's neighbor, neither good nor bad?

Is it, in general terms, good to want nothing for one's neighbor, neither good nor bad?

29 July, 1916

Und doch scheint in einem gewissen Sinne das nicht Wünschen das einzig Gute zu sein.

And yet not wanting seems to be the only good, in a certain sense.

And yet not wanting seems to be the only good, in a certain sense.

29 July, 1916

Hier mache ich noch grobe Fehler! Kein Zweifel!

I am still making serious mistakes here! No doubt!

I am still making serious mistakes here! No doubt!

29 July, 1916

Allgemein wird angenommen, daß es böse ist dem Anderen Unglück zu wünschen. Kann das richtig sein? Kann es schlechter sein / als dem anderen Glück zu wünschen?

Es scheint da sozusagen darauf anzukommen, wie man wünscht.

It is generally supposed that it is evil to want the other person to be unhappy. Can that be right? Can it be worse than wanting the other to be happy?

It seems to depend on how one wishes, in a sense.

It is generally supposed that it is evil to want the other person to be unhappy. Can that be right? Can it be worse than wanting the other to be happy?

It seems to depend on how one wishes, in a sense.

29 July, 1916

Man scheint nicht mehr sagen zu können als: Lebe glücklich!

It seems one can't say anything more than: Live happily!

It seems one can't say anything more than: Live happily!

TLP 6·43 (3)

If good or bad willing changes the world, it can only change the limits of the world, not the facts; not what can be expressed by language.

In short, the world will in this way have to become entirely different in kind. It must, so to speak, wax or wane as a whole.

The world of a happy person is a different one from that of an unhappy person.

If good or bad willing changes the world, it can only change the limits of the world, not the facts; not what can be expressed in language, but only what language expresses.

29 July, 1916

Die Welt des Glücklichen ist eine andere als die des Unglücklichen.

The world of the happy man is a different one from that of the unhappy man. [6.43 (3).]

The world of the happy man is a different one from that of the unhappy man. [6.43 (3).]

If good or bad willing changes the world, it can only change the limits of the world, not the facts; not what can be expressed in language, but only what language expresses.

29 July, 1916

Die Welt des Glücklichen ist eine glückliche Welt.

The world of the happy man is a happy world.

The world of the happy man is a happy world.

29 July, 1916

Kann es also eine Welt geben die weder glücklich noch unglücklich ist?

Then can there be a world that is neither happy nor unhappy?

Then can there be a world that is neither happy nor unhappy?

30 July, 1916

Komisch: Heute ärgere ich mich darüber daß ich / bei der Infanterie wo ich jetzt in Verpflegung bin nicht Offiziersmenage bekomme wie mir anfangs in Aussicht gestellt wurde. Ich benehme mich also im höchsten Grade kindisch und schlecht. Aber trotzdem kann ich meinen Ärger über das erlittene Unrecht nicht bemeistern. Immer wieder muß ich daran denken, und wie ihm etwa abgeholfen werden könnte. So dumm ist der Mensch.

Funny: Today I am annoyed that in the infantry, where I am now billeted, I do not get the officers' rations as was initially promised to me. So I’m behaving extremely childishly, and badly. But still I can’t cope with my annoyance at the injustice suffered. I have to keep thinking about it and how it could be remedied. People are so stupid.

 TLP 6·422

When an ethical law of the form “You ought to…” is laid down, one's first thought is, “And what’s going to happen if I don’t do it?” But clearly ethics has nothing to do with punishment and reward in the ordinary sense. So this question about the consequences of an action must be irrelevant. – At least these consequences must not be events. For there must be something right about that way of asking the question after all. While there must be a kind of ethical reward and punishment, these are bound to reside in the action itself.

(And it is clear also that the reward must be something pleasant, the punishment something unpleasant.)

When an ethical law of the form “Thou shalt…” is laid down, one's first thought is, “So then what if I don’t do it?” But clearly ethics has nothing to do with punishment and reward in the ordinary sense. So this question about the consequences of an action must be irrelevant. At least these consequences could not be events. For there must be something right about that question after all. There must be a kind of ethical reward and punishment, but these must be involved in the action itself. (And it is clear also that the reward must be something pleasant, the punishment something unpleasant.)

30 July, 1916

Der erste Gedanke bei der Aufstellung eines allgemeinen ethischen Gesetzes von der Form „Du sollst … ” ist: „Und was dann, wenn ich es nicht tue?”.

Es ist aber klar daß die Ethik nichts mit Strafe und Lohn zu tun hat. Also muß diese Frage nach den Folgen einer Handlung belanglos sein. Zum Mindesten dürfen diese Folgen nicht Ereignisse sein. Denn etwas muß doch an jener Fragestellung richtig sein. Es muß zwar eine Art von Lohn und ethischer Strafe geben aber diese müssen in der Handlung / selbst liegen.

Und das ist auch klar daß der Lohn etwas Angenehmes die Strafe etwas Unangenehmes sein muß.

When an ethical law of the form “You ought to…” is laid down, one's first thought is, “And what’s going to happen if I don’t do it?”

But clearly ethics has nothing to do with punishment and reward in the ordinary sense. So this question about the consequences of an action must be irrelevant. – At least these consequences must not be events. For there must be something right about that way of asking the question after all. While there must be a kind of ethical reward and punishment, these are bound to reside in the action itself.

And it is clear also that the reward must be something pleasant, the punishment something unpleasant. [See 6.422.]

When an ethical law of the form “You ought to…” is laid down, one's first thought is, “And what’s going to happen if I don’t do it?”

But clearly ethics has nothing to do with punishment and reward in the ordinary sense. So this question about the consequences of an action must be irrelevant. – At least these consequences must not be events. For there must be something right about that way of asking the question after all. While there must be a kind of ethical reward and punishment, these are bound to reside in the action itself.

And it is clear also that the reward must be something pleasant, the punishment something unpleasant. [See 6.422.]

When an ethical law of the form “Thou shalt…” is laid down, one's first thought is, “So then what if I don’t do it?” But clearly ethics has nothing to do with punishment and reward in the ordinary sense. So this question about the consequences of an action must be irrelevant. At least these consequences could not be events. For there must be something right about that question after all. There must be a kind of ethical reward and punishment, but these must be involved in the action itself. (And it is clear also that the reward must be something pleasant, the punishment something unpleasant.)

30 July, 1916

Immer wieder komme ich darauf zurück, daß einfach das glückliche Leben gut das unglückliche schlecht ist. Und wenn ich mich jetzt frage: aber warum soll ich gerade glücklich leben so erscheint mir das von selbst als eine tautologische Fragestellung; es scheint daß sich das glückliche Leben von selbst rechtfertigt, daß es das einzig richtige Leben ist.

I keep coming back to this: that only the happy life is good, the unhappy life bad. And if I now ask myself: "but why should I even live happily?" this of itself strikes me as a tautological question. It seems that the happy life is self-justifying, that it is the only right life.

I keep coming back to this: that only the happy life is good, the unhappy life bad. And if I now ask myself: "but why should I even live happily?" this of itself strikes me as a tautological question. It seems that the happy life is self-justifying, that it is the only right life.

TLP 6·421 (1)

It is clear that ethics cannot be proclaimed.

(Ethics and aesthetics are one.)

Clearly, ethics cannot be put into words.

30 July, 1916

Alles dies ist eigentlich in gewissem Sinne tief geheimnisvoll! Es ist klar daß sich die Ethik nicht aussprechen läßt!

In some curious sense all this is actually deeply mysterious!! Clearly, ethics cannot be proclaimed! [Cf. 6.421.]

In some curious sense all this is actually deeply mysterious!! Clearly, ethics cannot be proclaimed! [Cf. 6.421.]

Clearly, ethics cannot be put into words.

30 July, 1916

Man könnte aber so sagen: Das glückliche Leben scheint in irgend einem Sinne harmonischer zu sein als das unglückliche. In welchem aber??

But one could say: The happy life seems to be more harmonious than the unhappy one, in some sense. But in what sense??

But one could say: The happy life seems to be more harmonious than the unhappy one, in some sense. But in what sense??

30 July, 1916

Was ist das objektive Merkmal des glücklichen, harmonischen Lebens? Da ist es wieder klar daß es kein solches Merkmal, das sich beschreiben ließe, geben kann.

Dies Merkmal kann kein physisches sondern nur ein metaphysisches, / ein transcendentes sein.

What is the objective characteristic of the happy, harmonious life? Here it is again clear that there can be no such characteristic that can be described.

This characteristic cannot be a physical one but only a metaphysical one, a transcendent one.

What is the objective characteristic of the happy, harmonious life? Here it is again clear that there can be no such characteristic that can be described.

This characteristic cannot be a physical one but only a metaphysical one, a transcendent one.

TLP 6·421 (2)

It is clear that ethics cannot be proclaimed.

(Ethics and aesthetics are one.)

Clearly, ethics cannot be put into words.

30 July, 1916

Die Ethik ist transcendent.

Ethics is transcendent. [See 6.421.]

Ethics is transcendent. [See 6.421.]

Clearly, ethics cannot be put into words.

TLP 6·422

When an ethical law of the form “You ought to…” is laid down, one's first thought is, “And what’s going to happen if I don’t do it?” But clearly ethics has nothing to do with punishment and reward in the ordinary sense. So this question about the consequences of an action must be irrelevant. – At least these consequences must not be events. For there must be something right about that way of asking the question after all. While there must be a kind of ethical reward and punishment, these are bound to reside in the action itself.

(And it is clear also that the reward must be something pleasant, the punishment something unpleasant.)

When an ethical law of the form “Thou shalt…” is laid down, one's first thought is, “So then what if I don’t do it?” But clearly ethics has nothing to do with punishment and reward in the ordinary sense. So this question about the consequences of an action must be irrelevant. At least these consequences could not be events. For there must be something right about that question after all. There must be a kind of ethical reward and punishment, but these must be involved in the action itself. (And it is clear also that the reward must be something pleasant, the punishment something unpleasant.)

30 July, 1916

Der erste Gedanke bei der Aufstellung eines allgemeinen ethischen Gesetzes von der Form „Du sollst … ” ist: „Und was dann, wenn ich es nicht tue?”.

Es ist aber klar daß die Ethik nichts mit Strafe und Lohn zu tun hat. Also muß diese Frage nach den Folgen einer Handlung belanglos sein. Zum Mindesten dürfen diese Folgen nicht Ereignisse sein. Denn etwas muß doch an jener Fragestellung richtig sein. Es muß zwar eine Art von Lohn und ethischer Strafe geben aber diese müssen in der Handlung / selbst liegen.

Und das ist auch klar daß der Lohn etwas Angenehmes die Strafe etwas Unangenehmes sein muß.

When an ethical law of the form “You ought to…” is laid down, one's first thought is, “And what’s going to happen if I don’t do it?”

But clearly ethics has nothing to do with punishment and reward in the ordinary sense. So this question about the consequences of an action must be irrelevant. – At least these consequences must not be events. For there must be something right about that way of asking the question after all. While there must be a kind of ethical reward and punishment, these are bound to reside in the action itself.

And it is clear also that the reward must be something pleasant, the punishment something unpleasant. [See 6.422.]

But clearly ethics has nothing to do with punishment and reward in the ordinary sense. So this question about the consequences of an action must be irrelevant. – At least these consequences must not be events. For there must be something right about that way of asking the question after all. While there must be a kind of ethical reward and punishment, these are bound to reside in the action itself.

And it is clear also that the reward must be something pleasant, the punishment something unpleasant. [See 6.422.]

When an ethical law of the form “Thou shalt…” is laid down, one's first thought is, “So then what if I don’t do it?” But clearly ethics has nothing to do with punishment and reward in the ordinary sense. So this question about the consequences of an action must be irrelevant. At least these consequences could not be events. For there must be something right about that question after all. There must be a kind of ethical reward and punishment, but these must be involved in the action itself. (And it is clear also that the reward must be something pleasant, the punishment something unpleasant.)

30 July, 1916

Immer wieder komme ich darauf zurück, daß einfach das glückliche Leben gut das unglückliche schlecht ist. Und wenn ich mich jetzt frage: aber warum soll ich gerade glücklich leben so erscheint mir das von selbst als eine tautologische Fragestellung; es scheint daß sich das glückliche Leben von selbst rechtfertigt, daß es das einzig richtige Leben ist.

I keep coming back to this: that only the happy life is good, the unhappy life bad. And if I now ask myself: "but why should I even live happily?" this of itself strikes me as a tautological question. It seems that the happy life is self-justifying, that it is the only right life.

I keep coming back to this: that only the happy life is good, the unhappy life bad. And if I now ask myself: "but why should I even live happily?" this of itself strikes me as a tautological question. It seems that the happy life is self-justifying, that it is the only right life.

TLP 6·421 (1)

It is clear that ethics cannot be proclaimed.

(Ethics and aesthetics are one.)

Clearly, ethics cannot be put into words.

30 July, 1916

Alles dies ist eigentlich in gewissem Sinne tief geheimnisvoll! Es ist klar daß sich die Ethik nicht aussprechen läßt!

In some curious sense all this is actually deeply mysterious!! Clearly, ethics cannot be proclaimed! [Cf. 6.421.]

In some curious sense all this is actually deeply mysterious!! Clearly, ethics cannot be proclaimed! [Cf. 6.421.]

Clearly, ethics cannot be put into words.

30 July, 1916

Man könnte aber so sagen: Das glückliche Leben scheint in irgend einem Sinne harmonischer zu sein als das unglückliche. In welchem aber??

But one could say: The happy life seems to be more harmonious than the unhappy one, in some sense. But in what sense??

But one could say: The happy life seems to be more harmonious than the unhappy one, in some sense. But in what sense??

30 July, 1916

Was ist das objektive Merkmal des glücklichen, harmonischen Lebens? Da ist es wieder klar daß es kein solches Merkmal, das sich beschreiben ließe, geben kann.

Dies Merkmal kann kein physisches sondern nur ein metaphysisches, / ein transcendentes sein.

What is the objective characteristic of the happy, harmonious life? Here it is again clear that there can be no such characteristic that can be described.

This characteristic cannot be a physical one but only a metaphysical one, a transcendent one.

What is the objective characteristic of the happy, harmonious life? Here it is again clear that there can be no such characteristic that can be described.

This characteristic cannot be a physical one but only a metaphysical one, a transcendent one.

TLP 6·421 (2)

It is clear that ethics cannot be proclaimed.

(Ethics and aesthetics are one.)

Clearly, ethics cannot be put into words.

30 July, 1916

Die Ethik ist transcendent.

Ethics is transcendent. [See 6.421.]

Ethics is transcendent. [See 6.421.]

Clearly, ethics cannot be put into words.

1 August, 1916

Wie sich alles verhält, ist Gott.

How things stand, is God.

How things stand, is God.

1 August, 1916

Gott ist, wie sich alles verhält.

God is, how things stand.

God is, how things stand.

1 August, 1916

Nur aus dem Bewußtsein der Einzigkeit meines Lebens entspringt Religion – Wissenschaft – und Kunst.

Only out of a consciousness of the uniqueness of my life do religion - science - and art arise.

Only out of a consciousness of the uniqueness of my life do religion - science - and art arise.

1 August, 1916

Wie sich alles verhält, ist Gott.

How things stand, is God.

How things stand, is God.

1 August, 1916

Gott ist, wie sich alles verhält.

God is, how things stand.

God is, how things stand.

1 August, 1916

Nur aus dem Bewußtsein der Einzigkeit meines Lebens entspringt Religion – Wissenschaft – und Kunst.

Only out of a consciousness of the uniqueness of my life do religion - science - and art arise.

Only out of a consciousness of the uniqueness of my life do religion - science - and art arise.

2 August, 1916

Und dieses Bewußtsein ist das Leben selber.

And this consciousness is life itself.

And this consciousness is life itself.

2 August, 1916

Kann es eine Ethik geben wenn es außer mir kein Lebewesen gibt?

Can there be any ethics if there is no living being other than myself?

Can there be any ethics if there is no living being other than myself?

2 August, 1916

Wenn die Ethik etwas Grundlegendes sein soll, || : ja!.

If ethics is supposed to be something fundamental, there can.

If ethics is supposed to be something fundamental, there can.

2 August, 1916

Wenn ich recht habe; so genügt es nicht zum ethischen Urteil, daß eine Welt gegeben sei.

Die Welt ist dann an sich weder gut noch böse.

If I am right, then it is not sufficient for ethical judgment that a world is given.

Then the world in itself is neither good nor evil.

If I am right, then it is not sufficient for ethical judgment that a world is given.

Then the world in itself is neither good nor evil.

2 August, 1916

Denn es muß für die Existenz der Ethik gleich bleiben ob es auf der Welt lebende Materie gibt oder nicht. Und es ist klar daß eine Welt in der nur tote Materie ist an sich weder gut noch böse ist also kann auch die Welt der Lebewesen an sich weder gut noch böse sein.

As far as the existence of ethics is concerned, it must make no difference whether there is living matter in the world or not. And if it is clear that a world in which there is only dead matter is in itself neither good nor evil, then even the world of living creatures can in itself be neither good nor evil.

As far as the existence of ethics is concerned, it must make no difference whether there is living matter in the world or not. And if it is clear that a world in which there is only dead matter is in itself neither good nor evil, then even the world of living creatures can in itself be neither good nor evil.

TLP 5·632

The subject is a limit, not a part, of the world.

The subject is not part of the world, but a limit of the world.

2 August, 1916

Gut und Böse tritt erst durch das Subjekt ein. Und das Subjekt gehört nicht zur Welt sondern ist eine Grenze der Welt.

Good and evil enter only through the subject. And the subject is a limit, not a part, of the world. [Cf. 5.632.]

Good and evil enter only through the subject. And the subject is a limit, not a part, of the world. [Cf. 5.632.]

The subject is not part of the world, but a limit of the world.

2 August, 1916

Man könnte (Schopenhauerisch) sagen: Die Welt der Vorstellung ist weder gut noch böse, sondern das wollende Subjekt.

One could say (Schopenhauerianly): It is not the world as idea that is either good or evil, but the willing subject.

One could say (Schopenhauerianly): It is not the world as idea that is either good or evil, but the willing subject.

2 August, 1916

Die völlige Unklarheit aller dieser Sätze ist mir bewußt.

I am conscious of the complete unclarity of all these sentences.

I am conscious of the complete unclarity of all these sentences.

2 August, 1916

Nach dem Früheren müßte also das wollende Subjekt glücklich oder unglücklich sein und Glück und Unglück / können nicht zur Welt gehören.

According to the foregoing, the willing subject would have to be happy or unhappy, and happiness and unhappiness could not be part of the world.

According to the foregoing, the willing subject would have to be happy or unhappy, and happiness and unhappiness could not be part of the world.

2 August, 1916

Wie das Subjekt kein Teil der Welt ist sondern eine Voraussetzung ihrer Existenz so sind Gut und Böse, Prädikate des Subjekts, nicht Eigenschaften in der Welt.

As the subject is not a part of the world but a presupposition of its existence, so good and evil, which are predicates of the subject, are not properties in the world.

As the subject is not a part of the world but a presupposition of its existence, so good and evil, which are predicates of the subject, are not properties in the world.

2 August, 1916

Ganz verschleiert ist hier das Wesen des Subjekts.

The nature of the subject is completely veiled here.

The nature of the subject is completely veiled here.

2 August, 1916

Ja, meine Arbeit hat sich ausgedehnt von den Grundlagen der Logik zum Wesen der Welt.

Yes, my work has broadened out from the foundations of logic to the essence of the world.

Yes, my work has broadened out from the foundations of logic to the essence of the world.

2 August, 1916

Und dieses Bewußtsein ist das Leben selber.

And this consciousness is life itself.

And this consciousness is life itself.

2 August, 1916

Kann es eine Ethik geben wenn es außer mir kein Lebewesen gibt?

Can there be any ethics if there is no living being other than myself?

Can there be any ethics if there is no living being other than myself?

2 August, 1916

Wenn die Ethik etwas Grundlegendes sein soll, || : ja!.

If ethics is supposed to be something fundamental, there can.

If ethics is supposed to be something fundamental, there can.

2 August, 1916

Wenn ich recht habe; so genügt es nicht zum ethischen Urteil, daß eine Welt gegeben sei.

Die Welt ist dann an sich weder gut noch böse.

If I am right, then it is not sufficient for ethical judgment that a world is given.

Then the world in itself is neither good nor evil.

If I am right, then it is not sufficient for ethical judgment that a world is given.

Then the world in itself is neither good nor evil.

2 August, 1916

Denn es muß für die Existenz der Ethik gleich bleiben ob es auf der Welt lebende Materie gibt oder nicht. Und es ist klar daß eine Welt in der nur tote Materie ist an sich weder gut noch böse ist also kann auch die Welt der Lebewesen an sich weder gut noch böse sein.

As far as the existence of ethics is concerned, it must make no difference whether there is living matter in the world or not. And if it is clear that a world in which there is only dead matter is in itself neither good nor evil, then even the world of living creatures can in itself be neither good nor evil.

As far as the existence of ethics is concerned, it must make no difference whether there is living matter in the world or not. And if it is clear that a world in which there is only dead matter is in itself neither good nor evil, then even the world of living creatures can in itself be neither good nor evil.

TLP 5·632

The subject is a limit, not a part, of the world.

The subject is not part of the world, but a limit of the world.

2 August, 1916

Gut und Böse tritt erst durch das Subjekt ein. Und das Subjekt gehört nicht zur Welt sondern ist eine Grenze der Welt.

Good and evil enter only through the subject. And the subject is a limit, not a part, of the world. [Cf. 5.632.]

Good and evil enter only through the subject. And the subject is a limit, not a part, of the world. [Cf. 5.632.]

The subject is not part of the world, but a limit of the world.

2 August, 1916

Man könnte (Schopenhauerisch) sagen: Die Welt der Vorstellung ist weder gut noch böse, sondern das wollende Subjekt.

One could say (Schopenhauerianly): It is not the world as idea that is either good or evil, but the willing subject.

One could say (Schopenhauerianly): It is not the world as idea that is either good or evil, but the willing subject.

2 August, 1916

Die völlige Unklarheit aller dieser Sätze ist mir bewußt.

I am conscious of the complete unclarity of all these sentences.

I am conscious of the complete unclarity of all these sentences.

2 August, 1916

Nach dem Früheren müßte also das wollende Subjekt glücklich oder unglücklich sein und Glück und Unglück / können nicht zur Welt gehören.

According to the foregoing, the willing subject would have to be happy or unhappy, and happiness and unhappiness could not be part of the world.

According to the foregoing, the willing subject would have to be happy or unhappy, and happiness and unhappiness could not be part of the world.

2 August, 1916

Wie das Subjekt kein Teil der Welt ist sondern eine Voraussetzung ihrer Existenz so sind Gut und Böse, Prädikate des Subjekts, nicht Eigenschaften in der Welt.

As the subject is not a part of the world but a presupposition of its existence, so good and evil, which are predicates of the subject, are not properties in the world.

As the subject is not a part of the world but a presupposition of its existence, so good and evil, which are predicates of the subject, are not properties in the world.

2 August, 1916

Ganz verschleiert ist hier das Wesen des Subjekts.

The nature of the subject is completely veiled here.

The nature of the subject is completely veiled here.

2 August, 1916

Ja, meine Arbeit hat sich ausgedehnt von den Grundlagen der Logik zum Wesen der Welt.

Yes, my work has broadened out from the foundations of logic to the essence of the world.

Yes, my work has broadened out from the foundations of logic to the essence of the world.

4 August, 1916

Ist nicht am Ende das vorstellende Subjekt bloßer / Aberglaube.

Isn’t the subject that entertains ideas ultimately just superstition?

Isn’t the subject that entertains ideas ultimately just superstition?

TLP 5·633*

Where in the world is a metaphysical subject discernable?

You say this is just like the case of the eye and the visual field. But as a matter of fact, you do not see the eye. Aa—a

And nothing in the visual field suggests that it is seen by an eye.

Where in the world is a metaphysical subject to be found? You say this is just like the case of the eye and the visual field. But you do not actually see the eye. And nothing in the visual field would enable one to infer that it is seen by an eye.

4 August, 1916

Wo in der Welt ist ein metaphysisches Subjekt zu merken?

Where in the world is a metaphysical subject discernable? [See 5.633 (1).]

Where in the world is a metaphysical subject discernable? [See 5.633 (1).]

Where in the world is a metaphysical subject to be found? You say this is just like the case of the eye and the visual field. But you do not actually see the eye. And nothing in the visual field would enable one to infer that it is seen by an eye.

TLP 5·633*

Where in the world is a metaphysical subject discernable?

You say this is just like the case of the eye and the visual field. But as a matter of fact, you do not see the eye. Aa—a

And nothing in the visual field suggests that it is seen by an eye.

Where in the world is a metaphysical subject to be found? You say this is just like the case of the eye and the visual field. But you do not actually see the eye. And nothing in the visual field would enable one to infer that it is seen by an eye.

4 August, 1916

Du sagst es verhält sich hier ganz wie bei Auge und Gesichtsfeld. Aber das Auge siehst Du wirklich nicht.

Und ich glaube daß nichts am Gesichtsfeld darauf schließen läßt daß es von einem Auge gesehen wird.

You say this is just like the case of the eye and the visual field. But as a matter of fact, you do not see the eye. [See 5.633 (2).]

And I believe that nothing in the visual field suggests that it is seen by an eye. [Cf. 5.633 (3).]

You say this is just like the case of the eye and the visual field. But as a matter of fact, you do not see the eye. [See 5.633 (2).]

And I believe that nothing in the visual field suggests that it is seen by an eye. [Cf. 5.633 (3).]

Where in the world is a metaphysical subject to be found? You say this is just like the case of the eye and the visual field. But you do not actually see the eye. And nothing in the visual field would enable one to infer that it is seen by an eye.

4 August, 1916

Ist nicht am Ende das vorstellende Subjekt bloßer / Aberglaube.

Isn’t the subject that entertains ideas ultimately just superstition?

Isn’t the subject that entertains ideas ultimately just superstition?

TLP 5·633*

Where in the world is a metaphysical subject discernable?

You say this is just like the case of the eye and the visual field. But as a matter of fact, you do not see the eye. Aa—a

And nothing in the visual field suggests that it is seen by an eye.

Where in the world is a metaphysical subject to be found? You say this is just like the case of the eye and the visual field. But you do not actually see the eye. And nothing in the visual field would enable one to infer that it is seen by an eye.

4 August, 1916

Wo in der Welt ist ein metaphysisches Subjekt zu merken?

Where in the world is a metaphysical subject discernable? [See 5.633 (1).]

Where in the world is a metaphysical subject discernable? [See 5.633 (1).]

Where in the world is a metaphysical subject to be found? You say this is just like the case of the eye and the visual field. But you do not actually see the eye. And nothing in the visual field would enable one to infer that it is seen by an eye.

TLP 5·633*

You say this is just like the case of the eye and the visual field. But as a matter of fact, you do not see the eye. Aa—a

And nothing in the visual field suggests that it is seen by an eye.

4 August, 1916

Du sagst es verhält sich hier ganz wie bei Auge und Gesichtsfeld. Aber das Auge siehst Du wirklich nicht.

Und ich glaube daß nichts am Gesichtsfeld darauf schließen läßt daß es von einem Auge gesehen wird.

You say this is just like the case of the eye and the visual field. But as a matter of fact, you do not see the eye. [See 5.633 (2).]

And I believe that nothing in the visual field suggests that it is seen by an eye. [Cf. 5.633 (3).]

You say this is just like the case of the eye and the visual field. But as a matter of fact, you do not see the eye. [See 5.633 (2).]

And I believe that nothing in the visual field suggests that it is seen by an eye. [Cf. 5.633 (3).]

Where in the world is a metaphysical subject to be found? You say this is just like the case of the eye and the visual field. But you do not actually see the eye. And nothing in the visual field would enable one to infer that it is seen by an eye.

TLP 5·631 (1)

The subject that thinks, entertains ideas: there is no such thing.

If I were to write a book called The World as I Encountered It, then this would also have to report on my body, and say which parts are subject to my will and which are not, etc. For this is a method of isolating the subject, or rather of showing that in an important sense there is no subject; for it alone could not be mentioned in that book.—

The subject that thinks, entertains ideas: there is no such thing.

5 August, 1916

Das vorstellende Subjekt ist wohl leerer Wahn. Das wollende Subjekt aber gibt es.

The subject that entertains ideas is surely an empty illusion. But the willing subject exists. [Cf. 5.631 (1).]

The subject that entertains ideas is surely an empty illusion. But the willing subject exists. [Cf. 5.631 (1).]

The subject that thinks, entertains ideas: there is no such thing.

5 August, 1916

Wäre der Wille nicht, so gäbe es auch nicht jenes Zentrum der Welt das wir das Ich nennen und das der Träger der Ethik ist.

If the will did not exist, neither would that center of the world which we call the I, and which is the bearer of ethics.

If the will did not exist, neither would that center of the world which we call the I, and which is the bearer of ethics.

5 August, 1916

Gut und böse ist wesentlich nur das Ich, nicht die Welt.

It is really only the I, not the world, that is good and evil.

It is really only the I, not the world, that is good and evil.

5 August, 1916

Das Ich, das Ich ist das tief Geheimnisvolle!

The I, the I is profoundly mysterious!

The I, the I is profoundly mysterious!

TLP 5·631 (1)

The subject that thinks, entertains ideas: there is no such thing.

If I were to write a book called The World as I Encountered It, then this would also have to report on my body, and say which parts are subject to my will and which are not, etc. For this is a method of isolating the subject, or rather of showing that in an important sense there is no subject; for it alone could not be mentioned in that book.—

It is really only the I, not the world, that is good and evil.

It is really only the I, not the world, that is good and evil.

5 August, 1916

Das Ich, das Ich ist das tief Geheimnisvolle!

The I, the I is profoundly mysterious!

The I, the I is profoundly mysterious!

6 August, 1916

Nach 3 Tagen Bahnfahrt auf dem Marsch in die Feuerstellung. Nicht bei bester Gesundheit und durch die / Borniertheit und Gemeinheit meiner Umgebung seelisch marod. Gott gib mir Kraft, innere Stärke, der seelischen Krankheit zu trotzen. Gott erhalte mich bei frohem Mute.

Marching to the firing line, after a 3 day rail journey. Not in the best of health and feeling run down, due to the narrow-mindedness and viciousness of my company. God give me the power, the inner strength, to resist sickness of the soul. God save me with joyful courage.

7 August, 1916

Das Ich ist kein Gegenstand.

The I is not an object.

The I is not an object.

7 August, 1916

Das Ich ist kein Gegenstand.

The I is not an object.

The I is not an object.

8 August, 1916

Jedem Gegenstand stehe ich objektiv gegenüber. Dem Ich nicht.

I objectively face every object. Not the I.

I objectively face every object. Not the I.

8 August, 1916

Jedem Gegenstand stehe ich objektiv gegenüber. Dem Ich nicht.

I objectively face every object. Not the I.

I objectively face every object. Not the I.

11 August, 1916

Lebe in der Sünde dahin, d.h. unglücklich. Bin verdrossen, freudlos. Lebe mit meiner ganzen Umgebung in Unfrieden.

Live on in sin, i.e. unhappily. Am morose, joyless. Live at odds with everyone around me.

 TLP 5·641 (1)

So there really is a sense in which in philosophy there is a non-psychological way of speaking of the self.

The self enters into philosophy by way of “the world’s being my world”.

The philosophical self is not the human being, not the human body, nor the human soul, with which psychology deals, but rather the metaphysical subject, the limit – not a part – of the world.

The general form of a truth-function is: [p̅ , ξ̅ , N(ξ̅ )].

This is the general form of a sentence.

So there really is a sense in which there can be talk of the I in a non-psychological way in philosophy. What brings the I into philosophy is that “the world is my world”.

11 August, 1916

Es gibt also wirklich eine Art und Weise, wie in der Philosophie in einem nicht psychologischen Sinne vom Ich die Rede sein kann und muß.

So there really is a way in which in philosophy one can and must speak of the I in a non-psychological sense. [Cf. 5.641 (1).]

So there really is a way in which in philosophy one can and must speak of the I in a non-psychological sense. [Cf. 5.641 (1).]

So there really is a sense in which there can be talk of the I in a non-psychological way in philosophy. What brings the I into philosophy is that “the world is my world”.

TLP 5·641 (1)

So there really is a sense in which in philosophy there is a non-psychological way of speaking of the self.

The self enters into philosophy by way of “the world’s being my world”.

The philosophical self is not the human being, not the human body, nor the human soul, with which psychology deals, but rather the metaphysical subject, the limit – not a part – of the world.

The general form of a truth-function is: [p̅ , ξ̅ , N(ξ̅ )].

This is the general form of a sentence.

So there really is a sense in which there can be talk of the I in a non-psychological way in philosophy. What brings the I into philosophy is that “the world is my world”.

11 August, 1916

Es gibt also wirklich eine Art und Weise, wie in der Philosophie in einem nicht psychologischen Sinne vom Ich die Rede sein kann und muß.

So there really is a way in which in philosophy one can and must speak of the I in a non-psychological sense. [Cf. 5.641 (1).]

So there really is a way in which in philosophy one can and must speak of the I in a non-psychological sense. [Cf. 5.641 (1).]

So there really is a sense in which there can be talk of the I in a non-psychological way in philosophy. What brings the I into philosophy is that “the world is my world”.

12 August, 1916

Du weißt was du zu tun hast um glücklich zu leben; warum tust du es nicht? Weil du unvernünftig bist. Ein schlechtes Leben / ist ein unvernünftiges Leben. Es kommt darauf an sich nicht zu ärgern.

You know what you have to do to live happily; why don’t you do it? Because you’re unreasonable. A bad life is an unreasonable life. It is important not to get annoyed.

 TLP 5·641 (2)

So there really is a sense in which in philosophy there is a non-psychological way of speaking of the self.

The self enters into philosophy by way of “the world’s being my world”.

The philosophical self is not the human being, not the human body, nor the human soul, with which psychology deals, but rather the metaphysical subject, the limit – not a part – of the world.

The general form of a truth-function is: [p̅ , ξ̅ , N(ξ̅ )].

This is the general form of a sentence.

So there really is a sense in which there can be talk of the I in a non-psychological way in philosophy. What brings the I into philosophy is that “the world is my world”.

12 August, 1916

Das Ich tritt in die Philosophie dadurch ein, daß die Welt meine Welt ist.

The I enters into philosophy by way of the world’s being my world. [See 5.641 (2).]

The I enters into philosophy by way of the world’s being my world. [See 5.641 (2).]

So there really is a sense in which there can be talk of the I in a non-psychological way in philosophy. What brings the I into philosophy is that “the world is my world”.

TLP 5·6331**

For the form of the visual field is surely not like this:

The form of the visual field is surely not like this: Eye

12 August, 1916

Das Gesichtsfeld hat nämlich nicht etwa eine solche Form:

The form of the visual field is surely not like this:

The form of the visual field is surely not like this:

The form of the visual field is surely not like this: Eye

TLP 5·634 (1)

What this is connected with is that no part of our experience is a priori too.

Everything we see could also be otherwise.

Everything we can describe at all could also be otherwise.

There is no order of things a priori.

This is connected with no part of our experience being a priori.

12 August, 1916

Das hängt damit zusammen daß kein Teil unserer Erfahrung / a priori ist.

What this is connected with is that no part of our experience is a priori. [See 5.634 (1).]

What this is connected with is that no part of our experience is a priori. [See 5.634 (1).]

This is connected with no part of our experience being a priori.

TLP 5·634 (2-3)

What this is connected with is that no part of our experience is a priori too.

Everything we see could also be otherwise.

Everything we can describe at all could also be otherwise.

There is no order of things a priori.

This is connected with no part of our experience being a priori.

12 August, 1916

Alles was wir sehen, könnte auch anders sein.

Alles was wir überhaupt beschreiben können, könnte auch anders sein.

Everything we see could also be otherwise.

Everything we can describe at all could also be otherwise. [See 5.634 (2-3).]

Everything we see could also be otherwise.

Everything we can describe at all could also be otherwise. [See 5.634 (2-3).]

This is connected with no part of our experience being a priori.

TLP 5·641 (2)

So there really is a sense in which in philosophy there is a non-psychological way of speaking of the self.

The self enters into philosophy by way of “the world’s being my world”.

The philosophical self is not the human being, not the human body, nor the human soul, with which psychology deals, but rather the metaphysical subject, the limit – not a part – of the world.

This is connected with no part of our experience being a priori.

13 August, 1916

Kämpfe noch vergebens gegen meine schwache Natur. Gott stärke mich! ——

Struggle in vain against my weak nature. God strengthen me. ——

13 August, 1916

Angenommen der Mensch könnte seinen Willen nicht betätigen müßte aber alle Not dieser Welt leiden, was könnte ihn dann glücklich machen?

Suppose a man could not exercise his will but had to suffer all the misery of this world, then what could make him happy?

Suppose a man could not exercise his will but had to suffer all the misery of this world, then what could make him happy?

13 August, 1916

Wie kann der Mensch überhaupt glücklich sein, da er doch die Not dieser Welt nicht abwehren kann? /

Eben durch das Leben der Erkenntnis.

How can man be happy at all, since he cannot ward off the misery of this world?

Simply by a life of knowledge.

How can man be happy at all, since he cannot ward off the misery of this world?

Simply by a life of knowledge.

13 August, 1916

Das gute Gewissen ist das Glück welches das Leben der Erkenntnis gewährt.

A life of knowledge offers the happiness of a good conscience.

A life of knowledge offers the happiness of a good conscience.

13 August, 1916

Das Leben der Erkenntnis ist das Leben, welches glücklich ist, der Not der Welt zum Trotz.

A life of knowledge is a life that is happy in spite of the misery of the world.

A life of knowledge is a life that is happy in spite of the misery of the world.

13 August, 1916

Nur das Leben ist glücklich welches auf die Annehmlichkeiten der Welt verzichten kann.

Ihm sind die Annehmlichkeiten der Welt nur so viele Gnaden des Schicksals.

The only life that is happy is the life that can renounce the comforts of the world.

To it the comforts of the world are only so many graces of fate.

The only life that is happy is the life that can renounce the comforts of the world.

To it the comforts of the world are only so many graces of fate.

13 August, 1916

Angenommen der Mensch könnte seinen Willen nicht betätigen müßte aber alle Not dieser Welt leiden, was könnte ihn dann glücklich machen?

Suppose a man could not exercise his will but had to suffer all the misery of this world, then what could make him happy?

Suppose a man could not exercise his will but had to suffer all the misery of this world, then what could make him happy?

13 August, 1916

Wie kann der Mensch überhaupt glücklich sein, da er doch die Not dieser Welt nicht abwehren kann? /

Eben durch das Leben der Erkenntnis.

How can man be happy at all, since he cannot ward off the misery of this world?

Simply by a life of knowledge.

How can man be happy at all, since he cannot ward off the misery of this world?

Simply by a life of knowledge.

13 August, 1916

Das gute Gewissen ist das Glück welches das Leben der Erkenntnis gewährt.

A life of knowledge offers the happiness of a good conscience.

A life of knowledge offers the happiness of a good conscience.

13 August, 1916

Das Leben der Erkenntnis ist das Leben, welches glücklich ist, der Not der Welt zum Trotz.

A life of knowledge is a life that is happy in spite of the misery of the world.

A life of knowledge is a life that is happy in spite of the misery of the world.

13 August, 1916

Nur das Leben ist glücklich welches auf die Annehmlichkeiten der Welt verzichten kann.

Ihm sind die Annehmlichkeiten der Welt nur so viele Gnaden des Schicksals.

The only life that is happy is the life that can renounce the comforts of the world.

To it the comforts of the world are only so many graces of fate.

The only life that is happy is the life that can renounce the comforts of the world.

To it the comforts of the world are only so many graces of fate.

TLP 6·3751 (1-2)**

For instance, for two colours to be at the same place in the visual field simultaneously is impossible, indeed logically impossible, for it is ruled out by the logical structure of colour.

Remember how this contradiction presents itself in physics: roughly, that a particle cannot have two velocities at the same time; and hence that particles in different places at the same time cannot be identical.

(It is clear the logical product of two elementary sentences can neither be a tautology nor a contradiction. The statement that a point in the visual field has two different colours at the same time is a contradiction.)

For instance, for two colours to be at the same place in the visual field simultaneously is impossible, indeed logically impossible, for it is subject to the logical structure of colour. Let us look at how this contradiction appears in physics: roughly, that a particle cannot have two velocities at the same time; that is to say, particles in different places at the same time cannot be the same particle.

16 August, 1916

Daß ein Punkt nicht zugleich rot und grün sein kann muß dem ersten Anschein nach keine logische Unmöglichkeit sein. Aber schon die physikalische Ausdrucksweise reduziert sie zu einer kinetischen Unmöglichkeit. Man sieht zwischen Rot und Grün besteht eine Verschiedenheit der Struktur.

Und nun ordnet sie die Physik gar noch in eine Reihe. Und nun sieht man wie hier die wahre Struktur der Gegenstände ans Licht gebracht wird.

Daß ein Teilchen nicht zu gleicher Zeit an zwei Orten sein kann das / sieht schon vielmehr aus wie eine logische Unmöglichkeit.

Fragen wir z.B. warum so taucht sofort der Gedanke auf: Nun wir würden eben Teilchen die sich an zwei Orten befänden verschiedene nennen, und das scheint alles wieder aus der Struktur des Raumes und der Teilchen zu folgen.

That a point cannot be red and green at the same time may not seem to be a logical impossibility at first sight. But the very language of physics itself reduces it to a kinetic impossibility. One sees there is a difference in structure between red and green.

And now physics arranges them even further, into a series. And now one sees here how the true structure of objects is brought to light.

That a particle cannot be in two places at the same time does rather look like a logical impossibility.

If we ask why, for example, then the thought immediately comes up: Well, we would call particles that were in two places different, and this all seems to follow in turn from the structure of space and of particles. [Cf. 6.3751.]

That a point cannot be red and green at the same time may not seem to be a logical impossibility at first sight. But the very language of physics itself reduces it to a kinetic impossibility. One sees there is a difference in structure between red and green.

And now physics arranges them even further, into a series. And now one sees here how the true structure of objects is brought to light.

That a particle cannot be in two places at the same time does rather look like a logical impossibility.

If we ask why, for example, then the thought immediately comes up: Well, we would call particles that were in two places different, and this all seems to follow in turn from the structure of space and of particles. [Cf. 6.3751.]

For instance, for two colours to be at the same place in the visual field simultaneously is impossible, indeed logically impossible, for it is subject to the logical structure of colour. Let us look at how this contradiction appears in physics: roughly, that a particle cannot have two velocities at the same time; that is to say, particles in different places at the same time cannot be the same particle.
