TLP 1·21

Something can either be the case or not be the case while everything else remains the same.

What is the case—a fact—is the obtaining of states of affairs.

Each one can either be the case or not be the case and all else remains the same.

27 November, 1916

Entweder eine Tatsache ist in einer anderen enthalten, oder sie ist unabhängig von ihr.

[Text to be supplied]

[Text to be supplied]

Each one can either be the case or not be the case and all else remains the same.

TLP 1·21

Something can either be the case or not be the case while everything else remains the same.

What is the case—a fact—is the obtaining of states of affairs.

Each one can either be the case or not be the case and all else remains the same.

27 November, 1916

Entweder eine Tatsache ist in einer anderen enthalten, oder sie ist unabhängig von ihr.

[Text to be supplied]

[Text to be supplied]

Each one can either be the case or not be the case and all else remains the same.

TLP 3.11.14 (12)** 2.12.16 (1)+ (Pilch: 5·3221)

2 December, 1916

Die Ähnlichkeit der Allgemeinheitsbezeichnung mit dem Argument zeigt sich wenn wir statt φa schreiben (ax).φx.

[Text to be supplied]

[Text to be supplied]

2 December, 1916

Man könnte die Argumente auch so einführen daß sie nur auf einer Seite des Gleichheitszeichens / auftreten. Also immer analog „(∃x) ∙ φx ∙ x = a” statt „φa”.

[Text to be supplied]

[Text to be supplied]

TLP 6·53 a

The right method in philosophy would really be to say nothing except what can be said, i.e. sentences of natural science – i.e. something that has nothing to do with philosophy – and then, whenever someone wanted to say something metaphysical, to demonstrate to him that he had failed to give a meaning to certain signs in his sentences. Although the other person wouldn’t be satisfied – he would not feel we were teaching him philosophy – this method would be the only strictly right one.

The right method in philosophy would really be to say nothing except what can be said, i.e. propositions of natural science – i.e. something that has nothing to do with philosophy – and then, to prove to those wanting to say something metaphysical that they had failed to give a meaning to certain signs in their sentences.

2 December, 1916

Die richtige Methode in der Philosophie wäre eigentlich die nichts zu sagen als was sich sagen läßt also Naturwissenschaftliches also etwas was mit Philosophie nichts zu tun hat. Und dann immer wenn ein anderer etwas Metaphysisches sagen wollte ihm nachweisen daß er gewissen Zeichen in seinen Sätzen keine Bedeutung gegeben hat.

[Text to be supplied]

[Text to be supplied]

The right method in philosophy would really be to say nothing except what can be said, i.e. propositions of natural science – i.e. something that has nothing to do with philosophy – and then, to prove to those wanting to say something metaphysical that they had failed to give a meaning to certain signs in their sentences.

TLP 6·53 b*

The right method in philosophy would really be to say nothing except what can be said, i.e. sentences of natural science – i.e. something that has nothing to do with philosophy – and then, whenever someone wanted to say something metaphysical, to demonstrate to him that he had failed to give a meaning to certain signs in his sentences. Although the other person wouldn’t be satisfied – he would not feel we were teaching him philosophy – this method would be the only strictly right one.

The right method in philosophy would really be to say nothing except what can be said, i.e. propositions of natural science – i.e. something that has nothing to do with philosophy – and then, to prove to those wanting to say something metaphysical that they had failed to give a meaning to certain signs in their sentences.

2 December, 1916

Diese Methode wäre für / den anderen unbefriedigend (er hätte nicht das Gefühl daß wir ihn Philosophie lehrten) aber sie wäre die einzig richtige.

[Text to be supplied]

[Text to be supplied]

The right method in philosophy would really be to say nothing except what can be said, i.e. propositions of natural science – i.e. something that has nothing to do with philosophy – and then, to prove to those wanting to say something metaphysical that they had failed to give a meaning to certain signs in their sentences.

The right method in philosophy would really be to say nothing except what can be said, i.e. propositions of natural science – i.e. something that has nothing to do with philosophy – and then, to prove to those wanting to say something metaphysical that they had failed to give a meaning to certain signs in their sentences.

7 January, 1917

In dem Sinne, in welchem es eine Hierarchie der Sätze gibt, gibt es, natürlich, auch eine Hierarchie der Wahrheiten und der Verneinungen etc.

[Text to be supplied]

[Text to be supplied]

7 January, 1917

In dem Sinne aber in welchem es, im allgemeinsten Sinne, Sätze gibt, gibt es nur eine Wahrheit und eine Verneinung.

[Text to be supplied]

[Text to be supplied]

7 January, 1917

Dieser Sinn wird aus jenem gewonnen indem der Satz im allgemeinen aufgefaßt wird als das Resultat der einen Operation, welche alle Sätze aus der untersten Stufe erzeugt. etc.

[Text to be supplied]

[Text to be supplied]

7 January, 1917

Die unterste Stufe und die Operation kann die ganze Hierarchie vertreten.

[Text to be supplied]Vertreten: stand for

[Text to be supplied]Vertreten: stand for

In dem Sinne, in welchem es eine Hierarchie der Sätze gibt, gibt es, natürlich, auch eine Hierarchie der Wahrheiten und der Verneinungen etc.

[Text to be supplied]

[Text to be supplied]

7 January, 1917

In dem Sinne aber in welchem es, im allgemeinsten Sinne, Sätze gibt, gibt es nur eine Wahrheit und eine Verneinung.

[Text to be supplied]

[Text to be supplied]

7 January, 1917

Dieser Sinn wird aus jenem gewonnen indem der Satz im allgemeinen aufgefaßt wird als das Resultat der einen Operation, welche alle Sätze aus der untersten Stufe erzeugt. etc.

[Text to be supplied]

[Text to be supplied]

7 January, 1917

Die unterste Stufe und die Operation kann die ganze Hierarchie vertreten.

[Text to be supplied]Vertreten: stand for

[Text to be supplied]Vertreten: stand for

TLP 6·3751 (3)**

For instance, for two colours to be at the same place in the visual field simultaneously is impossible, indeed logically impossible, for it is ruled out by the logical structure of colour.

Remember how this contradiction presents itself in physics: roughly, that a particle cannot have two velocities at the same time; and hence that particles in different places at the same time cannot be identical.

(It is clear the logical product of two elementary sentences can neither be a tautology nor a contradiction. The statement that a point in the visual field has two different colours at the same time is a contradiction.)

For instance, for two colours to be at the same place in the visual field simultaneously is impossible, indeed logically impossible, for it is subject to the logical structure of colour. Let us look at how this contradiction appears in physics: roughly, that a particle cannot have two velocities at the same time; that is to say, particles in different places at the same time cannot be the same particle.

8 January, 1917

Es ist klar daß das logische Produkt zweier Elementarsätze nie eine Tautologie sein kann.

[Text to be supplied]

[Text to be supplied]

For instance, for two colours to be at the same place in the visual field simultaneously is impossible, indeed logically impossible, for it is subject to the logical structure of colour. Let us look at how this contradiction appears in physics: roughly, that a particle cannot have two velocities at the same time; that is to say, particles in different places at the same time cannot be the same particle.

8 January, 1917

Ist das logische Produkt zweier Sätze eine Kontradiktion und die Sätze scheinen Elementarsätze zu sein. So sieht man daß in diesem Falle der Schein trügt. (Z.B.: A ist rot und A ist grün.)

[Text to be supplied]

[Text to be supplied]

TLP 6·3751 (3)**

For instance, for two colours to be at the same place in the visual field simultaneously is impossible, indeed logically impossible, for it is ruled out by the logical structure of colour.

Remember how this contradiction presents itself in physics: roughly, that a particle cannot have two velocities at the same time; and hence that particles in different places at the same time cannot be identical.

(It is clear the logical product of two elementary sentences can neither be a tautology nor a contradiction. The statement that a point in the visual field has two different colours at the same time is a contradiction.)

For instance, for two colours to be at the same place in the visual field simultaneously is impossible, indeed logically impossible, for it is subject to the logical structure of colour. Let us look at how this contradiction appears in physics: roughly, that a particle cannot have two velocities at the same time; that is to say, particles in different places at the same time cannot be the same particle.

8 January, 1917

Es ist klar daß das logische Produkt zweier Elementarsätze nie eine Tautologie sein kann.

[Text to be supplied]

[Text to be supplied]

For instance, for two colours to be at the same place in the visual field simultaneously is impossible, indeed logically impossible, for it is subject to the logical structure of colour. Let us look at how this contradiction appears in physics: roughly, that a particle cannot have two velocities at the same time; that is to say, particles in different places at the same time cannot be the same particle.

8 January, 1917

Ist das logische Produkt zweier Sätze eine Kontradiktion und die Sätze scheinen Elementarsätze zu sein. So sieht man daß in diesem Falle der Schein trügt. (Z.B.: A ist rot und A ist grün.)

[Text to be supplied]

[Text to be supplied]

10 January, 1917

Wenn der Selbstmord erlaubt ist dann ist alles erlaubt.

[Text to be supplied]

[Text to be supplied]

10 January, 1917

Wenn etwas nicht erlaubt ist dann ist der Selbstmord nicht erlaubt.

[Text to be supplied]

[Text to be supplied]

10 January, 1917

Dies wirft ein Licht auf das Wesen der Ethik. Denn der Selbstmord ist sozusagen die elementare Sünde.

[Text to be supplied]

[Text to be supplied]

10 January, 1917

Und wenn man ihn untersucht so ist es wie wenn man den Quecksilberdampf untersucht um das Wesen der Dämpfe zu erfassen.

[Text to be supplied]

[Text to be supplied]

10 January, 1917

Wenn der Selbstmord erlaubt ist dann ist alles erlaubt.

[Text to be supplied]

[Text to be supplied]

10 January, 1917

Wenn etwas nicht erlaubt ist dann ist der Selbstmord nicht erlaubt.

[Text to be supplied]

[Text to be supplied]

10 January, 1917

Dies wirft ein Licht auf das Wesen der Ethik. Denn der Selbstmord ist sozusagen die elementare Sünde.

[Text to be supplied]

[Text to be supplied]

10 January, 1917

Und wenn man ihn untersucht so ist es wie wenn man den Quecksilberdampf untersucht um das Wesen der Dämpfe zu erfassen.
